story:
BRINE |

Brine came together as a creative collective of sorts here in Salt Lake City.  Sara Pickett, Ashley Creek and Symmer Andrews built BRINE to be a community organization.  We share assets like rehearsal space, performers, sponsorships, marketing materials etc.  We share those resources so that we can provide a place for an artist to show their creations who otherwise might not be able to do it on their own. 

Our debut performance  being presented by RDT Link Series and is happening in Salt Lake City.  Here are the details: 

  • Brine| an evening of works presented by Sara Pickett, Ashley Creek, Symmer Andrews and Sarah Donohue
  • Gallery of work by Josh Kump
  • Created by Sara Pickett, Ashley Creek and Symmer Andrews
  • Artistic collaboration with Josh Kump, Ben Waymen and Denae Shanidiin
  • When: September 16th and 17th, 2015
  • Where: Leona Wagner Black Box at the Rose Wagner Center for Performing Arts
  • Tickets: $12.00 or $10.00 for Students/Seniors : 
    • https://arttix.artsaltlake.org/single/PSDetail.aspx?psn=15360
  • Facebook Page:  
    • https://www.facebook.com/brinearts

What We Need:

Here is a breakdown of all the expenses incurred in putting on a dance concert here in Salt Lake that we are asking for assistance with:

  • Performance Venue Rental at the Leona Wagner Black Box in the Rose Wagner Center for Performing Arts
  • Lighting Designer
  • Videographer
  • Photographer
  • Graphic Design 
  • Printing costs
  • Media Materials- Posters, Flyers, Programs, etc.
  • Rehearsal space rental
  • Payment for professional dancers 
  • Costumes
  • Event Reception

If We Do Not Reach Our Project Goal:

Any funds that are contributed will still go towards covering the expenses of the concert.  We will be using the funds to pay for media materials, venue rental, payment for services rendered by other artists who contributed to the project to make it happen. 

The Impact

With our debut performance our aim is to create a new presence within the arts scene.  We bring variety.  We bridge the gap between artistic genres and generations.  In the future we strive to be an umbrella under which all artists can gather to share their work while  utilizing resources that might not be available on an individual level.  We see a lot of potential and flexibility within this paradigm of creative teamwork.  

We hope to impact our community by breaking down the elitist perspective about art.  We want to place art back into a community setting so it can be accessible to everyone.  We feel that it is valuable to bring together artists and present a fresh perspective on what art is and how everyone can relate to it.  We love the idea of being immersed in a diverse setting of every avenue of art without obstacles such as exclusion, censorship or lack of resources. 

Risks & Challenges

This is our first collaborative choreographic venture. As such we are working from the ground up to create this new platform for art in our city.  Our biggest challenges include getting enough funds to cover the bare cost of the performance as well as finding spare revenue to be able to pay our professional artists who are helping and participating in this project.  Our main challenge can be found in our efforts to make sure that all available seats are filled for the performance so that we can reach as much of the community as possible.  

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is able to help in a fiscal manner.   As conveyed  above we also need help with building this platform into our community.  Please share our campaign and our Facebook page.  Word of mouth is very helpful and necessary to help get our new project off the ground.  We welcome all sharing  help and give you our gratitude for helping to spread our communal vision.

story:
17th  Seoul Marginal Theatre Festival 2015

"Fifteen Wŏn Fifty Chŏn”

21 July – 2 August 2015

This year's festival takes as its theme questions of exclusion that in recent times seem to have gained a certain velocity in South Korean society. Discrimination and marginalisation towards minorities; the isolation of workers within the capitalist system; over-commercialised universities; histories of confinement; border controls and other matters concerning the "other" as different to a supposed "we". 

The expression "Fifteen Wŏn Fifty Chŏn” comes from the period following the 1923 Great Kanto Earthquake in Japan and the massacre of Korean ("Chosŏn") people accused of inciting rebellion against the imperial Japanese government in the wake of the earthquake's devastation across the Tokyo region. Not just Korean people, but also other minorities, particularly the Chinese Wenzho, those from Okinawa, the Rkukyu and Amami islands, and other people residing in Tokyo from other regions across Japan (particularly those from the Tohoku area) were also killed, imprisoned or tortured on being identified as "other" through their "Korean" pronunciation of this simple phrase: "Fifteen Wŏn Fifty Chŏn". 

And so can be seen too how in contemporary Korean society are also divisions, distinctions, marginalisations and targets to provide scapegoats as a tool of domination. Are we not then also in the process of becoming a society all too willing to eradicate all possible thought of a shared human dignity?

With this year's Seoul Marginal Theatre Festival, through a communal space known as "theatre" within the "stage" of life, moving with our "entire body"* across the borders of "here" or "there", recognising the respectful values of the many marginalised and oppressed, meeting with companionship and hospitable debate, we seek a recovery of feelings lost and offer the potential for a new communal solidarity. 

Inza Lim

Artistic Director

* "Starting (詩作) is not something done with the ‘mind’, and not that which is done with the ‘heart’, it is that which is done via the ‘body’. It is pushing and going onwards with ‘all the body’.” poet Kim Su-Yong (Minumsa: 1975)

Featured artworks 

(for images, see Gallery tab)

"The Crab Cannery Ship" - The Dong Theatre Company 

"Ships that sail the hell of capitalism”

An adaptation of Takiji Kobayashi’s 1929 novel Kanikosen, “The Crab Cannery Ship”, one of Japan’s most well-known and influential novels of “proletarian literature”. Following a true event,  the novel depicts the organization of a group of seasonal fishing workers into unions in response to their exploitation as slave labour under the guise of national industry and capitalist growth, revealing too the mechanisms of the ruling Japanese imperialist government. Through physicality, the performance attempts to understand the novel as a reflection of Korea during the Japanese occupation and to make a space to consider its contemporary legacies. 

"All Night" - Yeonpiltong X Praxis

A performance telling the every day stories of the “jjokbangchon” people, living in the “one-room” alley towns found throughout Korea’s bigger cities. Stories of taking care of each other, families dispersed between South and North, the will to live, eating, sharing songs and gathering together.

"Human Lost" - Jongsun Han

“Human Lost” is a picture exhibition by one of the survivors of the Busan Brothers Bokjiwon Incident which was a major human violation issue that came to light after March 22 1987 when one person was killed and 35 escaped from the largest vocational rehabilitation facility in Korea, housing many young children and teenagers. As one of the “bokjiwon brothers” from 1984-1987, Han Jongsun through pictures, protests and other art works, including in 2012 a one person protest in front of the Korean government, has given witness to the violations that were perpetuated at the complex. As a group these men have continued to develop an active presence to speak their own “truth to power” and recover a sense of human dignity in Korean society. 

"Le Petit JJANCOLAS: Whole Rounded Education" - Bjung Society

"My future dream is to be a cultural citizen!"

A performance reflecting on the growing-up experiences of a “Jjancolas”, a Korean-born boy born of third and fourth generation Taiwanese/Republic of China immigrant parents.  What is the possibility for a fully harmonized education at such a distance from one's“nation” state? Navigating through the perceptions of others, to what state does one belong? 

"Face Reality 2" - 'Giant Girls' gathering to support sex workers rights

“Face Reality 2” is another version of ”Face Reality”, which participated in 'The 1st Human Right Drama Festival 2014'. Both are pure creations where the whole process of writing, directing, acting, organizing is done by members of Giant Girls. Compared to first version which was was a more conventional fiction drama, this second version is a 'free-for-all discussion drama'. Such a change of form follows an aspiration to share the topic of the drama between audience and actors.  Therefore, ”Face Reality 2” will be an artistic space and also a discursive field that unravels the topic of 'Sexworkers' Rights' which in Korea has never been addressed properly.

The performance begins with the story of the prospective writer Yongja Na who publishes her autobiographical novel 'Face Reality',  based on her own experience as a sex-worker. Yongja Na suggests a special event to the audience in the 'Writer’s Talk', which is held to commemorate the publication. She suggests to the audience to have a discussion with her and the "thinking spirits" who appear in her dream and argue with her every night.

Slipping Away - Living Queer Reader's Theatre

An adaptation of the story “Slipping Away” by Jacqueline Woodson, first published in the groundbreaking U.S. collection of queer stories for young people, “Am I Blue” published in the 1990s. “Slipping Away” portrays the complexities and reactions experienced by young people confused about their sexual identity, including the perspecive of their parents; a story that gradually opens the eyes of understanding and sympathy. 

Special Lecture "This is University" - Eunyoung Kwon X Freecamp

A performance that questions “what is the university system?” so over-run by the pressures of entrance examinations and restructuring. How much should we, could we, be in control of it, and what would it Iook like if it could be changed?

"70 Years Old" - Community Theatre of Seoulkedam X Bukjeong Maeul

What does it mean to reach the age of 70 in contemporary Korean society, a society so driven by capitalist growth, and structured on western-centric imperialism? What are the possibilities then for friendship and the memory of community once one reaches such an age? How can the strains of our time be replaced by a greater care for our environment and ecological values? This performance tells a story of group of older people who grew up post-1945 and live in Seoul’s Bukjeong neighbourhood. 

"Living And Thinking As Artist Practice"  - Byungseo Yoo

Last winter, I landed in Berlin. I was selected as the P.s Berlin Residency artist. It is a programme of Can Foundation Seoul and I was the first and only artist it sent. However there was no support for the cost of living. It was a hard time because I didn’t have money. So ironically I had to work while I was being sent to make art work. 

I can`t work in Germany because I`m not supposed to (it is illegal), so I had to work in Seoul. Mainly it was writing and translation. And I also found another small business. It is bottle picking. Unlike in Seoul, Berlin has a funny system called 're-fund'. When you return an empty beer bottle, they give you back 8 cents for each bottle. Germans in general are beer lovers so it is a kind of easy job. So every daytime I went to exhibition and on the way home I picked up empty bottles. And in the night I write and think. So basically what I did in the last 4 months was live and think. 

But I’m an artist so I have to think about art. I have to create something. Just living and thinking can not be creation. So I thought about how I can create art in the situation where I belong. I have thought and thought, thinking day and night. I thought a lot. And finally I came to a sort of conclusion that I can create art where I am now. It is a 'Living and Thinking' combination. I mean, 'Living and Thinking', not 'living' and 'thinking'. Just 'living' is 'living' and 'Thinking' is 'Thinking' but with 'Living And Thinking' combined, there are tiny possibilities that this could be a creation. A creation in the context of contemporary art.

Support / Production:.

In 1999 when the Seoul Marginal Theatre Festival started with the motto of “Free creative and experimental minds”, through its dedication to become an "experimental theatre festival", an ensuing experimentalism developed in relation to new theatre language and forms.  

Through the mid to late 2000s, the institution of the theatre venue was joined with explorations into different kinds of space, including street theatre performances and public art projects. The topic of "city and theatre" was explored through the work of many artists and groups. The gaze of the "marginalised" was foregrounded in the voices of those subjects historically oppressed and marginalised, such as discharged workers and labourers. The festival attempted to exchange ideas about the contemporary and political possibility of, to echo the eponymous novel of Choi In-Hoon, the "square" of theatre. And so over 16 years the festival has continued to evolve as a project to discover the face, voice, discourse, new potentials and strength of imagination to be found in considering the possibilities that might be found within the phrase "art and society". 

The festival has continued to exist through the support and policies of publicly funded art programmes.  For the 17th Seoul Marginal Theatre Festival however, due to changes in government and the conditions under which public policy continues to operate, it was not possible to ensure that the festival would be able to uphold its position of "support is fine, but no interference".

This is not a new phenomenon. In 1973, the Korean Literature Promotion Fund had diminished funds and works that could no longer be supported, or rather, which did not appeal to the central government became, in effect, directly censored. The process of art works lining up for the process of public funding was losing its autonomy. What was defined as a "public" arts funding body quickly revealed itself as a politicised "non-public" institution. Art is political, but art funders too need to become "depoliticised". Only then can art itself naturally grow to be diversely imagined, to consider and communicate the various unseen dimensions of the world. 

Based on this philosophy, in order to secure more independent support and artistic autonomy, the 17th Seoul Marginal Theatre Festival is relieving itself of government support and is making efforts to produce its programme through community support and fund-raising. The act of not receiving government funding is predicted to bring difficulties even for the most basic support of artistic activities. But it is not just a proposal for artistic autonomy - it is also a proposal for beginning a new method of festival, where the artists, supporters and spectators are together and can more actively seek out and be responsible for the subjects that make a contemporary festival. 

Through crowd-funding and invited donations, the 17th Seoul Marginal Theatre Festival welcomes the participation of supporters wishing for meaningful artistic experiment.  

In Korea, donations can be made through www.tumblbug.com/ko/smtfestival

For any queries please contact: smtfestival @ daum.net

Thank you so much for your support!

www.mtfestival.org

story:
Short Summary

“BoyLesque” is a tongue in cheek variety show, which pays tribute to early 20th century American style burlesque comedy and vintage “striptease” performances, but with a twist - this revue has a distinct South African flavour. It is a fun journey through a variety of genres and styles of performance from comedy, cabaret, ballet and drag, to traditional zulu dancing, voguing and of course, the art of tease! 

“Boylesque” began in 2013 and since then  various versions of it have evolved (“The Late Night Varietease”, “Welcome to Burlesque”, “The Late Night XXXmas Boylesque Show”), touring around South Africa, gaining most popularity in Cape Town. Our yearly Christmas runs at the Alexander Upstairs in Strand street have become a tradition!

What We Need & What You Get

It is simple! We need the cheapest flights from Jozi to Cape Town and we have booked the cheapest accommodation (the Sun1)! The total costs come to around only ZAR 10 000!

The Impact

Our show brings a lot of joy to our fans! Just check out our

AUDIENCE FEEDBACK:

“I loved it! The show was smart, stylish, witty, sexy ... The versatile and energetic cast gave their all. Great fun. TELL EVERYONE. There are people creating intriguing, fabulous theatre in a fabulous venue - let's support it!”!!

“We were in stitches! The team from Boylesque hit the right notes - its funny, naughty, sexy, but not offensive. Its a delight! The actors are dynamic and almost addictive. The blend of original material makes it special while we can all have a laugh to some favourites mixed up with perfect comedic timing. Bravo! Brava! Please come back to Cape Town. We need something fresh and new.”!

“The show was hilarious -- good fun!! Dragged a friend of mine with -- wasn't too keen at first but left having enjoyed every minute of it. I particularly loved was homegrown material found from beginning to end -- really refreshing always walking in a show and given local relatable subject matter within a performance so well done to the team on a well rounded show!!!!”!

“Boylesque was everything good entertainment should be... Bravo!”!

We also create much needed employment for Cape Town based performers!

PRESS:

http://artscomments.wordpress.com/2013/05/01/it... 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help out financially, please share our campaign on social media!

“We were in stitches! The team from Boylesque hit the right notes - its funny, naughty, sexy, but not
offensive. Its a delight! The actors are dynamic and almost addictive. The blend of original material
makes it special while we can all have a laugh to some favourites mixed up with perfect comedic
timing. Bravo! Brava! Please come back to Cape Town. We need something fresh and new.”!

“The show was hilarious -- good fun!! Dragged a friend of mine with -- wasn't too keen at first but
left having enjoyed every minute of it. I particularly loved was homegrown material found from
beginning to end -- really refreshing always walking in a show and given local relatable subject
matter within a performance so well done to the team on a well rounded show!!!!”!

“Boylesque was everything good entertainment should be... Bravo!”!
We also create much needed employment for Cape Town based performers!







PRESS:







http://artscomments.wordpress.com/2013/05/01/it... 






    Other Ways You Can Help If you cannot help out financially, please share our campaign on social media!

story:
The My True Colors Festival Presents:

America, and the Adventures of Nat Turn-Up!


Short Summary

Nat Turn-Up, is an 18 year old rapper from Brooklyn, New York. After a taste of the ills of America's justice system, via the lens of a short stay in a juvenile detention center, he returns home to his community of family and friends on a mission. He is determined to become a revolutionary. To uplift and resurrect the minds of his people. Nat, along with his community are all fighting for their right to be heard, to be seen, to discover who they are and thrive in a world that both at times covertly and overtly oppresses them from being able to bask in the freedom which they all seek. As Gil Scott Heron once so poignantly said "Who Will Survive in America?" The characters in this play all ask this same question. What will it take to truly be free? Is it possible, and for who?


What We Need

  • "America, and The Adventures of Nat Turn-Up!" is in the early stages of it's development. In the past I've jumped right into production mode but this time I want to take the time to really flesh this piece out because I believe it to be both powerful and special. It's extremely personal to me. Therefore, my goal is to produce a week and a half long developmental workshop that will culminate in 2-3 performances of the play being presented as a staged reading at The Faison Firehouse Theatre in Harlem, N.Y. this summer.
  • Everything we raise will be going right into making this Staged Reading/Developmental workshop a success.
  • Your very generous donations will contribute to things such as allowing us to secure a rehearsal space, acquire rehearsal materials, provide transportation funds & compensation for an extremely gifted and dope creative team, among other costs that may arise in the process of putting this project on it's feet.

The Impact

  • I was born and raised in Brooklyn, N.Y. The same borough that this play takes place in. It is really important to me to see my community reflected not only in the media, but on stage. I've always been very inspired by what August Wilson did in depicting the lives and stories of African American people in Pittsburgh, PA in his ten play cycle which spanned over the course of the twentieth century. My goal is to do something similar for Brooklyn. This play is to be the first part of a much longer cycle, giving voice to people and a community that often goes misrepresented and unheard. I too want to leave a legacy that honors those from which I come from and also delves into the complexities of our existence. I want my people to feel seen. I think that it's important for art to speak. To bring about social and revolutionary change. I want this play to inspire people to mobilize. To awaken and unite. I want my community to rise above the system that attempts to silence them, heal and feel empowered to reclaim the glory and royalty that has always been running through our veins. For any of these things to happen, it is essential that this developmental process has all of the tools that it needs. This is where you come in. : ) I really hope that you will consider donating to this project today.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this page with your family, coworkers and friends! Help us get the word out! #blacklivesmatter

story:
ABOUT US

Proudly based in Seattle, WA, Jessica Jobaris & General Magic is a creative collective, directed by choreographer Jessica Jobaris, that nurtures risk, mystery, absurdity, sensation of the body, and emancipation through imagination. Her mission is to raise the importance of an experience of empathy for modern theater audiences, initiating communication with each other and with our ancestors, both of the natural world and in the ether. General Magic is the group of über talented collaborators that Jobaris works with on a project-to-project basis.

ABOUT THIS PROJECT / Why we need YOU!

- A Great Hunger -

Jessica Jobaris & General Magic will be co-presented for the third time by Seattle's On the Boards June 6-7, as part of their prestigious annual Northwest New Works Festival, as well as for the second time by Hand-to-Mouth-Theater's annual Festival Risk/Rewards, July 17-19 in Portland, Oregon. 

In these festivals, Jessica Jobaris & General Magic will premiere their latest dance-theater project A Great Hunger. It is incredibly exciting to be premiering this work... and touring it!  This is JJo&GM's 8th evening-length work, and A Great Hunger (almost a year in the making!) is the company’s largest project to date! 

We are a company of 13 collaborating artists, including 10 performers and 2 composers, and a film director. Additionally our performers operate as a collective company manager, and administrative work is shared among us by our vision of collaboration which in turn help move our new work forward behind the scenes.

We are asking for your support to help us cover the production costs of developing A Great Hunger!  These including rehearsal rentals, dancers' stipends, sound and film creation, costumes, set design and travel costs, all with a tax-deductible donation! (See bottom).

Did I already say your contribution helps to pay the performers as well as all creative collaborators?!?!  These performers are giving a LOT...

please read on.... 


A Great Hunger reflects on how we cope with loneliness, depression, anxiety and suicide. Also, it's about having our own unique experiences with grieving and healing. Having survived the loss of loved ones to suicide, along with our own intimate wranglings with depression, this performance piece has allowed JJo&GM, to explore these epidemics in America openly through the work; not just about the dark side, but also about the return home, and the renewal of hope. 

JJo&GM will be offering workshops and master classes using the process from the creation of A Great Hunger, as well as teaming up with American Foundation for Suicide Prevention by participating and giving proceeds to their annual Out of the Darkness Overnight Walk. http://www.afsp.org/

Your donation will help keep us moving not only through the premiere of A Great Hunger  but also through the remainder of the calendar year. We've set a goal to continue our company's impact in the community by completing this work for audiences by winter of 2016, self-producing a full evening performance at the newly constructed 12th Ave Arts Center in Capitol Hill neighborhood.

While our Indiegogo goal is $8,000, the goal for the entire campaign, to fully cover the costs of the premiere and further development of A Great Hunger is $11,000. We are hosting the remainder of this fundraising campaign through our May 16th Fundraiser, at The Moore Theater's speakeasy in Seattle, WA.

We hope you join us in supporting A Great Hunger, and help bring awareness around such intense and taboo subjects in our society. It is heavy; loneliness, depression, and suicide, heavy indeed, but we are also here to celebrate life, surviving, even thriving, and continue to do so through the work!  Therefore, our range of gratitude gifts are plentiful, and you'll even have a good time hand-picking your level of donation, as these reflect, with a sense of humor, certain sections of the choreography.

If you are feeling a pinch in your back pocket currently, other ways you can contribute are through donations to our Fundraiser! Do you have a product or skill you can offer for our May 16th fundraiser/auction?  Please contact jessicajobaris@gmail.com.

Thank you in advance for ANY (and we mean ANY, as it all adds up!) support you can offer, and know that your contribution is having a far reaching ripple effect through the arts and the AFSP, and therefore your community, and therefore the world!

Jessica Jobaris & General Magic is a sponsored performance project of Gamelan Pacifica a non-profit arts organization that supports Seattle choreographers thru their umbrella of 501(c)3 status. Contributions for the purposes of Jessica Jobaris & General Magic must be made payable to Gamelan Pacifica and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Dear Friends, 

The opening night of "Wooden Wars" will take place on May 22 at 5 pm. at the UM North Campus Duderstadt Center in Ann Arbor (2281 Bonisteel Blvd, Ann Arbor, MI 48109). We will also have an opendress rehearsal on May 21st at 6pm. The suggested donation is $15 and $10 (for students). 

Check out our poster and visit the play's Facebook page:

https://www.facebook.com/yiddishplay?ref=aymt_homepage_panel 

Come and show your support for Yiddish theater!

The author and director of Wooden Wars

Jana Mazurkiewicz is a PhD student at the Slavic Department at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. As a Yiddishist, she is devoted to rescuing the dying Yiddish language and culture. She would like to demonstrate that Yiddish can be revived not only in academia but also in the arts, and strives to encourage a discussion about a revival of Yiddish as a stage language and as a means of exploring the current state of Polish-Jewish relations.

The Story

“Wooden Wars” focuses on the lives of four young Catholics from modern Poland, each of whom changes forever when they discover that they might have Jewish roots. Sisters Zosia and Ania separate as one travels to America, converts to reform Judaism, and embraces her lesbian sexuality, while the other stays behind in Poland and marries a Chabadnik. Both come to speak Yiddish at home. Their stories are intertwined with those of their friends Jakub and Tadek, two young men whose own relationships with Jewish identity and Yiddish language are troubled. Neither as children nor as adults do the characters have control of their fates. Various paranormal forces are involved in the action, and Jesus appears to sing in Yiddish.

The Title

The title “Wooden Wars” refers to a cultural battle in contemporary Poland that’s highlighted in the play by two symbolic wooden artifacts: wooden crosses, and wooden figurines of Jews. These figurines, made of wood or clay, are a part of contemporary Polish culture. People buy them as amulets believing that they will bring happiness to their households. This article explains their meaning:

http://www.vice.com/en_ca/read/hey-poland-whats...

The Languages

“Wooden Wars” starts in English and Polish, but gradually includes more Yiddish so that by the second act almost all of the performance is in Yiddish. This structure asks us to reflect: Is Yiddish the key to understanding the Polish-Jewish past? For the audience’s ease, an English translation will also be projected as subtitles.

The Characters

Jamie Parsons as Zosia (later called Rus) - funny, brave, silly, talkative, homely. Zosia enjoys making fun of her sister Ania and challenging people. Zosia gets bored very easily. Zosia/Rus speaks YIVO Yiddish with a very strong American accent. She can be identified by her red harem pants, white and red shirt, and red hat in Act I, and all black outfit in Act II.

Sarah Garibova as Ania (later known as Frime) - very shy and serious, silent, pretty. Ania doesn't like interacting with the other kids and prays when no one is watching her. She constantly fiddles with her hands and is paranoid of being watched. Ania is intimidated by her sister, Zosia. Frime speaks the Polish dialect of Yiddish. She can be distinguished by her red skirt, white blouse, and rosary in Act I, and by a white blouse, grey skirt, and sheytl (head scarf) in Act II.

James Nadel as Tadek - energetic, self-confident, vulgar, stubborn, and a bully. He is arrogant and a “my way or the highway” kind of person; you’d better watch out for him. . He dons brown hat, brown pants, and a red, plaid sweatshirt, and often, a bottle of vodka.

Sara Feldman as Jakub – a nerdy, brainy, courageous outsider. He stares at maps all the time and travels in his dreams. Jakub is lumbered with a chronic cold. He speaks broken Yiddish and uses Hebrew words here and there. He wears a big black hat, white shirt, black vest, and red pants.

Sara Feldman as Jake – Rus’ partner. Jake is very kind, tries to be on good terms with everybody, and a tango expert. Jake is a weed smoker and speaks bine Yiddish (stage Yiddish) with a very strong American accent. Her Yiddish is brilliant. She wears a black dress and boots.

Alexandra Hoffman as Yitskhok – Frime’s husband, a Chabadnik. He is religious, smart and practical, not very devoted to his wife. Yitskhok has a very strong Hassidic American accent when he speaks Yiddish.Yitskhok fashions a black head covering, a black suit, and a prayer shawl.

Sanders as a Salesman who sells wooden Jews – He has a Santa Claus-like figure– energetic and a little pushy… He loves his job. The Salesman is the guy with the burlap sack marketing Wooden Jews.

Caren Feldman as a figurine of a Wooden Jew – The wooden Jew is enthusiastic and loves to dance. It does not want to be found and captured by the Salesman. The Wooden Jew’s appearance is companied by a Hassidic tune. The Wooden Jew can be recognized by its long beard, black hat, large coat, and ginormous boots.


Main goals of the project

• Initiating the collaboration between different communities at the University of Michigan

• Promoting creativity in Yiddish

• Encouraging people to involve in the arts

• Enhancing Polish–Jewish dialogue

The $2500 I raise is needed to stage the play (at least 4 performances) in a fully professional way and to record it on video.

Your contribution goes towards:

• Programs and Promotional Materials - $200

• Sets and Costumes - $200

• Lighting and Sound Design - $400

• Technical Staff - $700

• Video Editing and Reproduction - $1000

Thanks to the U-M Library and the Digital Media Commons for providing access to the Video Studio at no charge to help realize this production.

story:
Striplight Theatre is emerging in the Weirton area, and is dedicated to keeping the arts thriving in our community. We aim to provide education and team building skills through collaborative performance.


After completing our first season, Striplight has been given the opportunity to take our spring musical, "Flora the Red Menace,"  to competition.

We are asking our community for help with travel and competition fees.

We aim to provide education and team building skills through collaborative performance.After completing our first season, Striplight has been given the opportunity to take our spring musical, "Flora the Red Menace,"  to competition.We are asking our community for help with travel and competition fees.

story:
What is RIPPLED REFLECTIONS?

RIPPLED REFLECTIONS is a new, original musical with a book by Nicholas Ryan (19 years old), and music/lyrics by Julie Murtha (18 years old). The show was a recipient of a Scholastic Art & Writing award for Best Dramatic Script in 2014. It has been a 3-year journey to write this piece and it is still developing with workshops. (A clip from the first reading can be seen above.)The next staged workshop will occur in early June in Asbury Park, New Jersey. 

RIPPLED REFLECTIONS is about two people in love of the same sex, battling the forces that are driving them apart. 

Hal and Tom are in love, but a dark secret from the past, threatens to tear their relationship and lives apart. RIPPLED REFLECTIONS is a story of love, courage and finding that their love is a true test of survival in a brutal world of intolerance.

What We Need

We have found it to be nearly impossible to get large/professional theaters to produce the material because the score has not yet been transcribed/engraved (written out on sheet music). The composer has written a beautifully complex score that she played from memory. As young writers/composers, it is difficult to have the correct music theory knowledge to write out the music ourselves onto staff paper; therefore, we must hire a professional.
  • We need $1,500 to transcribe the score and get over this bump in the road so that the piece can flourish and grow!
  • All of the money will be going to the professional musicians to help TRANSCRIBE and ENGRAVE (write out the complex score onto sheet music). 
  • Having sheet music available with the show will make it possible to send the show out to be produced professionally or on a larger scale.
  • Special perks will be given for those whose donations match or are greater than the amounts shown to the right!

Every donation amount helps!

With every donation, you are supporting new artists, and an original idea/piece; and making our dream a little closer to coming true!

This piece is an important musical that touches on heavy subject matters. It is a story that needs to be told. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word to anyone you know who wants to support the arts. It is very difficult to get new work on its feet, especially from young writers. So please don't hesitate to blow up Facebook, Twitter and any other form of social media with your support of the show! Also, please use the Indiegogo share tools. Check out our website or social media pages for updates on the show! We hope to see you at our next workshop production! Thank you so much!

We have found it to be nearly impossible to get large/professional theaters to produce the material because the score has not yet been transcribed/engraved (written out on sheet music). The composer has written a beautifully complex score that she played from memory. As young writers/composers, it is difficult to have the correct music theory knowledge to write out the music ourselves onto staff paper; therefore, we must hire a professional.
  We need $1,500 to transcribe the score and get over this bump in the road so that the piece can flourish and grow! All of the money will be going to the professional musicians to help TRANSCRIBE and ENGRAVE (write out the complex score onto sheet music).  Having sheet music available with the show will make it possible to send the show out to be produced professionally or on a larger scale.
Special perks will be given for those whose donations match or are greater than the amounts shown to the right!    
Every donation amount helps!
With every donation, you are supporting new artists, and an original idea/piece; and making our dream a little closer to coming true!
This piece is an important musical that touches on heavy subject matters. It is a story that needs to be told. 

    Other Ways You Can Help Please spread the word to anyone you know who wants to support the arts. It is very difficult to get new work on its feet, especially from young writers. So please don't hesitate to blow up Facebook, Twitter and any other form of social media with your support of the show! Also, please use the Indiegogo share tools. Check out our website or social media pages for updates on the show! We hope to see you at our next workshop production! Thank you so much!

story:
video by Mister WA from Trillpeddlers 2009 production SF

To all glittery torchbearers of shameless fun, high ritual drag, sexual transgressive anarchy and wild queer theatre: PEARLS OVER SHANGHAI: The Cockettes Musical is coming home to Minneapolis!

With Theatre of the Ridiculous and Absuard, our newly-formed tribe of dedicated young stage professionals, we CALL FOR YOUR SUPPORT bringing this high-end low-brow gender-bending musical to the Twin Cities.

From the primordial Queer soup of 1970 San Francisco, PEARLS OVER SHANGHAI, the masterpiece strung together by our glittery-soaked elders & ancestors The Cockettes, is coming to the OPEN EYE FIGURE THEATRE this October 8th, 2015 with a 4 show run. This extravaganza includes a robust cast of 20, epic costumes and being directed by one of the most inventive directors Seth Gabriel-Mayotte.

Already your in-kind donations of head pieces, kimonos, body-suits, and Designer Originals have us well-positioned to summon this bejeweled beast. Our budget for this show is under $6,000, and with few other resources at present, we are REACHING OUT to YOU, our community here in the Twin Cities to help raise FUNDS, FUN and curtains as we cobble this together this LIVE NUDE tour-de-force, PEARLS OVER SHANGHAI; The Cockettes Musuical.

PEARLS, as we like to call it is, a mock comic opera that drags us into the underbelly of Shanghai circa 1937, is a mash up of Mikado, Looney Tunes, Ziggy Stardust, Busby Berkeley, The Rock Horror show & every bad Oriental exotica movie ever made. PEARLS OVER SHANGHAI, San Francisco's 1970's most unlikely hit musical features a score of 24 exquisite numbers by Original Cockette Richard "Scrumbly" Koldewyn and lyrics by Link Martin more exotic then a order of house chow fun. A show so hip that Rex Reed, Truman Capote, Angela Lansbury and Andy Warhol came to see it!

Q; WHO WERE THE COCKETTES? 

 A; At any given point in history, there is someone, somewhere who is having more FUN than anyone else; they are laughing singing dancing and often covered in glitter and rhinestones. This torch, passed across time and geography, was firmly in the hands of our tribal ancestors during their legendary years in San Francisco.

Sylvester, Divine, John Waters are just a few of the visionary figures that comprised The Cockettes, the loosely-knit clan of bearded hippie psychedelic drag queens founded in 1969 by reigning cosmic queen Hibiscus. Together, they created theatre performances that melded spiritual vision, 20s-30's music & film references, ritual drag, outrageous costume design and leftist socioplitical philosophies. Rather than traditional drag, the Cockettes members enveloped all peoples, genders, gay, straight or otherwise. Later on, The Cockettes quickly skyrocketed from a cult sensation to national stars, being covered by Life, Look, Esquire, Rolling Stones and now celebrated around the world.

"EVERY TIME YOU SEE TOO MUCH GLITTER OR A RHINESTONE OUT OF PLACE, YOU WILL KNOW IT'S BECAUSE OF THE COCKETTES" Lilla Roxon Mother of Rock

The Cockettes are coming to Minneapolis! Please Help us get our Rhinestone rolling as we raise curtains on PEARLS OVER SHANGHAI 2015.

Proceeds will be given to local HIV/AIDS and Homeless Youth programs in the Twin Cities.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP; We know that not all people have the ability to donate monetarily. However, that does not mean that you cant help Theatre of the Ridiculous and Absurd be successful in our campaign. Please post the link to this Indiegogo on your social media sites like Facebook and Twitter, or send this to your entire email list. Help us get the word out to as many people as possible.

story:
MultiStages, a multicultural and multidisciplinary theatre company in NYC, has dedicated its season to Latina playwrights. This April, we present ... 

"Comida de Puta (F%&king Lousy Food)" by Bronx native Desi Moreno-Penson, winner of MultiStages 2013 New Works Contest. Congratulations, Desi!

This year's production season is dedicated to supporting Latina women of Puerto Rican heritage. BRAVA!  Last Fall we produced the award-winning new musical Temple of the Souls set in Puerto Rico's El Yunque rain forest, and now we're moving Uptown to the Bronx.

Supporting new works by women of color is critically needed. The statistics of Latina playwrights getting their work produced in the United States is extremely low, and a great shame for all of us. We are missing these voices, perspectives, stories ... And it's time to LISTEN.

Please join us in our mission to support, encourage, and bring this amazing world premiere to the stage. We need you to make it happen!


COMIDA DE PUTA (F%&king Lousy Food)
by Desi Moreno-Penson
directed by Lorca Peress
April 8-26, 2015

West End Theatre
at The Church of St. Paul & St. Andrew
263 West 86th St.
New York, NY

AEA Showcase

Sex, magic, and spoken-word poetry illuminate this dark erotic tale of Phaedra on the gritty streets of the Bronx. A bodega owner’s new wife becomes strangely obsessed with her husband’s son, the lunch counter boy. Driven by lust, she invokes the vengeful power of the Santeria Gods who set off a vicious chain of events that no one can stop.

This multidisciplinary piece features a Cast of 6 onstage and 6 onscreen, an onstage musician, and 4 Videos shot on location. Your donation will help us reach both our artistic and financial goals. This multimedia piece requires a large technical staff and sophisticated technical equipment.


WHO'S WHO - THE CAST

APPEARING ONSTAGE

Roseanne Almanzar* (“Rosalia”), Darlenis Duran (“Alcidia”), Alex Hernandez (“Sotero”), Gustavo Heredia (“Viejo”), Mariana Parma* (“Laluz”), Marcos Sotomayor (“Manny and the “Chorus”)

APPEARING ON VIDEO

Venuz Delmar, Dennis Gagomiros, Mykal Monroe, Suni Reyes, Anita Velez, and featuring Emmy-winning journalist and NY Times best selling author, Jane Velez-Mitchell as news reporter Laura Santiago.

WHO'S WHO - THE ARTISTIC COMPANY

Desi Moreno-Penson, Playwright;  Jan Hartley, Projection Design; Christopher Marston, Filmmaker, Editor, Video Design; Alex Moore, Lighting Design; Lisa Renee Jordan, Masks & Costume Design; David Margolin Lawson, Sound Design; Justin and Christopher Swader, Scenic Design; A.J. Muhammad, Dramaturgy; Kimille Howard, Assistant Director; Lorca Peress**, Director
Andrea Wales*, Production Stage Manager
* members of AEA
**member of SDC

Set designed by Christopher and Justin Swader

Costume and Mask design by Lisa Renee Jordan

WHO'S WHO - THE PLAYWRIGHT
Desi Moreno-Penson

“As a writer, my literary objectives have been to present a revisionist, expressionistic view of contemporary U.S. Latino consciousness, devoid of the need for abject sentiment or apology. Comida de Puta (F%&king Lousy Food) is the second play in a cycle of plays I am currently writing and developing called Nuyorican Gothic… highly stylized, darkly surreal, and gothic. These plays all take place in the Bronx and feature heightened, poetic language and Nuyorican characters (Puerto Ricans born and raised in New York). The first play was Devil Land, and now with Comida de Puta, I’ve chosen to look towards Greek Theatre (Hypolotus), in order to tell this tale of unrequited lust and mysticism. At the same time, I see Comida de Puta as a strong piece for women, specifically Latinas. These kinds of roles continue to be very hard to come by in the American Theater. The play’s roots in Greek tragedy are a ‘remix’ of sorts for a new myth within a culture that continues to be in great need of exploring its own narratives as Americans.”

Comida de Puta (F%&king Lousy Food) began as a ten-minute play in the 2011 Going To The River Festival (plays by women of color) at NYC’s Ensemble Studio Theatre. Comida de Puta (F%&king Lousy Food) was selected as a finalist for the 2014 O’Neill National Playwrights Conference, and is the winner of MultiStages 2013 New Works Contest. 

To read more about Desi, please visit: www.multistages.org/upcoming

WHO'S WHO - MultiStages

Founding Artistic Director Lorca Peress: “As an artist of Puerto Rican heritage born in NYC, this project and its artistic challenges are of vital importance to me. I have dedicated my career to creating and developing new works that I believe advance the world's perception and exploration of culture, race, and identity. COMIDA DE PUTA is a daring new work by a brave and brilliant playwright whose voice and visions were formed on the streets of the Nuyorican Bronx. Come join the discussion."

MultiStages Mission & History: 

Founded in 1997, MultiStages' mission is to encourage collaborations between playwrights and artists to develop multicultural and multidisciplinary new works that celebrate a fusion of art forms that enrich, explore, and reinvent today's theatre. MultiStages has developed over 40 new works through its New Works Contests and Script Development Series, in collaboration with poets, filmmakers, composers, choreographers, musicians, visual and theatre artists who each represent an imaginative perspective. Awards: 2011 and 2013 Women in Arts and Media Collaboration Honorable Mention Awards, 4 HOLA Awards (including 2012 Gilberto Zaldivar Award for Outstanding production), Taino Award, FLAG Award, 3 Manhattan Community Arts Fund Awards (LMCC and the DOCA), Dramatists Guild Fund, N.W. Dible Foundation, Jewish Communal Fund, Materials for the Arts support from the DOCA. MultiStages is a member of Materials for the Arts through the Department of Culture Affairs, and a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization that receives grants in behalf of MultiStages, provides oversight to ensure grant funds are used in accordance with grant agreements, and provides reports as required by grantor.


WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET

    DID YOU KNOW that government and private foundations only fund about 12% of a project? That’s why we need friends like you to reach our goal.
  • We have an expansive program with two productions this season, and we hope to continue expanding our seasons in the future
  • We are holding our next new works contest soon, and expanding our script development series
  • We have new voices to discover and develop, and need your support.

FREE Talk Back:  

  • Sunday, April 12: “Classical Adaptations by Artists of Color,” with Playwrights Desi Moreno-Penson, Patricia Ione Lloyd, Carlos J. Serrano and Dramaturg A.J. Muhammad, Moderated by Lorca Peress, MultiStages Artistic Director

We will offer tax-deductions and Perks and thank yous in our program!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Support Women's Work. This production boasts many women on the team: writer, director/producer, designers, and more. Did you know that women make up the majority of theatre audiences and yet women are under-represented on stage and behind the scenes? Despite countless significant inroads, women still need recognition and support. And specifically Latina women -- there was only one Latina nominated at the Golden Globes, and she won!

  • Help us get the word out - send this campaign to your friends and colleagues, Friend us on Facebook, tweet and blog about the show, spread the word.
  • Buy a Program Ad to promote your project, business, or create a Congratulations page!
  • Come see the show and bring your friends!
  • Come to the Talk-Back and learn more about multidisciplinary theatre.
  • Volunteer as a production assistant or usher, and see the show for free!
  • Support advocacy and become a Friend of the League of Professional Theatre Women at www.theatrewomen.org
  • Email Contact@multistages.org to get involved.

story:
Save the PostHouse for Los Angeles Dance!

Designed by Newell Taylor Reynolds for himself and his wife and partner, Bella Lewitzky, the PostHouse is a one-of-a-kind place for dance in Los Angeles. Formerly home to the Lewitzky Dance Company for twenty years, the PostHouse now is at a critical crossroads. In order to preserve this space as a resource for the Los Angeles dance community, we need to raise some funds to acquire majority equity in the property and keep it going.

Since 1997, we have offered rehearsal space, classes and workshops, with a diverse range of companies and individuals actively working in the dance field. During that time, more than thirty companies and many more individual choreographers have created dances and art here in the beautiful environment that Newell built, and that he and Bella maintained. 

The PostHouse today is a continuation of this commitment to dance as a living, relevant art form that speaks to and from the heart and spirit.

If we are forced to sell the result would most likely be a "tear-down" and the loss forever of this historic home and studio.

Those of us who want to lift up the talented dancers and dance-makers here in Los Angeles can come together and keep this resource alive.

                                                              

We have maintained this iconic building for 18 years without asking for any outside help and want to continue the work here without interruption and without dependence on outside influences. It is unfortunate that circumstances now compel us to seek your help. Please be assured that this is a one-time, not an ongoing, appeal.

How can you help?

The target amount is $160,000; of that we already have raised one quarter, leaving an approximate need of $120,000, which includes costs to run the campaign. You can donate through Indiegogo. Any amount is needed and welcome.

Please tell your friends and colleagues about the campaign!!

This campaign opens a broad public appeal - both to dancers and artists who have created here as well as to all people who are interested in preserving this unique and historic place for dance in Los Angeles. The studio has fed many artists and birthed many works of art - it has the capacity to do so for many years into the future. 

Thank you for your time reading this and please help if you can- the life dreams of many people are in your hands - and their feet! You can be a part of fulfilling those dreams with your generous contribution. Any donation will help us to meet the goal! With much appreciation and gratitude, we thank you!

Please send this message to your friends and colleagues - the more who see the need for support the more we can continue to DANCE ON!

Some companies and dancers here at The PostHouse:                                                *See their photos in the Gallery which you can access from the top of the page

American Contemporary Ballet,  Arrogant Elbow: Sarah Elgart,  Benita Bike's Dance Art,  Body Traffic, Bubba Carr, Clairobscur Dance Company: Laurie Sefton,  Dances Made to Order: Kingsley Irons,  Donna Sternberg & Dancers,  Francisco Martinez Dancetheatre,  Hysterica Dance Co. : Kitty McNamee,  Latina Dance Project: Licia Perea,  Liz Hoefner,  Loretta Livingston and Dancers,  Louise Reichlin and Dancers,  M-Theory Dance Company: Taryn Wayne,  Mary Ann Kellogg,  Pennington Dance Group: John Pennington,  PTERO Dance Theatre: Paula Present,  Robyn O'Dell,  Ryan Heffington,  Storytime with Uncle Sean: Sean Greene,  String Theory Productions,  The Black Dahlia Project: Steven Espinosa, The PostHouse Dance Group,  Trip Dance Theatre: Monica Favand,  Viver Brasil: Linda Yudin,  Vox Dance Theater: Sarah Swenson,  Winnifred Harris Between Lines,  Yorke Dance Project: Yolande Yorke-Edgell
and many more...

                                     

A little about the history of the space:

Bella Lewitzky was a protege and then a colleague of Lester Horton, forming the Horton Dance Group in the 1930s, a company which continued until the early 1950s. Horton was a multi-talented artist who realized his vision through the purity of expression in dance and developed, with Bella, the Horton technique, still taught widely around the world. Bella’s company, The Lewitzky Dance Company under Bella's artistic direction, along with executive directors Darlene Neel and Ruth Eliel, performed and taught nationally and internationally. Her work in the Artists in the Schools program and on many panels and committees to promote the teaching of art in the United States was highly influential and formed a generation of dance educators throughout the States.

Of the Horton Dance Group notable artists include Alvin Ailey, Carmen DeLavallade, James Truitt and fashion designer Rudi Guernrich. Newell was briefly associated with the HDG as a dancer and went on to design sets for dance as an adjunct to his career as an architect. The next generation of dancemakers who Bella trained have influenced dance students by their work in performance and education - June Morris, Fred Strickler, Gary Bates, Jan Day, Linda Davis, Kurt Weinheimer,  MaryAnn Kellogg, Iris Pell, Sean Greene, Loretta Livingston, Susan Rose, Amy Ernst, Walter Kennedy, Laura McKirihan Poole, John Pennington, Christopher Burnside, Nora Reynolds Daniel, Don Bondi and Charles Edmondson, among others

Comments from artists who have worked here:

I had the singular privilege of working as a musician and musical collaborator with Bella Lewitzky and her company for many years - and the PostHouse was a second home to me at times. I went on to compose scores for many of Bella's alumni and much of it was created at the space. The space was built by Bella and her architect husband to be exactly what it is - a shrine for dancers and choreographers in Los Angeles.

The history of dance in Los Angeles has in many ways centered around activities at PostHouse - classes, master classes, workshops, choreography space, rehearsals, video and photo shoots and numerous receptions for visiting luminaries.

Dancer/choreographer/educator Diana MacNeil has carried on the tradition of the PostHouse as a creative place for the LA dance community - charging insanely low fees for the use of the space for classes and rehearsals. 

The PostHouse needs our help to keep it alive. I will be making a donation and I hope everyone with a love of dance will do so. We can't let this one-of-a-kind legacy disappear - there is nothing else like it here for the current generation of dancers and the next to come.
Jeff Rona

Viver Brasil had a few very incredible experiences at the Post House in our early years working with world renowned Brazilian teacher, dancer, choreographer Rosangela Silvestre.  The space was inspiring and the rent completely affordable. We had to move on as the neighbors did not love our drums as much as we need. Nevertheless, Diana has fervently maintained the space for all to use. This beautiful studio must survive! Give! 

Linda Yudin/Artistic Director Viver Brasil

I have so many fond memories of creating works in this enchanted ground so conducive to the process. "Cornfield," "The Colorado," "Dark Corner," "Miniatures," "Sing to Me of Love," "Primal Ground," "Ave Verum Corpus," and a host of others made their entrance in this special space. May it continue to host many, many creators of dance in days to come. 

Francisco Martinez and Francisco Martinez Dancetheatre.

For years The PostHouse was a second home for me. It was in that space that I grew into an adult dancer and became initiated in Lewitzky technique, thanks to Diana. I found a wonderful dance community coming to class and rehearsals at The PostHouse and will always treasure my time there

Francie Ridenhour

Dance Instructor Immaculate Heart High School

Thank you for having this wonderful space available for the Dance Community of Los Angeles. I for one have spent many years dancing in this space and learning how to dance in the style of Bella. This has been an indescribable gift for me, and it has made my life in Los Angeles so much richer. Performing modern dance whether in a class or as part of a performance has allowed me to feel even in a small way, a part of the Dance Community and I am so grateful that you have made this possible.

Jill Adler-Moore

"We created most of our first season's ballets at the PostHouse. Not many studios have a view like that."

Lincoln Jones, Artistic Director, American Contemporary Ballet

Jam Today loves rehearsing at Post House!

Robyn O'Dell

I was very inspired and felt so supported to create by you and the space, it is really something I had not expected or felt previously in LA. 

Corina Kinnear

We worked on a number of projects at Post House, and the two that come to mind as the biggest were "The Patchwork Girl of Oz" developed 2000-2002. One of the more recent links is from a performance at Jazz At Lincoln Center in 2013: http://youtu.be/dCaiCW4WMn4. We have taken this piece to six states, and after putting the evening long performance aside for a while performed it here in LA and it was also presented at the Long Island Children's Museum is 2011-12.

The second work was "Dream Scapes", actually a whole show of dances I created for a project imagined and produced by Steve Reid (Bamboo Forest). 

One of the things I really love about the studio is the setting - out the glass wall/window, we would sometimes see a deer. Right there in the Hollywood Hills.

Louise Reichlin

Louise Reichlin and Dancers

The Posthouse has been such a CRUCIAL SPACE in my dancing life since I have moved to LA! I have danced in this beautiful setting with Monica Favand Campagna and TRIP Dance Theatre, Paula Present and Ptero Dance Theatre, and most recently my new adventure: M-Theory Dance Company. I have had such an amazing time rehearsing and creating in this special place! Thank you, Diana MacNeil for providing this incredible resource for the LA dance community. We will do all we can to keep it alive and well for the future!

Taryn Wayne

M-Theory Dance Company

My company has been rehearsing at the PostHouse for a number of years now, and we love working there! The spirits of many dancers and dance makers are there!
Benita Bike

Benita Bike's DanceArt

Thank you for reading all the way through! Please donate today and let your people know about the campaign. Your donation is needed and appreciated. Together we can make The PostHouse go forward to generate the new in dance in Los Angeles!
Thank you,
Diana MacNeil

                                      

                                       THANK YOU for your SUPPORT!!
story_txt:
Save the PostHouse for Los Angeles Dance!


Designed by Newell Taylor Reynolds for himself and his wife and partner, Bella Lewitzky, the PostHouse is a one-of-a-kind place for dance in Los Angeles. Formerly home to the Lewitzky Dance Company for twenty years, the PostHouse now is at a critical crossroads. In order to preserve this space as a resource for the Los Angeles dance community, we need to raise some funds to acquire majority equity in the property and keep it going.
Since 1997, we have offered rehearsal space, classes and workshops, with a diverse range of companies and individuals actively working in the dance field. During that time, more than thirty companies and many more individual choreographers have created dances and art here in the beautiful environment that Newell built, and that he and Bella maintained. 
The PostHouse today is a continuation of this commitment to dance as a living, relevant art form that speaks to and from the heart and spirit.

If we are forced to sell the result would most likely be a "tear-down" and the loss forever of this historic home and studio.




Those of us who want to lift up the talented dancers and dance-makers here in Los Angeles can come together and keep this resource alive.


                                                              


We have maintained this iconic building for 18 years without asking for any outside help and want to continue the work here without interruption and without dependence on outside influences. It is unfortunate that circumstances now compel us to seek your help. Please be assured that this is a one-time, not an ongoing, appeal.
How can you help?
The target amount is $160,000; of that we already have raised one quarter, leaving an approximate need of $120,000, which includes costs to run the campaign. You can donate through Indiegogo. Any amount is needed and welcome.
Please tell your friends and colleagues about the campaign!!
This campaign opens a broad public appeal - both to dancers and artists who have created here as well as to all people who are interested in preserving this unique and historic place for dance in Los Angeles. The studio has fed many artists and birthed many works of art - it has the capacity to do so for many years into the future. 

Thank you for your time reading this and please help if you can- the life dreams of many people are in your hands - and their feet! You can be a part of fulfilling those dreams with your generous contribution. Any donation will help us to meet the goal! With much appreciation and gratitude, we thank you!
Please send this message to your friends and colleagues - the more who see the need for support the more we can continue to DANCE ON!
Some companies and dancers here at The PostHouse:                                                *See their photos in the Gallery which you can access from the top of the page

Contemporary Ballet,

Project: Yolande Yorke-Edgelland many more...
                                     
A little about the history of the space:

Bella Lewitzky was a protege and then a colleague of Lester Horton, forming the Horton Dance Group in the 1930s, a company which continued until the early 1950s. Horton was a multi-talented artist who realized his vision through the purity of expression in dance and developed, with Bella, the Horton technique, still taught widely around the world. Bella’s company, The Lewitzky Dance Company under Bella's artistic direction, along with executive directors Darlene Neel and Ruth Eliel, performed and taught nationally and internationally. Her work in the Artists in the Schools program and on many panels and committees to promote the teaching of art in the United States was highly influential and formed a generation of dance educators throughout the States.
Of the Horton Dance Group notable artists include Alvin Ailey, Carmen DeLavallade, James Truitt and fashion designer Rudi Guernrich. Newell was briefly associated with the HDG as a dancer and went on to design sets for dance as an adjunct to his career as an architect. The next generation of dancemakers who Bella trained have influenced dance students by their work in performance and education - June Morris, Fred Strickler, Gary Bates, Jan Day, Linda Davis, Kurt Weinheimer,  MaryAnn Kellogg, Iris Pell, Sean Greene, Loretta Livingston, Susan Rose, Amy Ernst, Walter Kennedy, Laura McKirihan Poole, John Pennington, Christopher Burnside, Nora Reynolds Daniel, Don Bondi and Charles Edmondson, among others
Comments from artists who have worked here:

I had the singular privilege of working as
a musician and musical collaborator with Bella Lewitzky and her company for
many years - and the PostHouse was a second home to me at times. I went on to
compose scores for many of Bella's alumni and much of it was created at the
space. The space was built by Bella and her architect husband to be exactly
what it is - a shrine for dancers and choreographers in Los Angeles.

The history of dance in Los Angeles has in many ways centered around activities
at PostHouse - classes, master classes, workshops, choreography space,
rehearsals, video and photo shoots and numerous receptions for visiting
luminaries.

Dancer/choreographer/educator Diana MacNeil has carried on the tradition of the
PostHouse as a creative place for the LA dance community - charging insanely
low fees for the use of the space for classes and rehearsals. 

The PostHouse needs our help to keep it alive. I will be making a donation and
I hope everyone with a love of dance will do so. We can't let this
one-of-a-kind legacy disappear - there is nothing else like it here for the
current generation of dancers and the next to come.
Jeff Rona
Viver Brasil had a few very incredible experiences at the
Post House in our early years working with world renowned Brazilian teacher,
dancer, choreographer Rosangela Silvestre.  The space was inspiring and
the rent completely affordable. We had to move on as the neighbors did not love
our drums as much as we need. Nevertheless, Diana has fervently maintained the
space for all to use. This beautiful studio must survive! Give! 
Linda

story:
Beginning on October 1st Eleusyve Productions will begin our funding drive to cover the cost of the presentation of Aleister Crowley’s The Rite of Jupiter, a rock opera in 2016.

This will be our sixth presentation of the series of seven, and we’re planning to raise the bar and set a new benchmark for excellence and spectacle, as is only fitting for Jupiter!

Great visions have price-tags, and we’ve got enough experience to know what we will require to make these visions a reality.

One of the great advantages to our crowd funded model of fringe theater is scalability. We’re fully committed to presenting the material, and it is entirely in the hands of our fans and patrons (that is you!) on how simple or elaborate our presentation will be. Reviewing our funding goals below will give you a clear indication of how simple and elegant, or how bombastic and elaborate our productions can be.

The second great advantage to crowd funded fringe theater is an almost complete absence of accountability to any corporate sponsor or umbrella organization. While we are grateful to companies like Microsoft and Starbucks that have afforded us matching funds in the past, thanks to the generous donations of employees of those organizations, these companies have no interest in what we’re presenting on stage. Our first goal is to create the most amazing experience for the fans, and if that means that we need to arrange for a blood splatter zone in light of the Maenad frenzy, we’re free to do that. Plastic suits may be available from vending, if we reach the proper stretch goal.

But now we’re just hinting at things best said plainly. Here is a breakdown of what we’ll need to achieve each of our goals in this project. 

$500 - Complete the sound track to The Rite of Jupiter.

$1500 - Present The Rite of Jupiter as a concert, no costumes/props/blocking, in a small theater.

$3500 - Present The Rite of Jupiter as a concert, with costumes, in a small theater - minimalist blocking/props/projections 

$10,000 - Present The Rite of Jupiter as a small theater rock opera, only a one weekend run, with costumes/blocking/props.

$16,000 - Present The Rite of Jupiter as a small theater rock opera, with costumes/blocking/props - two weekend run - one night with guest speaker.

$22,000 - Present The Rite of Jupiter as a full scale, grandiose theatrical production including a custom carousel, blood splatter zone, and specialist performers - two weekend run - one or two nights with guest speakers. Eyes on the prize! This is what you want!


Eleusyve Productions is fiscally sponsored by Shunpike.

story:
Meet Hughie: an incurable dreamer with a bad job, a worse cough, and a possible third date.  She'll call, right?  She'll totally call.

               Natalie follows poor Hughie around New York as he seeks to answer life's most pressing questions.  Like should he quit his miserable barista job?  Does he have black lung?  And how long until the next L train to Brooklyn?  All these questions and more will be answered in a fast-paced 45 minute musical going up at the end of March.

              The creative team is excited to bring this Natalie to the Midtown International Theatre Festival this March under the direction of Emily Feinstein.  

              Please consider making a donation to support this fun and flirty piece of theatre.  Contributions of all sizes are welcome and vital to ensure our upcoming production of Natalie can be the best it can be.

             Thank you so much for your support!

Our Team

Producer: Alex Donnelly
Composer: JJ Warshaw
Book and Lyrics: Nick Parker
Director: Emily Feinstein
Lighting Designer: Ruth Hollander
Sound Designer: Mark King
Advertising Director: Cindy Lozito

Cast

Hughie: Sam Mickel
Natalie: Mariana Quinn-Makwaia
Jill: Laura Winters
Charlie: Tadesh Ingaki
Vaughn: Chris Silverberg
Erin: Jo Chiang
Doctor's Office: Max Ash
