story:
"We have chosen to live lives less ordinary"

Crossing the state border in a stolen Ford V-8 with a trunk full of sawn-off shotguns and bootleg whiskey, Bonnie and Clyde have found one last place to hide. Time is ticking - they're on the run from the law and from reality, but which one will catch them first?

Based on the true story, and set in 1934 in an unnamed southern state of America, Bonnie and Clyde is an intimate re-telling of the final hours of one of the world's most infamous criminal couples.

Bonnie and Clyde was written by Adam Peck (Bristol Old Vic Associate Artist) and first produced in 2010 at Theatre 503. The entire play is a two-hander featuring only Bonnie and Clyde whilst they're hiding out in an abandoned barn trying to escape the law, reflecting on their turbulent past and struggling to predict what their future holds. Adam has created such vivid characters that aren't the stereotypical 'Bonnie and Clyde' most people automatically think of, and as actors this really excites us. We also understand that there's a great deal of responsibility when it comes to playing real people, so we've already begun the process of thoroughly researching the two of them. In addition to this we both have to organise the details of the set, costumes, props, budget and marketing - so there's lots of work to be done. It's a huge logistical and financial challenge to produce any form of theatre, especially at this point in time when arts funding has been cut so drastically. By contributing you will literally be the backbone of this production, and will be giving an exceptionally dedicated team of people the opportunity to create challenging theatre that brings an iconic piece of American history to London.


Our Company

Libitum Theatre is a new theatre company founded by Tom Nunez (Clyde) in late 2015. Our aim is really simple - when we find a play/project that excites us and we think we can work with, we'll do everything possible to turn it into a full production. Bonnie and Clyde will be a co-production with the award - winning theatre company Action To The Word, and we're lucky to have its founder and artistic director Alexandra Spencer-Jones on board as the director of our production. (Read below for more information)


Tom graduated from the Birmingham School of Acting in 2014, where he played the roles of Stucley in The Castle, Harry Bagley in Cloud 9, and Stone in City Of Angels. He has also played Hamlet for the award- winning theatre company Action To The Word. Other credits include BBC, ITV, and SKY television/commercial productions, as well as featuring as a Slytherin Student in multiple Harry Potter films.



Angel Parker (Bonnie) is our Associate Artist and has recently finished a foundation degree at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art (LAMDA). Whilst training she played the role of Miranda in William Shakespeare's The Tempest, as well as playing Irina Arkadina in Chekov's classic The Seagull. Other stage roles include Jane in The Wonderful World of Dissocia, and Victora in Cloud 9. Angel has been working in the acting industry from a young age, including featuring in both St Trinian's films and also gaining a place with The National Youth Theatre.




Alexandra Spencer - Jones (Director) is the founder and Artistic Director of the award-winning theatre company Action To The Word. She has produced and directed A Clockwork Orange which was met with critical acclaim. It was then taken up by West End producers Glynis Henderson Produtions, and subsequently has toured worldwide. She has also adapted and directed Bram Stoker's classic novel Dracula, which continues into development after playing to a highly successful first outing at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. At present Alexandra is directing A Midsummer Night's Dream which will be playing at this years Latitude Festival,before going to the National Theatre's River Stage in August. She has also recently directed Gobsmacked!, currently playing at Underbelly Southbank, and then touring Sydney later this year.

In addition to her work with Action To The Word, Alexandra has acted as Associate Director on Bend It Like Beckham at the Phoenix Theatre, to Jeremy Sans on La Perichole for Garsington Opera, and also to Peter Grimes for Grange Opera having assistant directed his Wizard Of Oz at the London Palladium.

www.actiontotheword.com


What We Need & What You Get

We're aiming to raise £6500, which we know is a lot of money but this will give us the funding to take the show to The Etcetera Theatre in October, as well as festivals in 2017 that we're currently negotiating. We're particularly interested in taking it to international audiences in Canada and the U.S. This is ultimate direction we'd like the show to go in, however we're focusing on making the production at The Etcetera Theatre the best that it can be in order to start 2017 in a strong position.

Below is a list of things that your contributions will be funding:

  1. Theatre Hire - Including technician, use of music, projector etc
  2. Set, Costume and Props - The play is set in 1934 in an unnamed Southern American state, and so we have to create an authentic environment that reflects this. This includes a wooden barn, glass bottles, temporary tattoos, food, and more. We also have to hire prop guns, which are costly.
  3. Director Fees and Rehearsal Space 
  4. Transport - This includes transport around London during the rehearsal period/production period. It also includes transportation of the set which will require van hire.
  5. Public Liability Insurance
  6. Marketing - This includes photography, printing costs, leaflets etc.
  7. Entrance into festivals in 2017


What do you get? Let's talk perks!

We know that we're asking you to be extremely generous, so first and foremost we want to thank you even for visiting this page and showing an interest in us. By contributing you can choose from a range of exciting perks that we've created, including the opportunity to have a drink with Bonnie and Clyde in a speakeasy. (They'll be paying, don't worry...) We've created perks to suit a range of budgets, so you can choose anything from extremely grateful social media shout-outs, to getting exclusive post-show party invitations, or even the chance to become a full executive producer of the show. Check out the full range of perks on the right >>>

Hang on, what happens if we don't reach our target?
If we don't reach 100% of our target (fingers crossed this won't happen), then we'll have to forget any aspirations of taking the show to different festivals and audiences in 2017, as this requires a fair amount of funding. If we only reach 50% of our target we'll still be able to take the show to The Etcetera Theatre, but we won't be able to make the show that we've dreamed of and will have to put everything on an even more extreme budget which will negatively affect the show. We think this would be really unfortunate because the play is set in a wonderfully detailed world, and having the freedom to create that world with the set, props and costumes is something we're committed to providing we have the correct budget.

The Impact

Your contributions will not only help this production, they are this production. The money we aim to raise is to cover every aspect of the plays production, from its very beginning to development in 2017 and beyond. We've chosen to embark on this journey because we feel we can do the play justice and create something truly special.

Even though the play is set in 1934 in America, we've already noticed many similarities between the social climate back then compared to the world we live in now. Bonnie and Clyde were young people that had struggled through the Great Depression, and even though the path they chose in life caused complete devastation to many families, it's important to understand what led them down this route. Since the economic crash in 2008 people all over the world have faced their own hardships, including huge amounts of unemployment and rising costs of living compared to the increase in wages. A study from the American Psychological Association has shown that young people aged between 18 - 33 are more stressed than the rest of the population, by quite a margin. Factors such as paying back student loans and the pressure of buying a house and starting a family contribute towards this stress, for instance in the UK it's now common knowledge that tuition fees have trebled to £9000, creating huge amounts of debt for young people and deterring many from higher education altogether. These themes of isolation and despair are beautifully brought to life in the text, and manage to make a play set 82 years ago resonate with modern audiences.

We feel extremely privaledged  to have Alexandra Spencer - Jones on board as she's well established within the arts industry and has had a wealth of experience in producing and directing theatre. Her theatre company Action To The Word currently has taken up residence at the Broadway Theatre in Catford, which will really help as this gives us flexible rehearsal space. Alexandra has worked with Tom in the past by casting him as Hamlet, and also as Harry Bagley in Cloud 9 by Caryl Churchill. By working with her again we know that the show is in safe hands.


Risks & Challenges

Our main obstacle will be making sure we market the show properly so that we hopefully sell out every night. Seeing as its only playing for one week we want to make sure that we're playing to full houses as often as possible, as this will also generate buzz for any future performances we do in 2017 etc. Another challenge is simply the logistics of moving the set, costumes, props across London and then storing them when they're not in use. Raising enough funds would eliminate this problem as we could afford to hire the required vehicles and storage facilities with little difficulty. In terms of taking the show to different venues in 2017, this would require a well planned strategy of applications as well as funding, as some international festivals charge fees to apply.

Alexandra has a history of creating productions and then taking them to multiple venues, from fringe settings to West End theatres, and so we would draw from her experience in guiding us through these challenges to ensure the show becomes a success.

Can't Contribute? Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand that not everybody has the means to donate. If you're reading this it means you've had a look through our campaign and for that alone we're grateful!

You may not be able to give us financial assistance, however you can still help us in other ways:

  • By directing other people to this page to create a buzz about our production, this could lead to further donations and would really help!
  • If you own a business, local or not, you may be able to help us by getting in touch and letting us advertise at your location. Also, you could help us by providing your services (e.g. poster/leaflet/programme printing) in return for an advertisement in our programme that will be seen by hundreds of audience members.
  • If you're London based and want to get involved/lend a hand... get in touch! We'd love to hear from you.

Thank you for visiting our campaign! We look forward to working on the production as soon a possible, and be sure to keep checking back for regular updates/information.

Tom & Angel

Main image credited to Charles Flint Photography
story_txt:
"We have chosen to live lives less ordinary"Crossing the state border in a stolen Ford V-8 with a trunk full of sawn-off shotguns and bootleg whiskey, Bonnie and Clyde have found one last place to hide. Time is ticking - they're on the run from the law and from reality, but which one will catch them first?Based on the true story, and set in 1934 in an unnamed southern state of America, Bonnie and Clyde is an intimate re-telling of the final hours of one of the world's most infamous criminal couples.Bonnie and Clyde was written by Adam Peck (Bristol Old Vic Associate Artist) and first produced in 2010 at Theatre 503. The entire play is a two-hander featuring only Bonnie and Clyde whilst they're hiding out in an abandoned barn trying to escape the law, reflecting on their turbulent past and struggling to predict what their future holds. Adam has created such vivid characters that aren't the stereotypical 'Bonnie and Clyde' most people automatically think of, and as actors this really excites us. We also understand that there's a great deal of responsibility when it comes to playing real people, so we've already begun the process of thoroughly researching the two of them. In addition to this we both have to organise the details of the set, costumes, props, budget and marketing - so there's lots of work to be done. It's a huge logistical and financial challenge to produce any form of theatre, especially at this point in time when arts funding has been cut so drastically. By contributing you will literally be the backbone of this production, and will be giving an exceptionally dedicated team of people the opportunity to create challenging theatre that brings an iconic piece of American history to London.Our Company
Libitum Theatre is a new theatre company founded by Tom Nunez (Clyde) in late 2015. Our aim is really simple - when we find a play/project that excites us and we think we can work with, we'll do everything possible to turn it into a full production. Bonnie and Clyde will be a co-production with the award - winning theatre company Action To The Word, and we're lucky to have its founder and artistic director Alexandra Spencer-Jones on board as the director of our production. (Read below for more information)

Tom graduated from the Birmingham School of Acting in 2014, where he played the roles of Stucley in The Castle, Harry Bagley in Cloud 9, and Stone in City Of Angels. He has also played Hamlet for the award- winning theatre company Action To The Word. Other credits include BBC, ITV, and SKY television/commercial productions, as well as featuring as a Slytherin Student in multiple Harry Potter films.









Angel Parker (Bonnie) is our Associate Artist and has recently finished a foundation degree at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art (LAMDA). Whilst training she played the role of Miranda in William Shakespeare's The Tempest, as well as playing Irina Arkadina in Chekov's classic The Seagull. Other stage roles include Jane in The Wonderful World of Dissocia, and Victora in Cloud 9. Angel has been working in the acting industry from a young age, including featuring in both St Trinian's films and also gaining a place with The National Youth Theatre.







Alexandra Spencer - Jones (Director) is the founder and Artistic Director of the award-winning theatre company Action To The Word. She has produced and directed A Clockwork Orange which was met with critical acclaim. It was then taken up by West End producers Glynis Henderson Produtions, and subsequently has toured worldwide. She has also adapted and directed Bram Stoker's classic novel Dracula, which continues into development after playing to a highly successful first outing at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. At present Alexandra is directing A Midsummer Night's Dream which will be playing at this years Latitude Festival,before going to the National Theatre's River Stage in August. She has also recently directed Gobsmacked!, currently playing at Underbelly Southbank, and then touring Sydney later this year.
In addition to her work with Action To The Word, Alexandra has acted as Associate Director on Bend It Like Beckham at the Phoenix Theatre, to Jeremy Sans on La Perichole for Garsington Opera, and also to Peter Grimes for Grange Opera having assistant directed his Wizard Of Oz at the London Palladium.
www.actiontotheword.com 


What We Need & What You Get
We're aiming to raise £6500, which we know is a lot of money but this will give us the funding to take the show to The Etcetera Theatre in October, as well as festivals in 2017 that we're currently negotiating. We're particularly interested in taking it to international audiences in Canada and the U.S. This is ultimate direction we'd like the show to go in, however we're focusing on making the production at The Etcetera Theatre the best that it can be in order to start 2017 in a strong position. 

Below is a list of things that your contributions will be funding:

Theatre Hire - Including technician, use of music, projector etc
Set, Costume and Props - The play is set in 1934 in an unnamed Southern American state, and so we have to create an authentic environment that reflects this. This includes a wooden barn, glass bottles, temporary tattoos, food, and more. We also have to hire prop guns, which are costly. 
Director Fees and Rehearsal Space 
Transport - This includes transport around London during the rehearsal period/production period. It also includes transportation of the set which will require van hire.
Public Liability Insurance 
Marketing - This includes photography, printing costs, leaflets etc. 
Entrance into festivals in 2017




What do you get? Let's talk perks!
We know that we're asking you to be extremely generous, so first and foremost we want to thank you even for visiting this page and showing an interest in us. By contributing you can choose from a range of exciting perks that we've created, including the opportunity to have a drink with Bonnie and Clyde in a speakeasy. (They'll be paying, don't worry...) We've created perks to suit a range of budgets, so you can choose anything from extremely grateful social media shout-outs, to getting exclusive post-show party invitations, or even the chance to become a full executive producer of the show. Check out the full range of perks on the right >>>

   Hang on, what happens if we don't reach our target?
If we don't reach 100% of our target (fingers crossed this won't happen), then we'll have to forget any aspirations of taking the show to different festivals and audiences in 2017, as this requires a fair amount of funding. If we only reach 50% of our target we'll still be able to take the show to The Etcetera Theatre, but we won't be able to make the show that we've dreamed of and will have to put everything on an even more extreme budget which will negatively affect the show. We think this would be really unfortunate because the play is set in a wonderfully detailed world, and having the freedom to create that world with the set, props and costumes is something we're committed to providing we have the correct budget.





The Impact
 
Your contributions will not only help this production, they are this production. The money we aim to raise is to cover every aspect of the plays production, from its very beginning to development in 2017 and beyond. We've chosen to embark on this journey because we feel we can do the play justice and create something truly special.
Even though the play is set in 1934 in America, we've already noticed many similarities between the social climate back then compared to the world we live in now. Bonnie and Clyde were young people that had struggled through the Great Depression, and even though the path they chose in life caused complete devastation to many families, it's important to understand what led them down this route. Since the economic crash in 2008 people all over the world have faced their own hardships, including huge amounts of unemployment and rising costs of living compared to the increase in wages. A study from the American Psychological Association has shown that young people aged between 18 - 33 are more stressed than the rest of the population, by quite a margin. Factors such as paying back student loans and the pressure of buying a house and starting a family contribute towards this stress, for instance in the UK it's now common knowledge that tuition fees have trebled to £9000, creating huge amounts of debt for young people and deterring many from higher education altogether. These themes of isolation and despair are beautifully brought to life in the text, and manage to make a play set 82 years ago resonate with modern audiences.
We feel extremely privaledged  to have Alexandra Spencer - Jones on board as she's well established within the arts industry and has had a wealth of experience in producing and directing theatre. Her theatre company Action To The Word currently has taken up residence at the Broadway Theatre in Catford, which will really help as this gives us flexible rehearsal space. Alexandra has worked with Tom in the past by casting him as Hamlet, and also as Harry Bagley in Cloud 9 by Caryl Churchill. By working with her again we know that the show is in safe hands.

Risks & Challenges
 
Our main obstacle will be making sure we market the show properly so that we hopefully sell out every night. Seeing as its only playing for one week we want to make sure that we're playing to full houses as often as possible, as this will also generate buzz for any future performances we do in 2017 etc. Another challenge is simply the logistics of moving the set, costumes, props across London and then storing them when they're not in use. Raising enough funds would eliminate this problem as we could afford to hire the required vehicles and storage facilities with little difficulty. In terms of taking the show to different venues in 2017, this would require a well planned strategy of applications as well as funding, as some international festivals charge fees to apply. 
 
Alexandra has a history of creating productions and then taking them to multiple venues, from fringe settings to West End theatres, and so we would draw from her experience in guiding us through these challenges to ensure the show becomes a success.
 
   
Can't Contribute? Other Ways You Can Help
 
We completely understand that not everybody has the means to donate. If you're reading this it means you've had a look through our campaign and for that alone we're grateful! 
You may not be able to give us financial assistance, however you can still help us in other ways:

By directing other people to this page to create a buzz about our production, this could lead to further donations and would really help!
If you own a business, local or not, you may be able to help us by getting in touch and letting us advertise at your location. Also, you could help us by providing your services (e.g. poster/leaflet/programme printing) in return for an advertisement in our programme that will be seen by hundreds of audience members.
If you're London based and want to get involved/lend a hand... get in touch! We'd love to hear from you.

Thank you for visiting our campaign! We look forward to working on the production as soon a possible, and be sure to keep checking back for regular updates/information.
Tom & Angel 
Main image credited to Charles Flint Photography

story:
Sydney Ignacio

Born and raised in Manila, Sydney began his dance career at the age of 14.  Training at Gigi Velarde David Ballet Dance Workshop, he earned “Commended” and “Honors” in his Royal Academy of Dance (RAD) examinations. He travelled internationally with “Earthsavers DREAMS Ensemble” as a UNESCO Artist for Peace and was a soloist for Philippine Ballet Theater for five years. In 2006, Sydney moved to the US to further his career in the performing arts. He has danced for Verb Ballets, Washington Reflexions Dance Company, El Teatro De Danza Contemporanea de El Salvador, CityDance 2 and CityDance Ensemble.

He also explores other mediums of physical expression such as aerial pole and straps, receiving the bronze medal at the 2014 U.S National Pole Championships level 4 and finalist in the U.S Aerial Championship 2015 Aerial Pole Category. Sydney is currently a member of Sax Lounge in Washington DC performing aerial pole dance, aerial straps and contemporary ballet.

Sydney needs your help to attend Circus Star 2016

Sydney dedicates all of his energy and resources to maintaining an exceptional level of artistry. This means that he often doesn't have the necessary funds to travel to competitions. Sydney needs financial assistance with travel expenses to attend the Circus Star 2016 in Los Angeles. Money will go towards purchasing his plane ticket and covering hotel costs.

The Impact

This campaign will support Sydney in his efforts to continue as a full-time dance and circus artist. It will expose his special talents to a larger community, helping him pursue his dream of sharing movement and dance with the world.

Other Ways You Can Help

Sydney will understand if you can't contribute, but you can still help by sharing this campaign with others or seeing him perform with fellow aerialists and dancers at Sax Lounge in Washington DC.

story:
About the play...

"Forgive me or kill me. That's the only choice you've got."

New Year’s Eve. 1989. South Africa. A black night watchman is preparing for his shift at a small, shabby travelling amusement park encamped outside a Karoo town. A white former army noncom approaches the park preparing for a night of celebration. As the new decade begins, the two men are forced to confront the future, while struggling to forgive the past. From the internationally acclaimed South African playwright Athol Fugard, Playland is a microcosm of the political and social upheaval of the apartheid system drawn out as two men try to learn what it means to walk side by side.
​
"A metaphor set to the sad and sour music of apartheid."  - The New York Post
​
"Fugard provides some meaty, at times searing arias for both men." - The New York Times

 

About the team...​

Joshua Boden (Sound Designer) is a Philadelphia based sound designer, composer/musician and improvising actor. He has designed sound and composed for a number of theatrical productions including The 24 Hour Bald Soprano and Fat Boy (Brat Productions), Acts of Sedition (Trajectories Theatre Project), and The Why  (Simpatico Theatre). In 2010 Joshua moved to Los Angeles California to be mentored by Oscar winning cinematic sound designer Dane Davis (Boogie Nights, The Matrix Trilogy, The Twilight Saga) and giving him the opportunity to learn while working on major Hollywood films. While living in Hollywood Joshua stumbled into long form comedic improvisation leading him to become an alumni of iOWest, Second City Hollywood, and Philly Improv Theater. Since returning from Los Angels in 2014 Joshua has has had the pleasure of working with Tribe Of Fools, designing the sound for their 2015 Fringe hit Zombies…With Guns! as well as Egopo’s 2015 production of The Children's Hour. When not creating sonic landscapes or participating in the existential knock knock joke that is long form improvisation, he spends time with his incredible wife Deborah and their two amazing cats, Miles “Buddy-Boy” Davis Boden-Seif and Billie “Little-Girl” Holiday Boden-Seif.

C. Ryanne Domingues  (Director) is thrilled to be back in Philadelphia and directing at the Drake. Before heading out West to attend graduate school, Ryanne was a founding member of Simpatico Theatre, where she held the position of Producing Artistic Director for five years and directed a variety of shows, including Stop Kiss, Angels Fall, Getting Out, Long Days Journey Into Night, and Pyretown. She has also worked with a number of other Philadelphia companies including The Wilma Theater, InterAct Theatre Company, and Plays & Players Theatre, among others. Other credits include work with New Musicals, Inc., California Shakespeare Theatre, South Coast Repertory Theatre, Little Fish Theatre Company, SkyPilot Theatre Company, and Utah Shakespeare Festival. Ryanne was a participant in the 2008 Lincoln Center Director’s Lab in NYC, and completed her MFA in Directing at the University of California, Irvine. www.ryannedomingues.com

Athol Fugard (Playwright) is an internationally acclaimed South African playwright whose best-known work deals with the political and social upheaval of the apartheid system in South Africa. He was educated at the University of Cape Town. His plays include The Captain's Tiger, Valley Song, My Children! My Africa, A Lesson from Aloes, The Island, and the award-winning Sizwe Banzi is Dead. Mr. Fugard has received six honorary degrees from esteemed colleges and is an Honorary Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature. 

Arnel Sancianco (Set Designer) is a Chicago based scenic designer. He’s receiving his MFA from Northwestern and is currently designing The Wiz with Kokandy productions and Las Meninas with The Hypocrites. He recently designed the sets for How We Got On with Haven Theatre and You On the Moors Now with The Hypocrites. Past design credits include Big Love at Northwestern’s Louis Theatre and The Grapes of Wrath and Green Day’s American Idiot in the Barber Theater, 15 Breaths (About Face), End Game (Right Brain Project), Melancholy Play (Northwestern), Eurydice (UC Irvine), and Picasso at the Lapin AgiIe (UC Irvine). For more of his work visit www.ArnelDesigns.com

Daniel Schreckengost (Lighting Designer) is a freelance lighting designer who has recently transplanted to New York City.  His previous work was based in Los Angeles where he designed for theatre, live events, and architecture.  He has designed theatrical performances for such companies and festivals as California State University – Dominguez Hills, Southern Utah University, Great River Shakespeare Festival, Pacific Conservatory of Performing Arts, Cleveland Public Theatre, Ice Factory Theatre Festival 2010, and Cuyahoga Community College – West. He has designed live event lighting for Mattel and Universal Studios Hollywood through his work with Radiance Lightworks.  Through his work with First Circle Design, Daniel has been an assistant designer on various live event and installation projects as well as a lighting designer for the company’s architectural projects.  Some of these projects include the Emmy Awards Governors' Ball, the Academy Awards Governors' Ball, the MGM Macau Butterfly Dome in China, and the Kids' Choice Awards Welcome Party. In his off-time, Daniel is an avid film photographer and vintage camera collector.  This allows him to continue to capture and study images in light. He earned his MFA from the University of California, Irvine.  www.schreckengost-designs.com

Stephanie Sintef (Stage Manager) is happy to be working again with Ryanne and her fellow Anteaters. Stephanie has been a freelance Stage Manager in Philadelphia for the past three years. She has worked with various theatres including: The Walnut Street Theatre, EgoPo Classic Theatre, Philadelphia Young Playwrights, Orbiter 3, Opera Philadelphia, and InterAct Theatre Company. Proud alumn of UC Irvine (BA Drama, Honors in Stage Management). 

 

About the cast...​

Mark Cairns (Gideon le Roux) is excited to collaborate with Ryanne & Jerry again, and with this talented crew!  Mark was born and raised in Pittsburgh, and earned a BS degree in Chemical Engineering there.  He served 4 years as an Army Officer at Fort Bragg and in the Gulf War, and worked for many years as an Environmental Engineer before becoming a professional actor.  Since then, he has worked with theaters such as The Wilma (Rock'N'Roll, Leaving, and Macbeth), The Lantern (A Midsummer Nights Dream, and Henry V), Philadelphia Shakespeare (Romeo & Juliet (twice), Pericles, and Twelfth Night), Bristol Riverside (Inherit the Wind), Theatre Exile (The North Plan), and Commonwealth Classic (a bunch of times).  Mark has also served the stage as an occasional writer, fight choreographer, and military consultant.  He has a number of film and television credits that include commercials, documentaries, and the film The Last Airbender.  He also owns & operates an investment business (PathfindersRE.com), and also makes mead in his basement.  Love to his wife Aileen, and their little scruffimuffin, Lucky -- both accomplished stage performers. 

Jerry Rudasill (Martinus Zoeloe) is a longtime Philadelphia based actor having worked with several Theater companies in the region including Azuka, Bootless Artworks, Philadelphia Shakespeare, Iron Age, Curio Theater Company, Hedgerow Theater, Shakespeare in Clark Park, Luna Theater Company, Plays and Players, and the Idiopathic Ridiculopathy Consortium, and was one of the original artists to participate in the inaugural season of the Philadelphia Fringe Festival over twenty years ago. He has served on the Board of the Philadelphia Dramatist Center and taught acting at New Freedom Theater and the Lawrenceville School. Notable credits include Feste in Shakespeare's Twelfth Night, Aaron the Moor in Titus Andronicus, Gerard Escobar in Death and the Maiden, RP McMurphy in One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, and the Soldier in Sarah Kane's, Blasted to mention only a few. Jerry is a graduate of Dickinson College and a 1992 recipient of the Weiss Prize for the Arts. This is his first time returning to the stage in two years and is excited to participate in a production of  one of the works of Athol Fugard, a personal favorite playwright.

 

Why this play now?

In light of this country's current political and social climate, I felt the need to produce a play that is about acceptance, forgiveness, and respect. However, I also thought it was important to show that these three things are incredibly difficult to achieve, both for ourselves and for others. The act of obtaining them takes great sacrifice, self reflection, and sometimes painful honesty.

Playland takes place near the end of apartheid in South Africa. It follows a black man and a white man as they attempt to find forgiveness in each other and in themselves. I have learned a lot about what it means to forgive by reading this play, and think it is an important piece that will surely promote active dialogue between audience members.
 

Why support theatre?

Before choosing to produce any play, I always ask myself why this piece must be seen in the theatre, and not on film or television. For this play, the answer came quickly: This play requires both stillness and risk. Various, quick camera angles would take away from the rawness of the piece. These men completely expose themselves emotionally, with no edits or touch-ups possible. Their breath is heavy, their hesitations filled with decades of fear and rage. This story can be told no other way than live.
 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $6,000 to make this incredible production come to life. This money will pay for the venue rental, artist salaries, marketing, set materials, costumes, and royalties to produce the play.
     
  • We have some pretty great perks, including tickets to the show and awesome name recognition to show off to your friends and family! ("I supported a really important play today. What did you do?") Plus, all donations over $1,000 are TAX DEDUCTIBLE!
     

The Impact

  • Help support independent theatre artists!
  • Bring your friends to a show that promotes acceptance and tolerance in today's world.
  • Let those around you know that art and culture are incredibly important to today's society.

About the cast...​
Mark Cairns (Gideon le Roux) is excited to collaborate with Ryanne & Jerry again, and with this talented crew!  Mark was born and raised in Pittsburgh, and earned a BS degree in Chemical Engineering there.  He served 4 years as an Army Officer at Fort Bragg and in the Gulf War, and worked for many years as an Environmental Engineer before becoming a professional actor.  Since then, he has worked with theaters such as The Wilma (Rock'N'Roll, Leaving, and Macbeth), The Lantern (A Midsummer Nights Dream, and Henry V), Philadelphia Shakespeare (Romeo & Juliet (twice), Pericles, and Twelfth Night), Bristol Riverside (Inherit the Wind), Theatre Exile (The North Plan), and Commonwealth Classic (a bunch of times).  Mark has also served the stage as an occasional writer, fight choreographer, and military consultant.  He has a number of film and television credits that include commercials, documentaries, and the film The Last Airbender.  He also owns & operates an investment business (PathfindersRE.com), and also makes mead in his basement.  Love to his wife Aileen, and their little scruffimuffin, Lucky -- both accomplished stage performers. 
Jerry Rudasill (Martinus Zoeloe) is a longtime Philadelphia based actor having worked with several Theater companies in the region including Azuka, Bootless Artworks, Philadelphia Shakespeare, Iron Age, Curio Theater Company, Hedgerow Theater, Shakespeare in Clark Park, Luna Theater Company, Plays and Players, and the Idiopathic Ridiculopathy Consortium, and was one of the original artists to participate in the inaugural season of the Philadelphia Fringe Festival over twenty years ago. He has served on the Board of the Philadelphia Dramatist Center and taught acting at New Freedom Theater and the Lawrenceville School. Notable credits include Feste in Shakespeare's Twelfth Night, Aaron the Moor in Titus Andronicus, Gerard Escobar in Death and the Maiden, RP McMurphy in One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, and the Soldier in Sarah Kane's, Blasted to mention only a few. Jerry is a graduate of Dickinson College and a 1992 recipient of the Weiss Prize for the Arts. This is his first time returning to the stage in two years and is excited to participate in a production of  one of the works of Athol Fugard, a personal favorite playwright.
 
Why this play now?
In light of this country's current political and social climate, I felt the need to produce a play that is about acceptance, forgiveness, and respect. However, I also thought it was important to show that these three things are incredibly difficult to achieve, both for ourselves and for others. The act of obtaining them takes great sacrifice, self reflection, and sometimes painful honesty.
Playland takes place near the end of apartheid in South Africa. It follows a black man and a white man as they attempt to find forgiveness in each other and in themselves. I have learned a lot about what it means to forgive by reading this play, and think it is an important piece that will surely promote active dialogue between audience members. 
Why support theatre?
Before choosing to produce any play, I always ask myself why this piece must be seen in the theatre, and not on film or television. For this play, the answer came quickly: This play requires both stillness and risk. Various, quick camera angles would take away from the rawness of the piece. These men completely expose themselves emotionally, with no edits or touch-ups possible. Their breath is heavy, their hesitations filled with decades of fear and rage. This story can be told no other way than live. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $6,000 to make this incredible production come to life. This money will pay for the venue rental, artist salaries, marketing, set materials, costumes, and royalties to produce the play. 
We have some pretty great perks, including tickets to the show and awesome name recognition to show off to your friends and family! ("I supported a really important play today. What did you do?") Plus, all donations over $1,000 are TAX DEDUCTIBLE! 


The Impact

Help support independent theatre artists!
Bring your friends to a show that promotes acceptance and tolerance in today's world.
Let those around you know that art and culture are incredibly important to today's society.

story:
Our Story

We are Notapom Productions, a new Hamilton based theatre company looking to bring our vision to the stage in our first production: a contemporary retelling of Shakespeare's Romeo & Juliet. This production will be incredibly of the moment, incorporating speeches and political statements surrounding recent elections in regards to racial tensions and tragedies between Islam and Catholicism, ripped right from the headlines of 2016. We will be paying particular attention to the way American politicians, including Donald Trump, use fear mongering and "Terrorism" as a buzzword to promote racism and create violent behaviour between neighbours.

We want to provoke people leaving the theatre to be more aware of how headlines and news biases affect their perceptions of others; we need your help to make this happen. 

We are looking to raise $3000 to make this vision a reality. This money is an absolute necessity for renting theatre space, purchasing set materials, construction, costumes, props, lighting tech, and makeup. Reaching this goal will allow us to return  profit from ticket sales to the artists and designers.

Every cent we raise will go directly into this production.

Every dollar helps, but if you are interested we are offering unique perks that you can take advantage of, such as a signed cast photo, a shout-out in our program, and a personalized thank you video from cast members.

We are also planning on another wave of perks in the next few weeks so if you don't see anything you like right now, stay updated for more.

Theatre is not easy. It is a collaborative effort that takes hours of rehearsals and planning to accomplish. Luckily, rehearsals are well under way and the energy and trust everyone feels for each other is palpable. Everyone involved is passionate about sharing our message as we workshop the script and develop characters that are relevant to this adaptation.

If you do not have the means to become a backer at this moment, there are other ways you can help. If this sounds like something you could be invested in, spread the word on social media. Every little bit helps. 

Thank you for checking out our campaign!

Sincerely,

The Notapom Team

 

SHOW DATES: 

September 16th, 17th, 18th, 22nd, 23rd, 24th, 25th - 8pm

September 17th and 24th - 2pm

 

LOCATION: 

Dundas Little Theatre - 37 Market St. South, Dundas, ON

story:
Who We Are

Revolutionary Motion (RevMo) was founded in 2013 by Ben "Drex" Drexler, Caitlin Hauer, and Leslie Elmore as a creative collaboration with props and dance. We began recruiting performers and working with them to develop new work that would emphasize choreography and movement expression through prop manipulation while maintaining a highly professional commitment to skill development and creative collaboration.

What we didn't expect was that it would turn into a family. While we strongly emphasized expression and professionalism, the atmosphere it created led to deep friendships and incredible relationships.

We've had great success at performing at Burning Man as well as one-off fire and LED performances in the DMV, but we've long harbored a greater ambition: mount one of our performances as a dance concert. Put our work in a theatrical context and let it stand alongside ballet and modern dance concerts as a work of creative artistry.

This year, we created something very special. The piece we've written for Burning Man is unlike the ones we'd written in years past. The storyline, the dynamic, the characters that have come about are unlike any piece we have made before. It’s been a long time goal to put a flow arts production on stage and this is the perfect piece to do it with! It will be the first full length flow arts dance concert in Washington, DC.

Help us show the world what our art is capable of as well as share our art with our friends and our community!

Our Project

Our piece has been inspired by this year's Burning Man theme: DaVinci's Workshop. We took this as an opportunity to explore the historical significance of the Renaissance and Enlightenment from several different perspectives. 

We didn't find any simple answers--mechanization has led us from the roots of industrialization and mass production to the last century's explosion in technology: landing men on the moon and making the world's information ever more accessible while simultaneously exposing workers to the horrors of factory labor and the emergence of weapons of ever greater destructive potential. Pushing back the tide of superstition into the age of reason has also led to a stigma toward traditional remedies and community resource structures, many of which are only now being rediscovered or implemented.

We believe the flow arts are uniquely suited to expressing these very complicated issues because our relationships with the objects around us can be complicated: we form a deep distrust of technology we don't understand while at the same time humanizing objects we have regular contact with, naming our cars or talking to our computers when they don't respond as we expect. Nowhere is the tension between object as extension of human while at the same time completely alien more apparent than in flow arts, where the movement of the props we spin is at once a marriage of intention as well as a constant struggle to produce the patterns and effects we see in our heads.

Our Goal & Your Perks

We've done a great deal of the hard work already by writing the work--we can't wait to share it with you! What we need is help funding the production of the show. We have reserved the Anacostia Arts Center in Washington, DC for the evenings of October 21 and 22 and paid our first deposit on the space, but we cannot complete the necessary funds for this show out of pocket. 

Our baseline goal is $2,000 for this production--this is an absolute bare minimum of the funds necessary to pull this off. This covers:

  • Rental of the blackbox theater at the Anacostia Arts Center.
  • Purchase of black lights to enhance the experience of our performance--since we are not performing with fire we want to get people as close to that experience as we can muster.
  • Paying a stage manager and a sound and light technician.
  • Advertising materials, including postcards, posters, and Facebook ads to get butts in seats--we want people to see this show!
  • Insurance for the event.

Ideally, we'd like to raise $3,000! Here's what that would cover:

  • Paying all our performers for their effort and time!
  • New costuming specifically designed for this show.
  • Professional video recording of the show to share online--to inspire other artists with our work and make it available to the entire world for free!

Our perks are offerings by the members of RevMo, pieces of their talents, time, and passion with the intention of contributing to this amazing project. When you choose one of these perks, know that you are receiving something deeply personal from the performer offering it.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't support this project monetarily, you can still help us reach our goal! Share this project with your friends and family on social media--every new set of eyeballs can potentially get us a step closer to our goal. 

We cannot reach this goal without your help! Thank you in advance for all your support, time, and energy. We are excited to bring our work to the stage!

story:
Short Summary

WE ARE! REVOLUTION!  That is how we introduce ourselves to the world. Revolution is a competitive show choir group from Olentangy Orange High School in Lewis Center, Ohio.  We have been competing since the High School opened its doors in 2008.  

As a competitive show choir, we travel around the state with a 20-minute production of singing, dancing, theatrics, and musicianship, smiling amid several costume and set changes and trying to win over the judges and the crowds.  The long hours of intense work and pressure, as well our love of music and performance, have together created a close-knit team and family.

Like many schools, our arts program does not get the level of funding it needs, but we still strive to put on the best show possible. Being a new school, we know we are the pioneers of what we believe will become a strong and proud tradition of performance and championships.  This is where you can help.  Please consider helping us in our pursuit of excellence that will keep our school and future students engaged in the arts.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to add instruction from professional within the world of show choir to sharpen our abilities as a team as well as improving our set that has inhibited our ability to set up and present effectively.  

The Impact

In the end, you would be helping a bunch of kids that just want to dance, sing and be accepted for loving this so much.  There are more of us out there that just need an awesome tradition, and some outreach from members of a championship team to light that spark to want to sing and dance in front of the world.  We are fearless when we perform, and it helps us be fearless in our lives.  Help us reach our potential as a team, and encourage more students to embrace the arts and amazing experiences you can have.  

Risks & Challenges

Even with additional resources no one can guarantee a win.  That's why you play the game, right?  But the encouragement you'll provide by believing in us and helping us with our goal will last past a win or lose during competition.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Follow and post anything and everything on every social media account you can.  And if you can't give, but see our posts, send us some good vibes and positive attitudes!

story:
Hi Folks!

As we draw near the end of our campaign, we just wanted to take a moment and point out some of the awesome things your donation will pay for as we embark on this journey...
$20 pays an actor for one performance 
$50 provides fresh script copies for everyone
$100 pays an actor for rehearsal
$500 pays one of our awesome designers
Keep that in mind if you're still debating on contributing. And if this is your first time to the site...read on!

INLAND EMPRESS is....

A thrilling new play from up and coming playwright Tom Cavanaugh, and directed by the award winning Jessica Hanna.

Returning home from a 7 year prison stint, Louise finds she's lost her place as matriarch of the family, and boss of the family business. Running meth on a mostly defunct horse ranch seemed like the perfect setup. But since Louise comes back from prison a very different woman, she wants to change things -- make them better for the sister and 3 nieces she's done nothing but scam, lie, and corrupt their whole lives. What she didn't count on was that they were all doing just fine without her. At least, that's what they want to believe.

A delicately balanced slice of seriously messed up family life, Inland Empress has a Tracy Letts vibe...if Tracy Letts was on meth. It's Breaking Bad meets The Facts of Life.

Based on true events.

No seriously, it's a good play people!

Mutant Collective is...

Three friends (Jeffrey Wylie, Monica Martin, and Victoria Watson) had a realization one day that they loved theater, but weren't getting to work on a specific project that they could truly call their own. Along came this play, which all of them fell in love with and decided to champion. With any luck, they'll survive this one and become the next big theater company in LA. (Well, maybe in their own minds, at the very least.)

Why you should contribute to THIS show...

Of all the possible projects out there, why give money to this one you ask?

1) We know what we're doing. We're all theater pros and know where each one of your dollars will be spent to create a kick-ass fantastic show.

2) As a new play from a new playwright, these opportunities are rare. If nothing else, support the amazing play that Tom has written that otherwise might sit in years of artistic committees and literary managers before anything maybe/might happen with it.

3) THIS PLAY HAS 5 AMAZING ROLES FOR WOMEN! That's right, ladies, poney up some money for theatrical equality.

*****

But above all...remember that no matter what you can give (even if it's a smile and words of support) you are contributing to something coming from a pure place of wanting to make really damn good art.

story:
Stretch The Story! 

My name is Sean O'Laoghaire and I'm from Portage in County Kerry, but living in West Cork and for many years now, I've been telling stories, to children and adults, with puppets and without.

In the last few days, I've been invited to Connecticut in the United States to tell stories at the opening of a new craft shop in Hamden, near the Quinnipac University.

This is a huge and once in a lifetime opportunity and I so want to make the most of it and contact with people and organisations that I could work with in the future and build up a proper tour, early next year. 

This could very easily launch my story telling career on a much bigger platform and I'll do everything to make it succeed.

The plan!

As this most welcome invitation came out of the blue, I've had no time to save and work out funds and to really make this most productive, I need to move around, travel and show my actual face and talent to people.

Over the last few months, I've began to write up the stories I tell and they have  richer and stronger layers added to them, by this process, it seems a perfect time finish, edit and get ready for publishing, as telling stories is so wonderful, but very fleeting in the moment, a collection of written stories is more tangible. Please inform me, if you have claimed one of the perks, so, I can furnish you with the relevant perks, Thank you!


Straight up Story telling is dying Art, I've been blessed with a natural aptitude for it and it gives me a chance to exercise peoples imaginations, it awakens something very primevel in the audience, creating a very soothing experience for one and all. The world needs more of this and more of me!  


And as well,

If you have any contacts in the America that might be interested in meeting me, please put us in contact, Thank you!.

story:
The Original Theatre Company has been making and touring theatre throughout the UK and Ireland for over 10 years. 

In the past 2 years alone, we have staged over 780 performances in 65 theatres to over 250,000 people without a penny of public subsidy.

We can see that regional public arts funding is heading towards a crisis point. Arts venues are closing in local communities and there are an increasingly smaller number of touring companies who can afford to take good quality work on the road. Audiences are invited to take fewer creative risks with what they see – and touring theatre is not seen as important, not vital, not something contemporary and relevant to talk about with friends. Yet, touring theatre still has the unique responsibility of giving Great Britain access to stories and ideas proposed from different perspectives, places to come and be challenged, to hear different voices, to share stories with neighbours and to laugh long and loud.
Of course, theatre is still thriving in London and the UK’s big cities – it’s a great time for story-telling – but is that inspiring if you live in a small town without ready access to transport or the inclination to travel for hours. What was the last thing you saw in your local theatre? If it didn’t excite you, why not? If it did – great! Now- what would happen if everyone in your community could keep having experiences like that week-in, week-out? Good theatres bring people together. Good stories bring joy and reflection and memories, and they remind us about the very great power we have as people alive today with beating hearts, emotions and passions.
 We have a vision to bring back great theatre to the regions with heart and ambition... but we need your help. We want to take the best writers, actors and artists and make work that will ignite stages around the country. Not made for the West End, but made for Hull, made for Eastbourne for Basingstoke, for Darlington for Berwickupon-Tweed and hundreds of other beautiful, vibrant UK towns. No compromises and no live screening in cinemas. 
Communication and collaboration has changed in the last ten years and we know that our voices and wishes can count for something. We are asking now for your voice to join the voices of thousands of others. We are not asking you to save a single theatre, or a specific community or group, we are asking you to stand up for original theatre in every town, for every community, for everyone. Demand more, engage more, tell the world about the stories that inspire you, and even the ones that don’t. 
Join us in celebrating the world around us. 
Thanks for all your support so far. 

We want to raise at least £30,000 towards developing and staging a bold and innovative programme of stories for 2016 and beyond. We need your help.

You can read our full vision for UK touring theatre here


What We Need & What You Get

You can hep us raise at least £30,000 to contribute towards development costs of new productions in 2016, including the award-winning Invincible by Torben Betts, which will receive its first ever UK tour, a major revival of Emlyn Williams' Night Must Fall and an exciting new play called Tom & The Superheroes by Craig Gilbert.

This money will help us attract more investment, through which we can commission and develop new playwrights as well as enable regional theatre audiences to see work by some of the best directors, actors and designers in the UK.

In exchange for your generosity, we are offering some incredible opportunities to get involved with theatre-making and to spend time with acting stars - including Leon Ockenden and Arthur Bostrom. We've got top tickets for next year's shows, lifetime memberships, backstage tours, signed programmes and drinks with our casts.

Whether you can just spare the price of a pint or whether you want to invest - and play a significant role - in something you really believe in, there is an opportunity to make a difference.

All funds raised will be used by The Original Theatre Company in the investment of new works, touring costs and to secure more long-term sustainable funding.

The Impact

Your contribution will:

  • Help secure the future of touring theatre in the UK
  • Be investing in a resourceful company with a brilliant track-record
  • Give you access to the world of story-telling, inviting you to play a part
  • Send a message to to policy-makers that regional theatre is vital

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Make some noise and spread the word! - link to this page and use the #storieseverywhere campaign hashtag
  • Join our mailing list, to find out how you can play a part in the future: 
---

 “I’m proud to say that some of the most exciting work of my career has been with Original Theatre Company. The standard of production has always been extremely high and as a company we love taking good plays to both traditional and not so traditional touring venues. Since first working with the company I’ve watched its reputation grow with audiences as they share our love of good theatre.”  

Arthur Bostrom - Actor

---

“Original Theatre Company has proved to be one of the most successful and exciting regional touring companies in recent years. The company has produced a number of artistic and commercially successful productions. Playing to large numbers of people, the works have been distinctively powerful and a cultural experience for our audiences. At the heart of everything Malvern Theatres believes in, this company reflects in the passionately held belief that regional audiences expect and deserve the very best quality of work.”

Nic Lloyd - Chief Executive, Malvern Theatres

---

“The Original Theatre Company is a regular visitor to Salisbury Playhouse both because of the quality of their productions and the fact that they sell extremely well. A delightful and highly professional company to deal with.” 

Sebastian Warrack - Executive Director, Salisbury Playhouse

---

“The Original Theatre Company’s commitment to high quality theatre is undeniable. The energy and enthusiasm with which they continue to bring their work to as wide and diverse an audience as possible is, in our times of cuts and commercial imperatives, positively inspirational. They know people need stories and they are determined to tell them.” 

Philip Franks - Actor

---

“We look to The Original Theatre Company to provide our audiences, current and new, with good productions of contemporary writing – work that resonates with as well as challenges their own experience of 21st century living.” 

Sarah Holmes - Chief Executive, Ipswich New Wolsey Theatre

---

“We have been delighted to witness the growing and well deserved reputation of The Original Theatre Company as a major contributor to touring theatre. Such high quality productions are essential to keep our audiences coming to drama in the future” 

Christine Bradwell - CEO, Anvil Arts 

---

“The Original Theatre Company has been a brilliant platform for me to explore and embrace a variety of complex characters and tour the length and breadth of the UK. I have travelled from Berwick Upon Tweed to Exeter and loved every minute of it.” 

Siobhan O’Kelly - Actor

---
story_txt:
The Original Theatre Company has been making and touring theatre throughout the UK and Ireland for over 10 years. 

In the past 2 years alone, we have staged over 780 performances in 65 theatres to over 250,000 people without a penny of public subsidy.
We can see that regional
public arts funding is heading towards a crisis point. Arts
venues are closing in local communities and there are an
increasingly smaller number of touring companies who
can afford to take good quality work on the road.
Audiences are invited to take fewer creative risks with
what they see – and touring theatre is not seen as important,
not vital, not something contemporary and relevant to
talk about with friends.
Yet, touring theatre still has the unique responsibility of
giving Great Britain access to stories and ideas proposed
from different perspectives, places to come and be
challenged, to hear different voices, to share stories with
neighbours and to laugh long and loud.Of course, theatre
is still thriving in London and the UK’s big cities – it’s a
great time for story-telling – but is that inspiring if you live
in a small town without ready access to transport or the
inclination to travel for hours.
What was the last thing you saw in your local theatre? If it
didn’t excite you, why not? If it did – great! Now- what
would happen if everyone in your community could keep
having experiences like that week-in, week-out? Good
theatres bring people together. Good stories bring joy
and reflection and memories, and they remind us about
the very great power we have as people alive today with
beating hearts, emotions and passions. We have a vision
to bring back great theatre to the regions with heart and
ambition... but we need your help.
We want to take the best writers, actors and artists and
make work that will ignite stages around the country. Not
made for the West End, but made for Hull, made for
Eastbourne for Basingstoke, for Darlington for Berwickupon-Tweed
and hundreds of other beautiful, vibrant UK
towns. No compromises and no live screening in cinemas. Communication and collaboration has changed in the last
ten years and we know that our voices and wishes can
count for something.
We are asking now for your voice to join the voices of
thousands of others. We are not asking you to save a single
theatre, or a specific community or group, we are asking
you to stand up for original theatre in every town, for
every community, for everyone. Demand more, engage
more, tell the world about the stories that inspire you, and
even the ones that don’t. Join us in celebrating the world
around us. Thanks for all your support so far. 







We want to raise at least £30,000 towards developing and staging a bold and innovative programme of stories for 2016 and beyond. We need your help.You can read our full vision for UK touring theatre here
   What We Need & What You Get
You can hep us raise at least £30,000 to contribute towards development costs of new productions in 2016, including the award-winning Invincible by Torben Betts, which will receive its first ever UK tour, a major revival of Emlyn Williams' Night Must Fall and an exciting new play called Tom & The Superheroes by Craig Gilbert.
This money will help us attract more investment, through which we can commission and develop new playwrights as well as enable regional theatre audiences to see work by some of the best directors, actors and designers in the UK.
In exchange for your generosity, we are offering some incredible opportunities to get involved with theatre-making and to spend time with acting stars - including Leon Ockenden and Arthur Bostrom. We've got top tickets for next year's shows, lifetime memberships, backstage tours, signed programmes and drinks with our casts.
Whether you can just spare the price of a pint or whether you want to invest - and play a significant role - in something you really believe in, there is an opportunity to make a difference.
All funds raised will be used by The Original Theatre Company in the investment of new works, touring costs and to secure more long-term sustainable funding.



The Impact
 Your contribution will:  Help secure the future of touring theatre in the UK Be investing in a resourceful company with a brilliant track-record Give you access to the world of story-telling, inviting you to play a part
Send a message to to policy-makers that regional theatre is vital



    Other Ways You Can Help  Make some noise and spread the word! - link to this page and use the #storieseverywhere campaign hashtag


Join our mailing list, to find out how you can play a part in the future:

story:
PROGETTO/PROJECT

(ita)

Trentesimo è un spettacolo di teatro danza totalmente autoprodotto da chi lo realizza. E' stato selezionato dalla compagnia ZEROGRAMMI attraverso il bando PREMUTAZIONI per un residenziale che si svolgerà nei mesi di gennaio e febbraio 2016. La presentazione ufficiale dello spettacolo è prevista il 10 marzo 2016 presso la Lavanderia a Vapore di Collegno. Trentesimo affronta un tema delicato, ma estremamente complesso. Pone l'attenzione su alcuni aspetti che ruotano attorno al concetto di stare e sugli infiniti paradossi che vivono tra l'idea di immobilità e l'idea di azione.

(eng)

Trentesimo is a dancetheatre performance, and it is totally funded from the creators. It has been selected from Cie. ZEROGRAMMI within the PERMUTAZIONI Competition for a residency that will take place during January and February 2016. The official debut of the performance is planned for the 10th of March 2016 at the Lavanderia a Vapore in Collegno (Turin). Trentesimo takes on a delicate matter, yet extremely complex. It pays attenction on staying, the several meanings of this concept and the infinite paradoxes between the conditions of immobility and action.



SINOSSI/SYNOPSIS

(ita)

Gengé ha da poco compiuto trent'anni e, come molti coetanei vive forte il contrasto e le tensioni legate alla realizzazione personale. Si reca ad un colloquio di lavoro per una posizione interessante presso la sede della multinazionale. Durante la salita, l’ascensore si ferma all'improvviso. Nel periodo della vita in cui il tempo sembra scorrere più veloce e la sensazione è quella di rischiare irrimediabilmente di perdere la grande occasione, Gengé pone questioni semplici, ma urgenti che rivolge a se stesso, agli altri e all'alto nel tentativo di trovare risposte che diventano subito altre domande sulla società che a volte limita e costringe, in cui il timore di sbagliare può trasformarsi in immobilità. Il tempo sospeso e lo spazio compresso spingono il protagonista a ridiscutere le motivazioni iniziali, riflettere con pungente ironia sulla tensione incolmabile tra realtà e rappresentazione e giungere alla sua personale scelta definitiva.

(eng)

Gengè recently turned 30 and similarly to other peers feels a strong contrast and tension linked to his personal establishment. He goes to a job interview for an interesting position at the site of an international corporation. While climbing till the apex presidential floor the lift suddenly stops. In a few seconds the keeper will inform him a technician squad is coming to rescue him. In the moment of life that seems to flow faster, where the constant sensation is to risk loosing your life opportunity, in a society that holds and limits with worries of mistakes and paralysis, Gengè asks himself, the others and the Higher simple urgent questions, in the trial to find answers that become other questions. The suspended time and compressed space push the character to reconsider his initial motivations, to think with spiking irony about the infinite tension between objective and subjective reality, and finally get to his definitive choice.



NOTE DI REGIA/DIRECTOR'S NOTES

(ita)

“L’esistenza dell’uomo è un nesso indistricabile di presente, passato e futuro. L’uomo vive nel mondo anzitutto come un agente che lo modifica e lo riorganizza continuamente”. (Martin Heidegger)

 Avere trent'anni e sentirsi persi. Una sensazione condivisa da un numero sempre crescente di coetanei. Una larga fascia di persone vive il passaggio all'età adulta con un senso di frustrazione. Il periodo della vita in cui progettare e scegliere consapevolmente si trasforma in un limbo, facile bersaglio di critiche e pregiudizi non soltanto della generazione dei padri, ma anche di chi sceglie di riconfermare i valori della tradizione. Si deve fare i conti con la difficoltà a costituirsi come individui, la distanza tra l’immagine che ognuno ha di se stesso e la proiezione dello sguardo degli altri, la confusione tra gli obiettivi che ci prefiggiamo per nostra volontà e le aspettative imposte da status e modelli sociali, la rinuncia a scegliere altro da quanto predefinito. In un contesto segnato da numerose falle sistemiche appare necessario riconsiderare la propria posizione nel mondo e trovare modi nuovi per agire. Il linguaggio del corpo è il punto di partenza della ricerca sull'immobilità e sulle molteplici possibilità che si aprono in una dimensione di spazio e tempo sospesi. A partire da una situazione di costrizione, Gengé traccia nuove traiettorie esistenziali che lo porteranno ad affrancarsi definitivamente da tutto ciò che quel lavoro, dapprima tanto ambito, rappresentava e scegliere la sua strada con coerenza e determinazione.

(eng)

“Human exsistence is an inextricable bound of present, past and future. Men live as agents that constantly interpret and transform meanings in the life-world”. (Martin Heidegger)

To be thirty and feel lost. A shared perception from a rising number of our peers. There’s a large share of people who feels the passage to the adult age as an element of frustration. The moment of life for wittingly planning and choosing becomes a limbo, a target for critics and prejudices of fathers and those who decide to reconfirm the virtues of tradition. One has to face the challenge of self-development, the divide between his own perception and the projection of the others’ eyes, the confusion between the objectives we intentionally aim to and the consequences of social models and statuses, the surrender to choose something different from what we what. In this critical system failure environment, it is clear we have to redesign our global location and find new strategies. The latter is dense and engaging and strongly bonded to a phisical vocaboulary that is firmly based on the observation of the dayly routine. The body language is the starting point of our research on immobility and the several chances given by the condition of suspended space and time. From a stuck situation, Gengè draws the lines of a new existence, untrapped from all that job meant and go his way with coherence and determination.


CREW

Direzione artistica Roberta Bonetto
Interprete Gabriel Beddoes
Produzione esecutiva Fabio Ferrero
Media content Francesca Bono
Comunicazione Stefano Durando

story:
Short Summary

Hello! My name is Kevin White and I am a young theatre artist living and working in Philadelphia. I have recently had the honor of being accepted into the first ever Think.Create.Inspire Festival through SCharliProductions! I have written a short play about depression, suicide, and how they affect people. To write this piece, last year I reached out over social media and got people's real stories about their struggles with depression and suicide. I used these stories, quotes, and my own thoughts on the subject to create this piece about depression awareness. It was originally performed at DeSales University for a directing project, and I am extremely happy to have the chance to spread the message of this piece of theatre to even more people!

What We Need

I am hoping to raise $5000 to produce this project to its fullest potential. This money is extremely important to compensate the artists working on the project, rent a space to rehearse, and to buy necessary props and costumes. Where does your money go exactly?
  • There are 7 characters in the play, and I am hoping to pay each actor a $500 stipend. This is $3500 out of the $5000 goal.
  • I need to cast and rehearse this piece in a space that the actors and I can work to the best of our abilities. I am hoping to use up to $750 for a space to rehearse, making this $4250 out of the $5000 goal.
  • The remaining $750 will go to necessary props and/or costumes that are needed for this project.
  • If we are lucky enough to unexpectedly come in under budget and have any money leftover, the remaining sum will reimburse me for my time and transportation. 

The Impact

With this project I hope to reach more people, inform them of the real affects of depression and suicide, and encourage them to help those around them who may suffer from the disease. When this project was originally put on while I was in college, it was met with great success. My professor, classmates, and friends all encouraged me to continue with this project. Its story-contributors urged me to spread their messages. Through this festival and this fundraising campaign, I hope to reach as many people as possible (the theatre has a 250 seat house). I hope this project will empower people to be able to start a conversation about depression and its affects with anyone who may need their help.

Risks & Challenges

Creating a piece of theatre is always challenging. It is always a risk to create art. Even more so, I believe, when a piece of theatre art has such strong subject matter and has the potential to impact its audiences so strongly. I believe I will be able to work with strong actors in a safe environment with this fundraising campaign. This will allow me to spread this project's message to the best of my abilities.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, and that is completely understandable. I truly appreciate your interest in this project. If you would like to help in another way, here's a few ways how!

  • Spread the word about this cause! Share with your friends, family, and coworkers. Many people have stories and experiences with this subject matter, and every little bit helps.
  • Buy a ticket! Tickets are not yet on sale but keep an eye on this website for more information!

Thank you so much for your consideration and help with this cause!
