story:
Short Summary

Hello! My name is Hope Clark and we are the Lalibela Circus and Cultural School in Lalibela, Ethiopia, the home of a UNESCO Heritage site where more then 45000 tourists come every year to visit the 13th century rock-hewn churches. I am volunteering to create a self-sustaining, income generating show about Lalibela history, community and culture to be performed in the fine UNESCO Cultural Center run by the Ministry of Culture and Tourism in the town of Lalibela. The intimate theater houses a stage and seats for 138 people. The ongoing show will be performed by local adult Circus and Dance Association members working full time. Revenue from ticket sales will build sustainable income for the Lalibela Circus and Cultural School and the community. Lalibela holds what some call the 8th wonder of the world, ancient architecture carved into the earth, instead of built upon it. We are creating business liaisons with the tourist industry to support this employment-creating project, while contributing to the community's rich ancient culture through modern voices.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $14,954 to cover the costs of fixing the sound system and automated movie screen in the UNESCO Cultural Center, a new set of mats, three traditional Ethiopian instruments, lights, microphones, sound equipment, traditional costumes and a rehearsal fee of $25 a week for 14  performers. We are planning for a 2-month rehearsal schedule. This will enable us to create a professional show that will be performed regularly for the visitors and tourists who come to see the remarkable churches. They will be transformed through an experience which exposes them to the cultural life, beauty and challenges of the community.

Here is the budget breakdown.

                                            

Mats - $1930, Musical Instruments - $1684, Costumes - $1050, Lights - $1476, Sound equipment - $2467, Set - $1500, Cultural Space Work - $1200, Salaries for 14 performers - $2800,Transaction Fees - $847. Expenses will be prioritized. The show will go on even if full fundraising has not been met, it will just be pared-down. 

Once the show is created we could create a gross income of $345,000 a year. These funds will provide a good salary for the performers, develop the Circus and Cultural School as well as fulfill other educational needs of the community.

Your contribution to create this show will have a huge impact..

I will oversee the distribution of these funds to produce the show.  In partnership with local Ethiopian Associations, we will create and publicize the performance. I will manage the day-to-day operations of the project. 70% of the profit will go to the community and 30% will cover administrative costs.

Other ways you can help

    As always your love is most important, so if you are inspired to share this project with your friends, please do. You can use the Indiegogo share tools.
story_txt:
Short Summary
Hello!
My name is Hope Clark and we are the Lalibela Circus and Cultural School  in
Lalibela, Ethiopia, the home of a UNESCO Heritage site where more then 45000
tourists come every year to visit the 13th century rock-hewn 
churches. I am volunteering to create a self-sustaining, income generating show about 
Lalibela history, community and culture to be 
performed in the fine UNESCO
Cultural Center run by the Ministry of Culture and Tourism in the town of Lalibela. The
 intimate theater houses a stage and seats for 138 people.  The ongoing show will be performed by local adult Circus and Dance 
Association members working full time. Revenue from ticket sales will 
build 
sustainable income
for the Lalibela Circus and Cultural School and the community. Lalibela holds what some call the 8th wonder of the world, ancient 
architecture carved into the earth, instead of built upon it. We are creating business liaisons with 
the tourist industry to support this employment-creating project, while 
contributing to the community's rich ancient 
culture through modern voices.What We Need & What You Get
We need $14,954 to cover
the costs of fixing the sound system and automated movie screen in the 
UNESCO Cultural Center, a new set of mats, three traditional Ethiopian 
instruments, lights, microphones, sound equipment, traditional costumes 
and
a rehearsal fee of $25 a week for 14  performers. We are planning for a 
2-month
rehearsal schedule. This will enable us to create a
professional show that will be performed regularly for the visitors and 
tourists who come to see the remarkable churches. They will be 
transformed through an experience which exposes them to the 
cultural life, beauty and challenges of the community. Here is the budget breakdown.                                             Mats - $1930, Musical Instruments - $1684, Costumes - $1050, Lights - $1476, Sound equipment - $2467, Set - $1500, Cultural Space Work - $1200, Salaries for 14 performers - $2800,Transaction Fees - $847. Expenses will be prioritized. The show will go on even if full fundraising has not been met, it will just be pared-down.  
Once the show is created we could create a gross income of $345,000 a year. These funds will provide
a good salary for the performers, develop the Circus and Cultural School
as well as fulfill other educational needs of the community. Your contribution
to create this show will have a huge impact..

the project. 70% of the profit will go to the community and 30% will cover administrative costs.

story:
Hey there!

Sofia, Alex, Georgia, Antonette & Chloe here,
As students, we've watched how influential this lifestyle can be on sensitive people, and their mental health. But this extends far beyond student life, and into society as a whole, with the way mental illness is perceived. 
Our project - Feel Free - was born when we realised how many gaps there are in society's understanding and tolerance of those tormented by mental health conditions everyday. Did you know that 1 in 4 people will experience a mental health problem in a year? From anxiety to manic depression and bipolar disorder, these issues need to be addressed.
In 2014, a member of one of our families began suffering from a serious mental illness. The whole family watched the pain and solitude grow as so many stigmas and judgment attached to mental health came rushing at them. It was the mere lack of understanding, tolerance, and compassion, that broke our hearts for this family member. And this isn't the only case where something similar has occurred; currently, many of the issues surrounding mental health remain unspoken of and untaught to everyday members of society. By bringing more of them to light in an approachable and dynamic way, we feel as a team that it may help society to gain more understanding and patience, which will in turn help those suffering to feel more comfortable in their skin.
It is so important to us to make that happen.

About FeelFree

FeelFree isn't just a campaign for a cause. We intend to combine art, community and cause, in order to initiate some serious steps towards changing society's outlook on mental health. 

FeelFree is a Dance & lights performance, that will take place in mid April, one month before Mental Health Month. In order to make this happen, we need to raise enough money, to cover the operations and artist expenses (dancers, speakers, venue hire and marketing). 

We have already been sponsored by our University for some of the core funding, to cover our marketing and technical needs. However, we need your help to raise the rest so that we can reach the widest audience, and make a bigger change.

How Much We Need 

  • £ 300 for operational and artist costs
  • Any money unspent will go straight to charity (find out more about the charities we aim to raise money for here: http://www.mind.org.uk
and here: https://www.rethink.org

The Impact

Your help is so valuable to us. Our passion for mental health awareness has carried us this far already, and we just need that extra push to be able to manifest it and have the impact on society that we seek, even if that means only a small one.

Risks & Challenges

Like any event, we face a few risks and challenges; they involve working with artists, and venues. Any event takes team work and we need to ensure that these bodies stay stable and committed to our event without any last minute diversions.

However, as Event management students, we believe that in our three years of training we have acquired the skills and knowledge through contingency planning and other operations management aspects to be able to overcome such hurdles, and see our goals through no matter what.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't feel that you can help us with funding, please don't feel bad. It's okay to be targeted with which causes you choose to contribute to, as standing for a cause is not a decision to be taken lightly! 

However, if you wouldn't mind spreading the word about FeelFree, and helping us reach our goals, we would be forever grateful.

www.facebook.com/feelfreeproject

Thank you so much for taking the time to read this guys, we really do appreciate it.


Sofia, Alex, Georgia, Antonette & Chloe

story:
20 years Live from The Edge!

Hello Family, 

We are proud to say that we are still here, 20 years in.  The road has been rough but the stride continues on "the one", to the pulse and rhythm of our communities' beat; and the beat don't stop. We are about to step forward into some of the most ambitious art-making / theater shaking we've ever undertaken; but at the same time, we are committed to keeping our feet connected to our roots as we take off running.  We are ready, but we need your help. 

Live!

So, here's the deal.  In addition to UNIVERSES continuing to create new work as an ensemble, our individual UNIVERSES also prepare to launch into theater making and community organizing conversation (across The Nation and Puerto Rico), utilizing The UNIVERSES Aesthetic of poetic musical theater making, to launch the UNIVERSES' LIVINGRoom Project. With UNIVERSES members in New York City, Oregon, San Francisco, Detroit and Puerto Rico we are casting a wide net where diverse communities can come together to chronicle the stories of an era; open Labs/Salons and Mics in LIVINGrooms across the US and Puerto Rico, bringing our most personal rooms to life. 

When UNIVERSES began 20 years ago, we had very little access to space. We met, talked, rehearsed and made music in car's and vans (because they had the best acoustics), and in our own living rooms because there's no place like home, when talking about home. We grew up at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe, The Point and the Sunday Tea Party, on Steve Canon's "Stoop" and in people's living rooms, where the words sung and spoken were rough, rugged and raw; where the criticism was thrown at you from the second you stepped to the page or the mic, with love of course. We broke bread, share stories and built families. That's the UNIVERSES journey and we are grateful.  And while we have worked hard to finally have some  "access" in the American Theatre, we often still find ourselves without rehearsal rooms or artistic homes and it all comes into perspective and we remember our home training.  We love how resourceful we can be, because our community taught us to be like that.  

One of the LivingRooms we will never forget, was Kibibi Dillon's (may she rest in all her power).  Poets, Singers, MC's, Dancers, Actors, Children, Mommas and Poppas, all squeezing into her living room to hear each other think and come to life.  It was simple... you got the invite and you showed up, ready to live ... in a room ... with your peoples. Here's to Kibibi and to the many who taught us to walk through doors and hold them open; to step into rooms and find our place; to receive and to give. 

Please help us launch UNIVERSES' LivingRooms. Your contributions, will help with the following:

  • Support our UNIVERSES artists as they coordinate, identify, teach and cultivate artistic groups; 
  • Support community members who want to open up their homes (living rooms) for these small artistic gatherings; 
  • support light snacks and non-alcoholic beverages;
  • support documentation of the gatherings, 
  • and help offset the cost of insurance. 

What you get. 

  • You can get some UNIVERSES music, signed programs, tickets to shows, etc.;
  • You can get a tax write off;
  • But most importantly, you get to be a part of a movement. Part of an artistic National Conversation. A supporter of artistic voices at the grass roots level. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to financially contribute at the moment, you can still help us:

  • You can get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools! :D
  • Maybe, if there is a UNIVERSE near you, you can volunteer to help with a LivingRoom Project of even volunteer your own LivingRoom.  
Let's do it. <3


UNIVERSES Poetic Musical Theater Ensemble is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of UNIVERSES Poetic Musical Theater Ensemble must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Short Summary

The video above is not us -its an example of the kind of choreography/music we will be sharing.

Anyways.

Hello, my name is Dani and I'm the social  media rep. of a small all -fem dance crew. We are full time students and between the ages of 16-22 and unfortunately we don't have the money to pursue our dreams.

We really want this, and I hate to ask for help but we really need it. We are a family and we have big dreams for each other.

  

The Impact

We would like to gain a full experience for up coming competitions in December.

We are all begging you to help.

But even if you can't thank you for reading this and please send us your hopes and prayers.

Thank you. You are promoting our dreams.


Risks & Challenges

 we may lose the competition. But even if we lose we will gain so much more. We will get to experience with each other fun, family and working hard for a goal.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

     Even if you can't give money, please give us your thoughts and prayers and help spread us through social media!

story:
What is New Blue?       

       New Blue is a dance festival aiming to guide emerging dance artists into the Toronto dance community. We strive to unite generations of dance from secondary students, emerging artists, to established artists, connecting the dots and building a strong, vibrant dance community. New blue is a platform for dance artists to share their ideas, engage communities and push creative boundaries. By creating opportunities for young artists we can strengthen the Toronto dance community. Our hope is to have a variety of shows to give artists more artistic freedom to their creations.

The Team

       New Blue is a Toronto based company founded by the graduating Dance Performance Studies class of George Brown College of 2015. The team is composed of emerging dance artists in Toronto. Each artists brings their own passion and creative mind to New Blue to make it one of the leading dance festivals of Toronto.

New Blue’s core members are:

Peter Kelly - Festival Artistic Director

Jenna Schaefer - Festival Producer

Carolyn Morris - Festival General Manager

Shakeil Rollock - Festival Marketing Manager

Macey Culhane - Artistic Associate

Emily Bruno - Artistic Associate

Anneka Burghout - Festival Coordinator

We Need You!

       Our hopes are to inspire many individuals with our festival and to introduce new faces into the dance world. However, to connect to a large demographic we require your support to reach our financial goal. All donated funds will be allocated to festival venues, artist fees, staff, insurance, and other requires to produce a dance festival. We are young artists reaching out to other artists. With your support we can work together to launch the careers of emerging dancers and increase the longevity by creating opportunities for one another.

Support Us In Other Ways!

       Every dollar counts. However, we understand that money isn't always available but there are many other great ways to support these artists and the festival. We are happy to have volunteers join our team, in-kind donations are always helpful as well. Blog, share, subscribe and like our pages to spread the word. Every supportive effort will make a difference!

Like us on Facebook!

Subscribe to Youtube!

Follow us on Instagram!

Check out our Website!

story:
ME & MY GIRLFRIEND NEED TO TOUR THE WORLD! 

ME & MY GIRLFRIEND need to tour the world! Its storyline and the cast are incredible. Your contribution will get us on the road and on the stages of many well known theaters. 

Me & My Girlfriend is about CIARA TATE, who is a beautiful and smart Entertainment Lawyer. Her life was fine until she meets SEAN BOYD an intelligent intern with a passion for music. Ciara loved Sean's ambition. She invested a lot of her time, energy, and love with Sean to only have reality to slap her in the face.

After seven years of unwedded bliss and being just a “silent business partner”, Ciara takes a disliking to Sean’s egotistical and narcissistic ways after help building his major record company. On the eve of her birthday Sean’s arrogance became evident, when he makes an indecent proposal. Instead of asking Ciara to be his wife, Sean asks her to have his baby. Of course Ciara is totally against the idea, especially when she realizes Sean never had any intentions on marrying her in the first place. With this wakeup call, Ciara now wants to claim her life back as her own woman. When Ciara confronts Sean about his behavior towards her, she realizes that Sean doesn’t care how she feels. All that matters is her position as Sean Boyd’s personal assistant, whore, and silent partner. Adding salt to an injury, Sean wants Ciara to have his “son” whether she wants to or not. The pressures from Sean's personality leaves Ciara's individuality and independence desperately pleading for Sean to take notice.

“What is it, that I have to do Sean so you will start listening to me?”
Just when things seem like it could not get any worse with Sean, Ciara overhears him discussing his diabolical “pregnancy plan”. After hearing what Sean has done, Ciara decides it's game time. It’s time to take her life back into her own hands, starting with getting a pregnancy test and having a talk with Sean. Ciara arranges a meeting with Sean but he stands her up. Immediately Ciara comes home to find Sean, Mike, and crazy Duke watching a football game. Ciara is upset and outwardly asks Sean why did he stand her up. Subsequently Sean ignores her, so Ciara grabs the remote and shuts off the TV. She refuses to give back the remote until Sean agrees to go into their room to talk.  Sean grudgingly stomps into to the bedroom  and stipulates five minutes of his time. Ciara immediately let’s Sean know that she’s going back into practicing entertainment law. Of course Sean is against her gesture and Ciara asked him “What do I have to do, to get you to start listening to me?” Sean thinks for a moment and then says, “When you start wearing the pants, then I’ll start listening to you.” That’s when Ciara has a light bulb moment, she thanks Sean and leaves out the house. Ciara's attitude instantly changes with a whole new wardrobe to match.

Finally, Ciara finds out that Sean’s plan for her to carry his heir is coming true. Ciara’s plans to regain her independence and return back to entertainment law comes to a halt. Ciara has to act fast and pull it all together before Sean finds out she’s pregnant.


    ABOUT THE WRITER, DIRECTOR & PRODUCER

    Hello my name is Ngozi Thomas, I am 47 years old, a mother, erotic poet, author, playwright and director. 

    For the past 6 years, I have been taking care of my father who suffers with dementia, diabetes,  and a host of other ailments. Caring for my father is an around-the-clock job which caused me to be extremely withdrawn & depressed. Being a caregiver to your loved one is not easy and things get emotionally taxing. I kept up my strength to care for my father but I stopped taking care of myself. 

    In the beginning of 2014, I was cleaning out my office space (closet) and I came across one of my many "in-the works" scripts (Me & My Girlfriend) and I started crying "Why didn't I finish this, why did I allow so many years to pass without even attempting to finish it?" I called a friend of mine and just blurted out that I was going to finished this script and put it on stage.  Yes, of course I freaked out and started to withdraw from the idea. Then Bam! I woke up and started doing whatever was necessary to save money for the theatre's rental fee, plus insurance, plus security deposit, plus my arm, plus... (Just kidding) Now look how thankful and happy I was after leaving the theatre. 

    Unfortunately I had not finished the script, so I did what any writer with only fifteen pages of a script written would do... find a muse and have a discussion. Three days and 62 pages later... Presto a finished script and table read! 

    After the audition process and the long schedule rehearsals my dreams were now tangible. In August 2014, I was able to put my play on a stage for the first time in Philadelphia at the Adrienne Theatre. It was a creative success, so much so that Ariane Davis from Love & Hip Hop Atlanta came to see my play and she absolutely LOVED IT! She loved it so much that she will be playing the lead character (CIARA TATE) in the Atlanta performance. 


    After my success in Philadelphia my ambitions to travel with Me & My girlfriend on the road was motivated by the audience's positive feedback. The feeling of achieving my goals helped with my depression tremendously. Having my mother by my side during opening night was the greatest gift in the world. Unfortunately, exactly one week after the play was over, my mother suddenly died in her sleep. She was only 65 years old and that caused me to go back into my shell. 
    My stumbling blocks have now turned into my stepping stones and taking my play on tour would've made my mother proud. Two years later, my actions and stepping stones have lead me on the path to become a great director and playwright.


    What We Need & What You Get

    I am doing everything possible to raise as much money through my own hard work. However, this task is very exhausting due to taking care of my father and driving for Uber & Lyft just to assist with the production funding. I understand my dedication, sacrifices, and your generous contributions will allow me to meet the production goal of $54,947 for Me & My Girlfriend.


    While our production will feature a main lead, we are presenting an extraordinary cast with major credits to best deliver the play's material.  These actors are generously working for a minimal fee but they still need to be paid for their time and talent. We need to hire ten employed staff members to manage the production, marketing, promotions, and interactions with the press regarding Me & My Girlfriend shows.

    • The Venue (7 Stages Theatre) 
    • A fully Staffed Stage Crew
    • Lighting & Sound design
    • Furniture
    • Wardrobe
    • Hair & Make-up
    • Set Designer & Materials
    • Props
    • Playbills
    • Video & Photography
    • Marketing & Promotions
    • And most of all we NEED your contributions
    With your contribution we'll give our utmost gratitude. In recognition of your support certain "Perks" will be made available.  Our "Perks" consist of recognition on our highly trafficked website to VIP tickets to the opening night, as an option to say thank you for your support.  Please, donate today!  We deeply appreciate your help. 
    If we don't reach our entire financial goal, we'll just use the money that was raised from Indiegogo on tissues and comfort food  for an alternative way to ease our sorrow (Just Kidding).

    The Impact

    Using Theater as a medium, the constant silent struggle that many live with every day the play ME & MY GIRLFRIEND provides a voice.  Martin Luhter King has a quote that reads "Our lives begin to end the day we become silent about the things that really matters." Therefore, the story of ME & MY GIRLFRIEND won't stop until this message reaches as many people as possible. If individuals will take the time to learn more about the power of "YOUR" voice in various types of relationships, one will appreciate their self worth.


    Risks & Challenges

    With any venture there will be hurdles, for example typical daily distractions and obtaining the adequate amount of funding within the projected time frame. 

    The challenges caring for my father while working full time, building a website, making phones calls, writing, sending out emails, promoting via social media and being a producer on a few hours of sleep is an understatement. However, having friends and family to volunteer their time because they believe in my dream will help me to overcome these challenges.


    Other Ways You Can Help

    I know some of you may not be able to contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • So please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
    • We can always use a helping hand with stage set and cleaning crew during production
    • Donations of  props and furniture.  
    • And PLEASE share Indiegogo on your social media sites!
    Talk about us!  Learn about Me & My Girlfriend, and talk about the play and its message with your families and friends.  
    Please visit our website: www.ngozithomas.com
    To learn more about the play and watch some videos, and see just how incredibly powerful this story truly is.  We can't spread our message without your help. 


    And that's all there is to it.
story_txt:
ME & MY GIRLFRIEND NEED TO TOUR THE WORLD! 

ME & MY GIRLFRIEND need to tour the world! Its storyline and the cast are incredible. Your contribution will get us on the road and on the stages of many well known theaters. 

Me & My Girlfriend is about CIARA TATE, who is a
beautiful and smart Entertainment Lawyer. Her life was fine until she meets SEAN
BOYD an intelligent intern with a passion for music. Ciara loved Sean's ambition. She invested a lot of
her time, energy, and love with Sean to only have reality to slap her in the face.
After seven
years of unwedded bliss and being just a “silent business partner”, Ciara takes a disliking
to Sean’s egotistical and narcissistic ways after help building his major
record company. On the eve of her birthday Sean’s arrogance became evident, when he makes an indecent proposal. Instead
of asking Ciara to be his wife, Sean asks her to have his baby. Of course Ciara
is totally against the idea, especially when she realizes Sean never had any
intentions on marrying her in the first place. With this wakeup call, Ciara now
wants to claim her life back as her own woman. When Ciara confronts Sean about
his behavior towards her, she realizes that Sean doesn’t care how she feels. All
that matters is her position as Sean Boyd’s personal assistant, whore, and silent partner. Adding
salt to an injury, Sean wants Ciara to have his “son” whether she wants to or
not. The pressures from Sean's personality leaves Ciara's individuality and independence desperately
pleading for Sean to take notice. 






“What is it, that
    I have to do Sean so you will start listening to me?”





  
 
Just when
things seem like it could not get any worse with Sean, Ciara overhears him
discussing his diabolical “pregnancy plan”. After hearing what Sean has done, Ciara decides it's game
time. It’s time to take her life back into her own hands, starting with getting
a pregnancy test and having a talk with Sean. Ciara arranges a meeting with Sean but he stands her up. Immediately
Ciara comes home to find Sean, Mike, and crazy Duke watching a football game.
Ciara is upset and outwardly asks Sean why did he stand her up. Subsequently Sean
ignores her, so Ciara grabs the remote and shuts off the TV. She refuses to give
back the remote until Sean agrees to go into their room to talk.  Sean grudgingly stomps into to the bedroom  and stipulates five minutes of his time. Ciara immediately let’s
Sean know that she’s going back into practicing entertainment law. Of course
Sean is against her gesture and Ciara asked him “What do I have to do, to get
you to start listening to me?” Sean thinks for a moment and then says, “When
you start wearing the pants, then I’ll start listening to you.” That’s when
Ciara has a light bulb moment, she thanks Sean and leaves out the house. Ciara's attitude instantly changes with a whole new wardrobe to match.



Finally, Ciara
finds out that Sean’s plan for her to carry his heir is coming true. Ciara’s plans to
regain her independence and return back to entertainment law comes
to a halt. Ciara has to act fast and pull it all together before Sean finds out she’s pregnant.





ABOUT THE WRITER, DIRECTOR & PRODUCER
Hello my name is Ngozi Thomas, I am 47 years old, a mother, erotic poet, author, playwright and director. 
For the past 6 years, I have been taking care of my father who suffers with dementia, diabetes,  and a host of other ailments. Caring for my father is an around-the-clock job which caused me to be extremely withdrawn & depressed. Being a caregiver to your loved one is not easy and things get emotionally taxing. I kept up my strength to care for my father but I stopped taking care of myself. 
In the beginning of 2014, I was cleaning out my office space (closet) and I came across one of my many "in-the works" scripts (Me & My Girlfriend) and I started crying "Why didn't I finish this, why did I allow so many years to pass without even attempting to finish it?" I called a friend of mine and just blurted out that I was going to finished this script and put it on stage.  Yes, of course I freaked out and started to withdraw from the idea. Then Bam! I woke up and started doing whatever was necessary to save money for the theatre's rental fee, plus insurance, plus security deposit, plus my arm, plus... (Just kidding) Now look how thankful and happy I was after leaving the theatre. 

Unfortunately I had not finished the script, so I did what any writer with only fifteen pages of a script written would do... find a muse and have a discussion. Three days and 62 pages later... Presto a finished script and table read! 


After the audition process and the long schedule rehearsals my dreams were now tangible. In August 2014, I was able to put my play on a stage for the first time in Philadelphia at the Adrienne Theatre. It was a creative success, so much so that Ariane Davis from Love & Hip Hop Atlanta came to see my play and she absolutely LOVED IT! She loved it so much that she will be playing the lead character (CIARA TATE) in the Atlanta performance. 



After my success in Philadelphia my ambitions to travel with Me & My girlfriend on the road was motivated by the audience's positive feedback. The feeling of achieving my goals helped with my depression tremendously. Having my mother by my side during opening night was the greatest gift in the world. Unfortunately, exactly one week after the play was over, my mother suddenly died in her sleep. She was only 65 years old and that caused me to go back into my shell. 

My stumbling blocks have now turned into my stepping stones and taking my play on tour would've made my mother proud. Two years later, my actions and stepping stones have lead me on the path to become a great director and playwright.
  
What We Need & What You Get I am doing everything possible to raise as much money through my own hard work. However, this task is very exhausting due to taking care of my father and driving for Uber & Lyft just to assist with the production funding. I understand my dedication, sacrifices, and your generous contributions will allow me to meet the production goal of $54,947 for Me & My Girlfriend.

While our production will feature a main lead, we are presenting an extraordinary cast with major credits to best deliver the play's material.  These actors are generously working for a minimal fee but they still need to be paid for their time and talent. We need to hire ten employed staff members to manage the production, marketing, promotions, and interactions with the press regarding Me & My Girlfriend shows.
 The Venue (7 Stages Theatre) 
A fully Staffed Stage Crew
Lighting & Sound design
Furniture
Wardrobe
Hair & Make-up
Set Designer & Materials
Props
Playbills
Video & Photography
Marketing & Promotions
And most of all we NEED your contributions


 
With your contribution we'll give our utmost gratitude. In recognition of your support certain "Perks" will be made available.  Our "Perks" consist of recognition on our highly trafficked website to VIP tickets to the opening night, as an option to say thank you for your support.  Please, donate today!  We deeply appreciate your help. 


If we don't reach our entire financial goal, we'll just use the money that was raised from Indiegogo on tissues and comfort food  for an alternative way to ease our sorrow (Just Kidding).





The Impact
Using Theater as a medium, the constant silent struggle that many live with every day the play ME & MY GIRLFRIEND provides a voice.  Martin Luhter King has a quote that reads "Our lives begin to end the day we become silent about the things that really matters." Therefore, the story of ME & MY GIRLFRIEND won't stop until this message reaches as many people as possible. If individuals will take the time to learn more about the power of "YOUR" voice in various types of relationships, one will appreciate their self worth.




Risks & Challenges With any venture there will be hurdles, for example typical daily distractions and obtaining the adequate amount of funding within the projected time frame. 
The challenges caring for my father while working full time, building a website, making phones calls, writing, sending out emails, promoting via social media and being a producer on a few hours of sleep is an understatement. However, having friends and family to volunteer their time because they believe in my dream will help me to overcome these challenges.
   Other Ways You Can Help I know some of you may not be able to contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help:  So please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
We can always use a helping hand with stage set and cleaning crew during production
Donations of  props and furniture.   And PLEASE share Indiegogo on your social media sites! 

Talk about us!  Learn about Me & My Girlfriend, and talk about the play and its message with your families and friends.  Please visit our website: www.ngozithomas.com
To learn more about the play and watch some videos, and see just how incredibly powerful this story truly is.  We can't spread our message without your help. 
And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

INTRODUCTION & BACKGROUND 
My name is Sebastian Karlsson, 33 years old, and living in Sweden. My father told me that when I was 5 years old I was out playing in the garden, suddenly turning to him and saying: "Dad, I want to become an actor when I grow up." I did become an actor. Theatre became a great passion of mine, in the community, in school, and at home. For many years it was my identity. Until God changed my priorities.  

In the years of 2006-07, I was studying acting at Blekinge Läns Folkhögskola (acting conservatory in Sweden). As my studies neared completion, a worry of what would happen next started to arise. My prayer was to continue studying theatre at one of Sweden´s four national acting schools. As I was walking on campus, suddenly, the Holy Spirit prompted me to go to the computer lab and search for "Christian theatre schools in the United States." I did, and found Abilene Christian University (ACU) in Texas, U.S. 

The joy I felt inside when the website of ACU came up was incredible! It was like the theatre program at ACU was tailored just for me. It was just what I had been longing and praying for! 

I applied and was accepted to the acting program at Abilene Christian University. (2007-2011 - B.F.A in acting.) Those years changed my life! My faith bloomed out, and Jesus became so real to me after having encountered Him in a powerful way. 

During one special week at ACU God spoke to me about my identity. It was a week of transformation. My identity shifted from "being the actor," and from putting my value in what I did on stage to being a child of God. 

THE CAMPAIGN 

Two years ago, I felt a prompting to make John´s gospel into a one hour long stage performance. What if theatre could help to spread the message about Jesus? My vision was to produce a high quality show that broke new grounds, touching people through the performing arts. The process of producing this show has truly been amazing. The people involved in completing the show were all non-believers, they were all inspired by it, and touched by it. 

The show was named The Gospel of John  and opened on March the 28th 2014. After the curtain call, my neighbor came up to me in tears. The show had touched her and many others in a wonderful way. The show was performed six times. 

Now, my wish is to revive the show and take it to new audiences across Sweden, and also abroad. I believe that it is a powerful tool to spread the message about Jesus, using theatre in a new and creative way. This show explores theatre and faith, stage acting and film acting, and dramatic effects through lights and sound. The show is a multimedia production, incorporating film, stage acting, and sound & lights in an innovative and appealing mix, as some parts are prerecorded film clips interacting with live stage performance. All the roles are done by one actor. 

It would be much harder to revive and tour with this show without the help and support of contributors. The funds raised would give me a solid base to stand on for this project, and they would greatly help to produce and tour the show. Thank you so much for considering supporting this project! 

What We Need & What You Get

  • The funds needed to revive the show and to take it on tour is: $18.600
  • My long-term financial goal for the show is to make it support itself. 
  • The budget is as follows: 

Sound & Light equipment for the show: $5.900                                                            Projector & Projector Screen: $2.000                                                                               Salaries (actor & director): $9.400                                                                                           Software: $700                                                                                                                                   Unexpected expenses: $600  

If the campaign does not reach the entire goal for the fundraiser, the funds raised will go towards sound & light equipment for the show. This is to make it easier to tour with the show at any given time, without having to be dependent on renting the equipment needed.  

Perks

The campaign offers a number of exciting perks. Here are some!
  • Get a personal thank you note from the actor. 
  • Get a digital download of the show.
  • Receive a DVD of the show + your name in the credits. 
  • 20 min Skype session with the actor. 
  • Support the show and get a free weekend (Fri-Sunday) at Röda Huset café, shop, and hostel in Sweden. (Transportation to Röda Huset, such as airfare, is not provided in this perk).   

The Impact

I believe this show can speak to both believers and non-believers in a powerful way. Many times, people who do not have a Christian background hesitate to enter a church building. They might feel uncomfortable to do so. This show has the potential to bring the message of Jesus to people outside the church, to schools, to corporations, to hospitals, to town halls, and other public places. 
When the Gospel of John opened in 2014, it played in a small town hall, seating about 60 people. Having the show in that type of building opened up for new audiences. One performance was also given in a theatre space, and had about 40 people in it, of which only one was a Christian. The others were professional and semi-professional theatre people from the region. The response on the show has been very positive! 

Risks & Challenges

The show does come with challenges. Sometimes, when promoting something new to churches, it can be met with suspicion. This has been, and might be a future challenge in promoting this show towards congregations. Pastors may ask, "Is this credible?" "Can we trust him?" and so forth. 
When performing in more public venues, there is always a risk of not getting an audience. They might think that because it is the gospel of john then that is nothing for them. The audience can sometimes have a preconceived idea of what the show must be like, based on previous experiences with Christianity. 
However, I believe all this can be overcome. By touring with the show, and marketing it in a good, non threatening way, it may open up for new audiences. 
Also, by inviting church leaders to a preview of the show they can see what it is about, before taking it to their church venue. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for considering supporting the project. I am very grateful for any support. Here are some other ways that you can help if you feel unable to support the project financially: 
  • Please consider to join in prayer for the project. I believe that prayer is very important when breaking new grounds. 
  • Helping by getting the word out about the campaign and the project. The more people who would like to help the better. 
  • Share about the project on social medias, do not forget to use the Indiegogo share tools. 
Thank you so much for all your help and support, it means a lot! 
/Sebastian Karlsson

story:
Ursa Major is based on the true story of the Sisters Dart’s grandparents, who were involved in a tragic car accident on Highway 2 in Alberta, Canada. 

The accident left their grandfather, Jim, in a coma, from which he awoke severely brain injured. Their grandmother, Lynn, walked away from the accident with comparatively minor injuries. When faced with the decision to either let Jim go, or become his full time caregiver, Lynn told the doctors: “he has cared for me my entire life, I must care for him now.”

Ursa Major is an inspired story of love, devotion, and the strange world that exists between consciousness and unconsciousness. Part fairytale, part heartbreaking romance, Ursa Major combines original compositions and contemporary choreography in an immersive world that invites audience into an unimaginable story about completely imaginable people.

Funds raised during this campaign will go directly toward the production of Ursa Major. 

Your donations will help pay for: 

- artists fees. We have an incredible team of extremely gifted theatre professionals pouring their heart, soul, sweat, tears and blood into the success of this project. We want to pay them what they're worth! Our team is: Cliff Kelly (Actor); Paula Humby (Actor); Ainsley Hillyard (Choreographer); Leif Ingebrigtsen (Composer/Musician); Matt Schuurman (Set & Video Designer); Cheyenne Sykes (Costume & Lighting Designer); Trent Crosby (Production Manager); and Kerry Johnson (Stage Manager). 

- set materials and labour. However magical it may look when we're done, our set requires much more than magic to become a reality. We require a little extra help to pay for materials (wood, nails, paint, rebar, sash cord, twinkle lights and more!) and the skilled labour necessary to bring our vision to life. 

- costumes. Our costume designer is incredible at working within a budget, but she needs a budget to start! Funds raised will go toward creating original costumes from found articles for two actors.

- marketing materials. We've built a show - now we need people to see it! Funds raised will go toward the creation and printing of posters, handbills, programs, outreach efforts, and more. 

We have been creating original theatre in Edmonton for nine years. This is the first time we've asked for help producing our work. We believe in this project. We believe this is an important story worth telling. We believe audiences will fall in love with this story and its characters in an unforgettable way. We believe this project will not only propel our careers as creators forward, but will also help us take our first steps as a touring company outside of Edmonton. 

Ursa Major by Megan Dart is being produced by Workshop West Playwrights' Theatre as part of its 2015/16 season. All donations made to this campaign will go to Workshop West Playwrights' Theatre in support of the production of Ursa Major. Workshop West Playwrights' Theatre is a charitable organization (#119304392RR0001). Charitable tax receipts will be issued for all donations over $10. Thank you for your support!

Risks & Challenges

There are always challenges in creating new theatre. Sometimes, plans don't pan out exactly the way we thought, or we run into limitations, be those of the venue, time, or production value. As theatre artists, this demand for flexibility pushes us to become even greater creators. We embrace those challenges as opportunity to do and be better.

Please help us spread the word! Share this campaign on Facebook and Twitter!

story:
RADD Fest 2016

Produced by RADD Theatre Co.

What's Happening?

RADD Fest is a two week festival in New York City, showcasing a dozen intimate companies and independent artists. We’ve gathered street performers, slam poetry epics, a one act that takes place entirely within a box, and so much more. Each night is something fresh, a new story ready to be shared. Your tax deductible donation will make it all possible!

When/Where

April 19th to May 1st

The Sargent Theater @ The American Theatre of Actors

314 W 54th Street

New York, NY 10019

Buy My Ticket!

Why Donate?

Live performance is complicated and expensive to create alone. Lights, sets, props, stage managers, marketing, scheduling, contracts, and rehearsal space - the sheer logistics of producing independently in NYC can be paralyzing.

RADD Fest is all about supporting new, innovative work by taking care of the details. We’ll design a flexible set, bring in a brilliant stage manager, and help each company advertise their show. We want to make it easy for them to do the hard, nurturing work of creating theater.

Your tax deductible donation will go directly to making that possible. The money raised will plug in projectors, hang lights, and buy insurance. Your contribution will allow artists to walk into a rent-free space, meet other like-minded thinkers, and get paid for their work.

RADD Theatre Co.

We are a 501(c)3 company fiscally sponsored through Fractured Atlas. All donations are tax deductible. Learn more about us on our website!

www.raddtheatreco.com

Where Does the Money Go?

$8,000 Fundraising Goal

  • 50% Space: Half the cost of the theater rental, the light package, and the sound equipment.
  • 25% Personnel: Compensation for designers, stage-manager and front of house staff to to run the festival.
  • 25% Supplies/Publicity: Posters, programs, and set materials.

After we cover the theatre rental, all ticket sales will go straight back to the artists involved. Woo!

If you’re interested in a more detailed breakdown feel free to reach out and we are happy to send you our working budget.

Who Am I Supporting?

[Alphabetical Order]

The Box Show by Dominique Salerno 

www.facebook.com/boxshowtime/

A one woman show with sketch-style characters, musical numbers, and fully improvised segments, The Box Show constantly flips perspectives and takes its audience on an imaginative exploration without ever leaving the cubic dimensions.

Diverging Elements: Heroines in History

www.divergingelements.org

Heroines in History features the stories of Anne Frank, Rosa Parks, and Inez Milholland as they come to life through movement and music.

Hook & Eye Theater: SHE/SHE/SHE 

www.hookandeyetheater.com

SHE/SHE/SHE is piece about the National Parks of the past and present and contains spontaneous interviews of audience members about their experiences.

Joust Theatre Company: The Monthly Joust

www.jousttheatre.org

An evening of quick science fiction plays that explore how rapidly developing of technology is affecting the world around us.

Lust & Liberty: Water

www.lustandliberty.org

Water is a staged myth that meditates on water as a symbol of change, growth, and our natural interconnectedness.

Move Inc. & Syracuse University Drama: Gemini Vanishing

www.vpa.syr.edu/academics/drama

Gemini Vanishing is a devised hybrid-performance that weaves movement, text and original music together as parallel stories unfold: the story of an astronomer and her bipolar daughter and the myth of the Gemini twins.

The Oneness Project

www.keelaygipson.com

An evening of creative responses to injustice, featuring slam poetry, monologues, short film, and music.

My Straighties by Ryan Haddad

www.ryanjhaddad.com

Set against the backdrop of Ryan's college fraternity experience, this piece is an exploration of the relationships between straight and gay men, the closeness that can develop when there is no expectation of physical intimacy, and the challenges that arise when friendships become more fulfilling than romance.

RADD Comedy Night, Hosted by Jesse Roth

www.jesse-roth.com

A smorgasbord of improv, stand-up and sketch comedy hosted by the luminous Jesse Roth. Stand-Ups: Matt Gehring, Drew Brandon Jones, Jordan Myrick, Dylan Palladino, Adrienne Pluta & Tessa Skara. Improv: Porm, New Greta & Matt’s Emotions.

RADD Film Night, featuring Unworld & Other Films

An intimate night of independant films with drinks, snacks, and bean bag chairs! Featuring Unworld (previously titled Girlwatcher) by Max Mueller, produced this summer by RADD Theatre Co.

Playright's Playground, Workshop Series

Come take part in the reading of new plays where audience feedback is a part of the process. The following plays will receive time, space and resources to reshape, rework and re-imagine:

  • Grief by Danny Coates-Finke

  • Orphans & Outsiders by Andrew Garrett

  • An untitled play by Kevin Slack

--------------

Thank you for your support! We’ve got a talented and passionate group of artists ready to work, and we can’t wait to get started!


Come Play! | #playradd

story:
Take a glimpse underneath the Big Top with this a capella musical circus sideshow! In the dusty desert, Myrtle Corbin, the Four-Legged curiosity, meets her match. Can this veteran performer make a life outside the tent?

Set during the Victorian era in the American West, this true story explores themes of self-worth, performance, and trusting in true love. We watch as a one-of-a-kind woman takes a leap of faith and grapples with the uncertainty of starting a new life.

AN EXCERPT FROM THE SCORE

The a capella score uses only voices and the human body to create full soundscapes and advanced harmonies.


 

WHAT IS THE FRINGE NYC FESTIVAL?

The New York International Fringe Festival (FringeNYC) is the largest multi-arts festival in North America.  This year is the 20th annual festival and our show was selected out of a competitive pool of applicants.  From August 12–28, there will be 5 performances in the Flamboyán Theater at the The Clemente Center in the Lower East Side. FringeNYC has been the launching pad for numerous Off-Broadway and Broadway transfers, long-running downtown hits, and regional theater productions. FringeNYC alumni include Bradley Cooper, Morgan Spurlock (Supersize Me, CNN’s Inside Man), Mindy Kaling, Tony Award winner Diane Paulus (Pippin), Michael Urie (Ugly Betty), and Naomi Grossman (American Horror Story), and countless other success stories.

This festival presents some of the world’s best emerging theatre troupes and we are honored to be included.

 

WHERE IS YOUR MONEY GOING?

Costumes! (Victorian Costumes!)  & Set!  Fringe is a forum to see, be seen and network. It's an opportunity to reach a wider audience, and we must be ready to impress.  Costuming is a large part of each character and when you look good, you feel good...and when you feel good you can create an amazing performance.  All of our props and set pieces are key to the story and your donations will go towards the very items that will be on stage!

Water & Food!  We gotta keep these hardworking thespians alive and well in rehearsals!

Printing & Promotion! From scripts, to promotional posters & fliers, to the programs we hand out at performances, printing is a large cost that is required of any production.   

Insurance and Flame-Proofing! The festival requires all set and props to be CERTIFIED flame-proof. Our set includes fabric and wood materials which all need to be professionally treated and  tested. 

Check out this pie chart to see exactly where every dollar of the campaign ends up. Any money we make over our goal goes to a fund for future Ex Fall productions and grants.

THE TEAM

Lily Ali-Oshatz - Book-writer, Lyricist, and Co-Composer

Lily Ali-Oshatz is a Brookyln-based writer and performer. She is a member of the 1st graduating class of The New Studio on Broadway for Musical Theatre at Tisch, NYU, where she also studied in the Experimental Theatre Wing. Lily found a home as both a writer and an actor as a member of the Musical Theatre Factory. "Extraordinary Fall" was presented last winter by the New York FRIGID Festival and received a showcase as part of Musical Theatre Factory's 4x15 program. She is currently working on a feminist puppetry project with Kelley Selznick and continuing to write a solo piece based on her experience with the New York City justice system. Lily hopes to ignite compassionate awareness through art and storytelling.

Mark Galinovsky - Music Director, Co-Composer, Producer

Mark Galinovsky is a resident music director for Piper Theatre and the Westchester Sandbox Theatre, as well as a voice teacher/music director at Performers Theatre Workshop in Maplewood, NJ. His recent musical directing credits include A Little Night Music (NYU Players Club), The Extraordinary Fall of the Four-Legged Woman (Frigid Festival), Footloose! (College of Mount Saint Vincent), Sweeney Todd (Piper Theatre), and Little Shop of Horrors (Westcoast Black Theatre Troupe). Other organizations he has worked with include Broadway Youth Ensemble, Davenport Theatrical, Fringe, NYMF, The Secret Theatre, and Untitled Theatre #61. Mark is a proud graduate of NYU Steinhardt (BM ’13).

Madeline Wall - Director

Madeline Wall is a Seattle-born, New York City based director, filmmaker, and  designer. She received her BFA in Film from NYU's Tisch School of the Arts. Since moving to New York, she has worked for ABC, NBC, Showtime, Parkwood Entertainment, 11th St. Workshop,  and on numerous independent music videos, commercials, and films. Her work as a designer has been featured in festivals around the world. The short film, Girl in the Chair, which she designed and produced was a Student Academy Award nominee. She recently won three Craft Awards at The First Run Film Festival for her work as a designer and editor. Before she worked in film, Madeline was involved in devised theatre and acting. “Extraordinary Fall” offers an opportunity for her to return to stage-work and musicals.

Nick Probst - Stage Manager

Nick Probst is a Wichita, KS native making his way in the big city and the smaller city near it, as he now calls Jersey City, NJ home. He has worked as a director, stage manager, actor, writer, and many other roles in Kansas, NYC, Brooklyn, Hoboken, and Jersey City, and has been having a fantastic time helping with an original work for the first time with FringeNYC. Nick is currently studying comedy with Upright Citizens Brigade, has several tattoos, and can ride his bike real fast.

Kelley Selznick - Puppetry Designer and Director

Kelley Selznick is a New York based puppeteer, designer, director and builder. She just was a puppet wrangler for the NYMF production of Ludo's Broken Bride. Favourite design credits include Kid Kristy and the Candy Touch and Firebird  for LaMama Kids. Previous shows include puppeteering and wrangling for Jim Henson’s Dinosaur Train Live and Erth Dinosaur Zoo Live's National Tours. You can see more of her work at www.kelleyselznick.com

Kyle Johnson - Publicist

Kyle James Johnson is an actor/director/collaborator hailing from the mythical land of Reno, NV.  He got his start in plays and musicals back home, worked his way up into casino shows and helping produce musicals in Nevada, and has become involved in the administration side of the theatre world here in little old NYC.  Kyle loves collaborating on new works, is currently helping fundraise for the Walk to End Alzheimer's Manhattan, and really likes Thai food.

A NOTE FROM THE DIRECTOR

First of all, thank you for visiting our page! Any support we get, whether it's a donation, passing along info about the show, or just taking the time to read about it, is so encouraging and it overwhelms me with gratitude.

I've been working on this show for a number of years now, and this script is such a privilege to work on. I have so much love for these characters. I find personal catharsis in every single one of their stories. Every time we run the show or read through the script, my understanding of the story grows in complexity and in love. I can so clearly see the world we have created together- this technicolor fairytale in the desert, where true love "just happens," and good prevails.  On top of that, the music (too often) brings me to tears, and every time I see the cast in costume I get butterflies. I feel so blessed and privileged to be working on this piece. This is exactly where I want to be.

It's hard to ask for anything. Especially money.  I wish making theatre was cheaper. I will continue working to find ways to barter, budget, and cut costs. But for the costs we cannot avoid, we need your help! It takes a village. If you're able to contribute, please do! In return, I will continue to work as hard as I can to put on this beautiful show.

Thank you, so much, from the bottom of my heart!
-Maddie

story:
Short Summary

Festival51 is a Rhode Island-based women's playwriting festival designed to create exposure and work for female writers and theater artists. We have received 406 scripts for 2016 (up from only 26 in 2015) and are currently selecting four finalists to be chosen for full production.  All plays will be fully staged and produced at 95 Empire Street (AS220) in Providence, RI July 15-24 as well as staged readings and a single production at Contemporary Theater Company in Wakefield, RI.

Festival51 Website

Funding is necessary for Festival51 to meet it's main goal: provide female writers and theater artists paid exposure in their selected craft. Proceeds from this fundraiser will go directly to the artists involved - Festival51 is not a for-profit venture, but a showcase and an opportunity for female artists to see their work staged and produced.

What We Need & What You Get

While we are also seeking alternative funding sources such as grants and direct donations via our website, your contribution here will enable us to meet the goal of providing paying jobs for women writers and directors and give voice to an underrepresented element of Rhode Island and Southern New England Theater.

  • With four plays being selected for full production, your contribution will help provide funding for four playwrights and four directors as well as the designers required to fully produce these shows. For example: $25 buys us an hour of audition space needed to cast all four plays; $50 supports an Assistant Stage Manager; $100 supports a Director; $200 pays a winning playwright. This campaign is just a small fraction of our overall costs, but every little bit will help in a meaningful way. 
  • Be a part of elevating the discussion about equality in the arts.
  • Even if we don't meet our full goal, the money raised will still be divided equally among the artists and provide some level of pay for their artistic efforts.
  • You will be listed as a Donor to the Festival and, depending on your donation level, receive other perks and benefits related to the event itself, including private events and performances.

The Impact

Women's voices in the Arts and Theater, in particular, are still struggling to be heard in a field where male playwrights and directors still have dominance. Festival51 has been designed to help levelset that discrepancy and, in our second year, we are poised to become an annual event in Rhode Island.

The organizers of Festival51, in conjunction with AS220 (as220.org) and Contemporary Theater Company (contemporarytheatercompany.com) have a collective wealth of experience and talent making them uniquely qualified to successfully mount such an endeavor. Organizers Leann Heath and Terry Shea have been practicing Theater artists for decades, as actors, directors, designers, producers, organizers, marketers and developmental curators. An array of experienced theater artists are involved in reading and selecting scripts.

The talent is in place, scripts have been submitted from all over New England and finalists are being selected. Your contribution will ensure that the women who produce these final works will have a chance to succeed in their field and have their voices heard in a crowded, often male-dominated landscape.

Risks & Challenges

We are aware that many Arts organizations are seeking help and donations in order to survive in a crowded field. Festival51 does not have the kind of name exposure that other, established Arts entities in Rhode Island may have, but we believe that with the right outreach, we can overcome that challenge. Our presence in social media (Festival51 Facebook Page, @rifestival51 on Twitter ) has already garnered substantial attention and we await a potential RISCA grant. That grant will not be enough to meet projected expenses, however, and producing plays creates financial need beyond being able to pay writers and artists. We believe that with your aid, we can meet our production costs and still be able to provide a modest stipend to those women contributing to Festival51's success.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if your contribution is small (or you cannot contribute at all) please help us by passing the word about Festival51 to anyone you know. People can visit us at www.festival51.org or our Facebook page at www.facebook.com/rifestival51.

We can answer any and all questions at rifestival51@gmail.com or (401) 285-0351.
Thank you for your help in making Festival51 a reality and a success!

 in order to survive in a crowded field. Festival51 does not have the 
kind of name exposure that other, established Arts entities in Rhode 
Island may have, but we believe that with the right outreach, we can 
overcome that challenge. Our presence in social media (Festival51 Facebook Page, @rifestival51 on Twitter )
 has already garnered substantial attention and we await a potential 
RISCA grant. That grant will not be enough to meet projected expenses, 
however, and producing plays creates financial need beyond being able to
 pay writers and artists. We believe that with your aid, we can meet our
 production costs and still be able to provide a modest stipend to those
 women contributing to Festival51's success.
  Other Ways You Can Help 
Even if your contribution is small (or you cannot contribute at 
all) please help us by passing the word about Festival51 to anyone you 
know. People can visit us at www.festival51.org or our Facebook page at www.facebook.com/rifestival51. We can answer any and all questions at rifestival51@gmail.com or (401) 285-0351.
 Thank you for your help in making Festival51 a reality and a success!

story:
"The 614th Commandment" 

Performing on June 2nd, 2016 at 8pm as part of the Expat Expo | Immigrant Invasion Festival at English Theatre Berlin | International Performing Arts Center

      The 614th Commandment is a darkly funny play in which two actors embodying multiple characters examine both the role of Holocaust history in contemporary Jewish identity and American- Jewish perspectives regarding Germany in the 21st century, all through a critical, absurdist lens.

      It is based on over 100 interviews conducted with Jewish people of a variety of backgrounds in Los Angeles, California, and was inspired by the writer’s experiences as an American Jewish woman living in Berlin.

    What We Need & What You Get

    English Theatre Berlin is providing us with 1000 euro (!!!). We'd like to raise another 2000. Here's where all that money is going:

    • The artists! We've assembled a wonderful team to bring this piece to the stage - two actors (Kellen York and Carrie Getman), a director (Adam Donald), and a writer/producer (Alissa Rubinstein). Alissa has been developing the play for over two years, Alissa and Adam have been working together since January, and Kellen and Carrie joined the team in early April. Currently the actors will each receive 300 euro for their time, the director will receive 600 euro and the writer/producer gets nothing because she's organizing the whole thing ;) These people are incredibly talented theater professionals who are dedicating a lot of time and energy to "The 614th Commandment," and Alissa would love to pay them an additional 100-200 euro each, if possible. 
    • Rehearsal space! We rehearse approximately 10-15 hours/week (10 in April, 15 in May, depending on peoples' schedules), and pay 3-5 euro/hour for the room (depends on which rooms are available at Theaterhaus Berlin-Mitte). For the cost of a latte you could fund an hour of rehearsal time for us!
    • Transcription costs! This is a documentary play based on interviews. 7 euro buys us 1 hour of transcription services! We'll spend no more than 300 euro on this. 
    • Filming! The goal is to make a DVD and/or high quality digital video file that includes the final performance, bits of rehearsal, interviews and other fun behind-the-scenes moments that will be given as a gift to contributors. Stay tuned for price quotes. 
    • And if we don't make it to 2000 euro...that's fine! Even the smallest contribution helps. Got 3 euro/~$3.50 USD lying around that you want to throw our way? You've just bought us an hour of rehearsal space! 
    • The minimum we need to put on the show is 1500 euro - that covers the minimum for the actors and director and hopefully most of the rehearsal space hours. If we only have 1500 euro to play with, Alissa has to eat the costs for the rest of the rehearsal space, transcription, filming and any unforeseen expenses. Ideal? No! Totally doable? Yes! No matter how much money we raise/don't raise, the show is HAPPENING.

    The Impact

    This is a funny show. Seriously. 

    • Many of you have probably wondered about the sorts of things "The 614th Commandment" addresses - what's going on in Germany right now? Why would an American Jewish millennial choose to live there? What do American Jews think about Germany today, anyway? What do Germans think of American Jews? And what are we all doing with this Holocausty history that ties us all together? 
    • "The 614th Commandment" is based off of more than 100 interviews that touch on these topics, but this is not your typical sentimental Holocaust story. It's silly, and dark, and absurd, and haunting, and thought-provoking, and hilarious. 
    • We currently only have one official performance scheduled - June 2nd at ETB - but we're hopeful that this is just the first incarnation of "The 614th Commandment" that will appear on a Berlin stage - and we also have growing interest from producers in Los Angeles and Jerusalem! 

    Risks & Challenges

    Documentary theater is hard. We know that. 

    • We've got hundreds of hours of interviews, and two months to distill them down into 60 fast-paced minutes of exciting theater. 
    • The director and both actors are dedicated theater professionals with years of experience, particularly in devised theater, the practice of developing a theatrical performance as a creative team without a finished script as a jumping off point. All three have degrees in theater. The writer/producer, in addition to her degree in theater, has also been immersed in this topic for over 10 years. 
    • We can do it! With laser focus, passion, creativity, talent and your support, we can put on an amazing show on June 2nd - and beyond. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Can't contribute cash? That's cool! Help us in other ways!

    • Spread the word about the show! Utilize your social media skillz! 

    And guys...THANK YOU. We're so excited about this!

story:
The Party Line Presents:

We Know Edie La Minx Had a Gun

May 12-14, 8pm - Standard Toykraft, Brooklyn  

We know Edie La Minx had a gun. 

We know a mummified body was found in her apartment. We know this body had a gunshot wound to the head. 

We Know Edie La Minx Had a Gun is a new work that dives into the sensationalism surrounding the life and death of a fabulous drag queen.

Edie La Minx first took the runway as part of the 46th season at the Yale Cabaret —the artistic home for Yale School of Drama students. The co-writers, Helen Jaksch, Kelly Kerwin and Emily Zemba, have collaborated on a new draft full of musical performances, dance floor pageantry, and high-kicking, shade-throwing, larger-than-life queens.

Edie La Minx will happen over three nights (May 12-14) at Standard Toykraft, a former textile factory-turned theater on the third floor of an unmarked building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

We Need Your Support

Shimmy into your support hose and help us lift up Edie La Minx. We need one more push to bring Edie to New York. Your contributions will go directly to getting this project off the ground. 

Donations will go to paying our actors, designers, and technical directors the wages they deserve. They will go to our rental fee at Standard Toykraft, and to the costumes, makeup, and lighting that these queens need to shine.

We know that giving a few bucks is no small thing. This city is expensive and every last dollar matters. So, if you do decide to donate, please know that effort isn't lost on us.  No gift is too small.

We are so grateful for our community. And we can't pull this off without you.

*If you prefer to make a tax deductible donation, please visit our Fractured Atlas page at: https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/prof...

Other Ways You Can Help

·  Come see the show! Tickets are on sale now (http://edielaminx.brownpapertickets.com/)

·  Share this campaign with your friends and family

·  Share our website on social media. We’re at thepartylinepresents.org

·  Tell your friends to see the show!

What is The Party Line?

The Party Line is a new Brooklyn based theater company led by Kelly Kerwin and co-founded with Whitney Dibo, Will Rucker, and Emily Zemba. We invite you to come share a cocktail with us, throw confetti in the air, and ditch decorum.  For more info, check out our website at thepartylinepresents.org

FEATURING

Seth Bodie

James Cusati-Moyer

Jax Jackson

John Moauro

Jeremy O. Harris

Tom Pecinka

Jack Ramsey


THE TEAM

Kelly Kerwin: Director, Co-Writer

Emily Zemba: Associate Director, Co-Writer

Helen Jaksch: Dramaturg, Co-Writer

Whitney Dibo: Producer

Will Rucker: Producer, Stage Manager

Christopher Ash: Sets, Lights, Projections

Grier Coleman: Costumes

Eva Peskin: Sound

Mitchel Civello: Assistant Director

Sara Holdren: Graphic Designer

Rowan Magee: Fight Choreography

story:
INTRODUCTION

Hello I'm Lin Rountree...most of you know me as an R&B, Soul, Contemporary Jazz recording artist and producer. But today I'm reaching out to you as a passionate business leader who's interested in uplifting this community. For the past three years my organization Ltree Entertainment has proudly partnered with the El Olam Center for Dance and Arts  to bring an annual 2 day Praise-dance conference to the city of Detroit.  

Every year the conference culminates in a FREE Gospel and Praise Concert  at the end of the Weekend.   This year, because of overwhelming demand the conference had to move to larger venue. (COBO CENTER). And in order to accommodate its exponential growth additional resources are needed in order to ensure participants have the have the best experience possible.  We're asking for your assistance in order to keep concert portion of this event Free and Open to the public, just as it's been since its inception.

ABOUT THE 2-DAY DANCE CONFERENCE

The purpose of this amazing event is to:

  •  Bring people together ages 7 and up for technical training in, and spiritual inspiration through the art of dance by making access to internationally renowned dance leaders/instructors form places like The National Liturgical Dance Network, Alvin Ailey and others,  affordable to individuals who have limited resources as well as educate them in the health benefits of dance; mind body and spirit. 
  • The conference in its fourth year will take place this June 17th and 18th at COBO Center. If you or anyone you know of is interested in participating, regardless of skill level, please visit www.elolamdance.org for more information. 


THE CONCERT

For the past 3 years at the end of this incredible weekend Ltree Entertainment has Sponsored a Gospel and Praise Dance Worship Concert featuring powerful performances by the National guest instructors, National Gospel artists Like Bishop William Murphy who ministered last year, and the conference participants who perform using the techniques they've learned over the weekend…and for the past 3 years the concert has been Free and Open to the Public.  This years concert we’ve already confirmed both: National Gospel Recording artist Kevin LeVar  and Phil Tarver (former worship leader of Shekinah Glory Ministry)

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

Because the conference has grown in size and demand…..it had to be moved to a larger venue this year which is why it’s now at Cobo Center.  Good thing is that there is space for well over 1000 people to attend the evening concert.  The challenge is being able to fully cover all of the fixed costs of preparations needed to accommodate that many people.  That said, Ltree Entertainment is committed to helping keep the Concert portion of this event Free and Open to the public.

YOUR DONATION

Our goal is to raise $10,000. These funds will be used to:

  • Keep the concert free and open to the public
  • Make this Concert the best experience possible for the community
  • Hire professional sound engineers with the equipment to accomodate a large audience of 1,000 plus people
  • Hire of professional musicians to accompany our national artists
  • Advertise so that more people can be encouraged to experience the uplifting power of Worship music and Praise dance
  • Venue rental costs
  • Make it possible for the City Of Detroit to continue to generate positive imagery through high character events like this  Concert
(A portion of your donation will go to the El Olam Cares Foundation, a non-profit organization that provides scholarships for disadvantaged inner City youth to attend the 2-Day conference and other events pertaining to dance education)

Will you donate?  

Thank you and God bless…

story:
Short Summary

The mapping lineage project aims to document practitioner experiences of ensemble improvisation practices. The project collected over 60 practitioner lineage maps from artist participants at the Form in Question symposium hosted by the Institute for Creative Research at Tisch School of the Arts/NYU in January 2016.  We now wish to publish these lineage maps in an artist book with commentaries in order to provide a valuable resource to artists, practitioners and researchers in the dance field.

 What We Need & What You Get
  • The cost of publishing the book is £3000 GBP
  • The book uniquely documents the lineage of prominent practitioners in ensemble improvisation since the 1970s. The maps are both artistically engaging and historically significant. 
  • All funds will go to the cost of publishing the book.


The Impact

  • The Form in Question Symposium brought together ensemble improvisation practitioners from across the generations.  It was a unique meeting of artists who have documented the lineage of their work through this project that was part of the symposium.
  • The book is a beautiful artifact and a historical document that will be of use to dance students, scholars, artists and historians.


Risks & Challenges

The book will be printed by the Guildford Street Press, a student run press at the University of Bedfordshire, UK.  The book will be bound with a french fold (subject to testing), with a green cover and black riso print on off-white paper inside.

  • The Guildford Street Press regulary produces book for exhibitions and degree shows.
  • Using the Guildford Street Press will help to keep the publication costs down.
  • A risk is that our timescale will slip.
  • Additional monies raised will be used to print additional copies of the book and to subsidise distribution


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share our campaign with your colleagues and friends!
