story:
Our Story:

Founded in 2015, the Flagstaff Shakespeare Festival's inaugural season featured a successful run of Twelfth Night. Our first repertory season, O Brawling Love! in 2016, showcased Romeo & Juliet and A Midsummer Night's Dream. We are excited for our third season, Cruel to be Kind, which will excite audiences with Macbeth  and All's Well That Ends Well in 2017.

The mission of the Flagstaff Shakespeare Festival is to faithfully portray classics of the Renaissance and American stage for the purpose of honoring authorial intent, enlightening audiences, and revitalizing our understanding of theatre through performance and education. Flagstaff Shakespeare Festival is dedicated to offering exciting artistic opportunities and experiences for the residents of northern Arizona.


The Impact:

The Flagstaff Shakespeare Festival in Flagstaff, Arizona, will be a regional and national destination. It will allow audience members to experience the performance of Shakespeare and classic American plays outdoors, in local historic venues, and (in future seasons) in a purpose-built reconstruction of the Fortune Playhouse.

Bringing in previous cast members, veteran actors from all over the country, and even an associate from Shakespeare's Globe, Flagstaff Shakespeare Festival is excited to continue bringing Shakespeare to Flagstaff. However, the company needs your support in order to make this season our most successful yet.


What We Need:

We can only achieve our goal with the help of our donors, sponsors, and supporters. Our expenses include:

  • Event Sites
  • Advertising and Promotion
  • Technical Support
  • Storage Space
  • Actor Housing
  • Administrative Expenses 
  • Costumes/Props/Set
In addition to these important needs, our long-term goal is to build a professional theater company. We’re looking for support to start this new Shakespeare festival, which boasts connections to such prestigious institutions as the Globe in London and the Blackfriars Playhouse in Staunton, Virginia. In sum, we aim to establish a company that benefits not only Flagstaff, but the broader theatre community. We want to create jobs and support these jobs as any working company must, and we need everyone’s help to get there.


How We Thank Our Sponsors:

  • We will display your logo prominently on all print materials produced for the show you sponsor (seen by hundreds of patrons at each show), on our website (over a thousand visits monthly), and in all our social media advertising (thousands reached every week).
  • An actor will give your business special mention in our curtain speech.
  • We will give your business several complimentary and discount tickets for the show you sponsor.

Other Ways You Can Help:

Talk about us: Whether you live in Flagstaff, Phoenix, or elsewhere across the country or the world, word of mouth is invaluable advertising. Tell your friends and family about FlagShakes, the actors you know, and the shows you have seen!

Follow us: Check out what Flagstaff Shakespeare Festival shares on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and Snapchat. And be sure to like our posts!

Contact us: Do you have any ideas about how to get the word out about FlagShakes? Want to talk with one of the directors about your suggestions? We want to hear from you! Email admin@flagshakes.com.

Sponsor Us: Let us know what you want from a partnership with Flagstaff Shakespeare Festival, and we'll discuss different options with you. If you know of an organization or individual who may be interested in sponsoring FlagShakes, please contact us.

Follow us: Check out what Flagstaff Shakespeare Festival shares
on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and Snapchat. And be sure to like our posts!
Contact us: Do you have any ideas about how to get the word out about FlagShakes? Want to talk with one of the directors about your suggestions? We want to hear from you! Email admin@flagshakes.com.
Sponsor Us: Let us know what you want from a partnership
with Flagstaff Shakespeare Festival, and we'll discuss different options with
you. If you know of an organization or individual who may be interested in
sponsoring FlagShakes, please contact us.

story:
I am Dustin Klein, a pianist, and an elementary school choir director and drama teacher at a private school. Tom Alvarez is free lance journalist, actor/model, former arts administrator, and television producer/director.  We both live in Indianapolis, Indiana.  We are co-creators of "Calder, The Musical" for which I am the composer and Tom is the lyricist. Together, we co-wrote the book.

We are raising funds towards the completion of the second stage of our project.The first stage was the successful presentation of an abbreviated version of our show in the IndyFringe Theatre Festival which was the #1 best-selling show. The second stage is the world premier full production which will be presented Jan. 27 - Feb. 12, 2017 at the IndyFringe Basile Theatre.

Besides our desire to inform, education, entertain and inspire our audiences regarding the innovative Calder and his work, through our musical, we also wish to provide a challenging, creative opportunity for artists in our community. By supporting our project you will not only make it possible for them to be afforded compensation for their efforts, but also provide them with  a prestigious professional credit that can contribute to the advancement of their careers.

The $20,000 we hope to raise will go towards stipends for our semi-professional performers (actors, singers, dancers), as well as crew members and professional designers (costumes, lighting, sound, props, projections, and illustrator).

We think our perks which include going behind the scenes at our rehearsals; enjoying a private concert of our original songs with Tom and me as your hosts; and having an original song written, just for you—are all pretty darned special.

We believe our charming musical about a revolutionary artist, who brought art to life, is a positive antidote to the troubling times we live in. By participating in helping us bring it to the stage you are promoting original work and art in general, as a means of inspiring peace and harmony.

As far as any risks associated with your donation, we have already demonstrated, through our success at IndyFringe, that we are more than capable of producing theatre and filling seats. Good reviews and the popular appeal of our show also spoke to its high level of artistic quality.

Tom and I believe our ideal skill set (artistic and admistrative) has gotten us this far. We have absolutely no doubt that, with your support, we will achieve our ultimate financial and artistic goals as we move forward.

If you are not able to make a financial contribution (and none is too small) please help us spread the word to your friends (tell ten of them), acquaintances and colleagues via social media. Find us at "Calder, The Musical" on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and Snapchat.  We welcome you to become a fan!

"Calder, The Musical" is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of "Calder, The Musical" will be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Harrison Lang and The Egremont Barn present:

Spring Awakening!

 

Welcome to Harrison Lang's campaign to raise funds for the Berkshires' premiere  production of Steven Sater and Duncan Sheik's Tony Award winning Broadway hit musical, Spring Awakening. Harrison Lang grew up in the Berkshires and is currently a local actor completing his  degree in Musical Theatre at Tulane University.  Back in the fall, the owners of The Egremont Barn and Harrison decided that a new way to attract people to the venue would be to produce a full-fledged musical production in the space that showcases its versatility. This summer a brilliant piece of musical theatre, that has touched millions of people across the world and changed the course of Broadway, will be produced in The Egremont Barn. The Spring Awakening cast and creative team is comprised entirely of young Berkshire County actors who have worked both professionally and regionally. Your contribution to our production will help support the voices of promising up and coming actors as well as help produce a beautiful, important, and timeless piece of musical theatre. 

Performances: June 21-24 @ 7:30pm, June 25 @ 2pm

The Egremont Barn at The Egremont Village Inn: 17 Main St. South Egremont, MA 01258

Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/SpringAwakeningEB/

Follow us on Instagram: @springawakeningeb

Tickets on sale soon!

 

Directed by Harrison Lang 

Choreographed by Natalie Sala

Music Direction by Cindy Gutter and Mike Pacifico

Produced by Harrison Lang, Gigi Teeley, Caitlin Teeley, and The Egremont Village Inn

Stage Management/ Assistants to the Director: Victoria Aldam and Corey Potter

 

STARRING: 

Jackson Teeley as Melchior Gabor

Caroline Fairweather as Wendla Bergmann

Ali Louis Bourzgui as Moritz Stiefel

Caitlin Teeley as Ilse Neumann

Joey Labrasca as Hänschen Rilow 

Diana Quetti as Martha Bessell

Connor McNinch as Ernst Röbel

John Ververis as Georg Zirschnitz 

Aiden Chalfonte as Otto Lämmermeier 

Corey Potter as Thea

Julia Murphy as Anna

Gigi Teeley as The Adult Woman

Adult Man casting will be announced soon!

 

What We Need 

I feel it paramount to pay the people who are devoting their time and energy to his production. Since this is a grassroots project, any contribution helps. All funds raised will go directly to paying some actors, creative team members, and designers, as well as cover fees for costumes, lights, and props. The funds raised will also cover any miscellaneous expenses such as program printing and marketing fees. These things add up and every little bit helps. This is where you come in!

Why it matters:

There is no shortage of beautiful theatre in Berkshire County and I am so excited to share an  essential piece of musical theatre with this community. Spring Awakening is an incredibly meaningful show to me because it allowed me to accept myself for who I was, and I firmly believe it will do the same for our audience members. 

By using local artists of different mediums I hope to expand the pool of people who support local theatre. My hope is to see a diverse community in our audiences; teachers, grandparents, musicians, mechanics, lawyers, bus-drivers, comedians, you name it! Good story telling should be accessible to everyone and I want to see you there!

Having done theatre in high school and college, as well as some local theatre since moving back, I've become committed to uplifting the work of young Berkshire County talent. Acting is an incredibly difficult, and often time fruitless profession, but I want to give young talent the opportunity to express themselves through a piece of theatre they are 100% devoted to and passionate about.  

Most importantly, I wish to make theatre accessible to  all  audiences. The arts is a fully accepting community and there is no room for judgement or discrimination. Spring Awakening is a show that is cast based on talent and passion, not race, gender, or religion. It celebrates individuality and the power of communication. 

Your kind contributions help to keep ticket prices low.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, that's okay! By sharing this campaign on social media or emailing it to friends, family members, and teachers, you are already helping out. 

Please support the show by coming this summer. I, and the entire Spring Awakening cast and creative team,  hope to see you in our audience! Check back on the facebook page, or theegremontbarn.com for updates on when tickets will go on sale.

Performances run: Wednesday June 21, Thursday June 22, Friday June 23, and Saturday June 24, at 7:30pm, and Sunday June 25 at 2pm.

story:
Who are we, and what's this hullabaloo all about?

We're Scapegoat Collective! Helmed by Daniel Pagett (Artistic Director) and Sonia Vaillant (Artistic Producer), we're an indie theatre company coming out of Toronto. With combined experience in directing, dramaturgy, acting, design, producing, marketing, playwrighting, and stage and production management, we've got big ideas and the background to make them happen. Scapegoat Collective has produced two shows previously - Big Plans by Jeremy Taylor (directed by Kat Sandler) and Hangman by Jason Maghanoy (directed by Daniel Pagett) - but now we're looking to create original new works, starting with Cloud by Daniel Pagett.

Starting with a small group of people and expanding to the population of Earth, Cloud tells of humanity's discovery of a practical collective consciousness – a more efficient internet, where files are shared in real time, directly to the brain. Not just audio and visuals, but thought files, emotion files, tactile files. What does empathy mean when it is immediately informed by another human’s real-time experience? What does that do to love? To hate? Can we still disagree once our entire life experience is unified? Won't it get lonely when we aren't connected? Won't it get lonely if we're all the same? Cloud explores these questions through traditional and untraditional narrative, and investigates themes of ownership, sex, love, non-monogamy, and the need to feel special.

We have an amazing cast and creative team lined up, and we'll be in the beautiful Artscape Sandbox for our performance run. Cloud is an ambitious, multi-disciplinary project that has the potential to be something really beautiful and meaningful - your contributions will help us craft this alternate world by providing funding for the talented artists making up our team and the materials required to make their vision come to life.

What We Need & What You Get

Oh boy, making art is EXPENSIVE, hey?! Luckily we've been on the case for months, and we've been pounding the pavement, staying up late applying for grants, and throwing some super fun events to raise funds for this production. With our extensive roots in indie theatre, we know how to hustle and make a dollar count. That said, we can all use some help.

Because Cloud is a multi-disciplinary production, there are lots of moving parts, which means lots of expenses, but lots of opportunities to work with and employ artists of different backgrounds. Some of our expenses include:

  • Venue - $8,000
  • Tech costs and building materials - $10,000
  • Venue and Artist Insurance - $3,000
  • Marketing - $3,000

And that doesn't even include fees for our lovely and talented artists who are making the dream come to life. Every dollar helps us actualize the world of Cloud and get us as much money into the pockets of our artists as possible, because we all know the starving artist trope is overdone and over-romanticized and we really just all love to eat. 

So why Cloud right now?

As it stands, fear, division, and isolation are used as political weapons. Cloud explores a converse extreme – the possibility of ultimate empathy through a collective consciousness. Our approach for both this production and the development of Scapegoat Collective as an organization, is to combat this loneliness, fear, and isolation. It’s easy to question the value of art when it seems like the sky is falling, but it is through these creative outlets that - we believe - true change can be achieved. The theatre has always been a place for storytelling, discussion, and community. It is a place to safely and thoughtfully challenge ourselves and each other, and a place where anyone can find inclusion and solace. Theatre is a sanctuary that we need more than ever. The ability to sit with strangers and engage with each other and with a piece is pivotal right now. It creates community out of what was previously disconnect.

We know what we are fighting against. Both the production and our process demonstrate what we are fighting for. Community, compassion, and joy are our weapons. Fight with us.

Risks & Challenges

Any theatre practitioner knows that it can be tricky getting people out to the theatre! This project is very ambitious, but luckily we're not afraid of a challenge and our combined experience means we've seen what works and what doesn't in indie theatre because - well, we've been there! We think this show is going to be something really special that people want to talk about and we're all about finding every way possible to make those conversations happen.

This production of Cloud is a springboard for things to come from Scapegoat Collective and we've been fortunate enough to have the support of some amazing organizations and companies so far, INCLUDING Artscape Sandbox, Bad Dog Comedy Theatre, Mugshot Tavern, and Forked River Brewing Co. We're part of a great community and your help strengthens that even more - every little bit counts and nothing goes unnoticed (did we mention how far we can spread a dollar?).

Putting on any theatre show involves a certain amount of risk and brings its fair share of challenges. We've been in the trenches before and we know that not only can we bring Cloud to life, but it's the first stepping stone in the growth of this big-hearted company and it'll allow us to tackle even bigger challenges in the future.

Other Ways You Can Help

Hey man, we get it! If you can't make a donation, DON'T WORRY. You can support us by helping to spread the word by social media and/or email by using either the Indiegogo share tools at the top of the page, or by linking directly to our campaign!

And if you or anyone know is in Toronto in October, COME SEE THE SHOW! More than anything, we're thrilled to get this bad boy out into the world and start talking to people about it.

Thanks and ever thanks, from the bottom of our goofy indie-theatre hearts.

story:
The Goal

Our goal is simple: Raise funds to pay our cast for the world premiere of this musical at the 2017 Hollywood Fringe festival. We don't want to have to depend on ticket sales to guarantee that the artists helping us get paid for their time and talent.

Small theater in Los Angeles is done because of passion for a project. But we also believe in showing our talented folk that their passion deserves SOMETHING as payment. Please help us make this a guaranteed reality that's not dependent on ticket sales.

We also want to bring this production to our friends all over who want to support us, and shouldn't miss out on this stunning show. This is a follow up attempt at raising funds at the behest of many friends who would be thrilled to see what we've all put so much into this project, and we want to do this right, with professional photography and videography. 

The Show

Our preview is June 2nd, with only 4 performances following during June. We're focusing on ticket sales and getting audience in to see them, which you should absolutely do if you can, However, if you're not local, or if you can simply spare a few bucks to help us along the way, it would surely contribute to something fantastic!

What We Need

We've covered so much of this show already. Registration for the festival. Cost of the venue. Promotional materials. Fantastic costumes for 10 performers. Insurance. Amenities during rehearsals. The list goes on producing a show like this, and we're happy to say that we've done it.

We're asking for $2,000 so we may

  • Pay all 10 performers for all 5 performances
  • Pay for high quality professional pictures and video capture of this show.

If we don't reach our goal, the show will go on! We'll use what we get to pay the actors before covering anything else and before paying ourselves back for expenses.

If we exceed our goal, we'll have a few surprises to share with our backers as a thank you. The extra money would put us on great footing for any extension of this show beyond Fringe, which we hope to do.

Simply put, your money goes to the show.

story:
Ehrstrand Dance Collective is a family of experienced artists representing four continents that works to create and continue international dance exchange and foster global artistic relationships. For the last ten years, we have explored and experimented with the creation of new and exciting work at our Styggbo Residency and Dansforum Festival in Sweden. Styggbo Residency, created in 2008 by Helena and Julia Ehrstrand, which began with only 7 dancers, has grown to more than double in size and has become a highly sought-after dance opportunity for contemporary dance artists. Though we, the artists of Ehrstrand Dance Collective, live and work throughout the year in many different countries—including Japan, Mexico, Brazil, Italy, Finland, Sweden, the U.S., and Spain—we come together each year at Styggbo Residency to share, grow, and create within our common language and love of dance. 

One of our foremost goals has always been to build a network of collaboration and community amongst international artists.  We believe that collaboration between artists of different cultures and identities only serves to enrich dance as an art form and a communal language across the globe. Most recently, one of our newest collaborators in Mexico invited Ehrstrand Dance Collective to create work and perform at Festival Internacional de Danza Contemporánea de la Ciudad de México, one of the largest dance festivals in Mexico. This is a huge and unique opportunity for us to create connections with new artists we might not otherwise have the chance to meet.  It is a big step towards furthering our goal of growing the current Styggbo Residency/Dansforum Festival into a broader global network of contemporary dance residencies and festivals.  For this project to succeed as we envision it, we need to raise money to fund transportation for our 9 dancers to travel to Mexico City. We have already been able to secure accommodations and other necessities upon arrival in Mexico, and the final piece of our journey is gathering support for our flight costs. 

Now more than ever, the conversation between international artists is of extreme importance. We ask that you consider making a contribution to our project and to international contemporary dance as a whole. Please do not miss this opportunity to begin connecting the world through dance!
story_txt:
Ehrstrand Dance Collective is a family of experienced artists representing four continents that works to create and continue international dance exchange and foster global artistic relationships. For the last ten years, we have explored and experimented with the creation of new and exciting work at our Styggbo Residency and Dansforum Festival in Sweden. Styggbo Residency, created in 2008 by Helena and Julia Ehrstrand, which began with only 7 dancers, has grown to more than double in size and has become a highly sought-after dance opportunity for contemporary dance artists. Though we, the artists of Ehrstrand Dance Collective, live and work throughout the year in many different countries—including Japan, Mexico, Brazil, Italy, Finland, Sweden, the U.S., and Spain—we come together each year at Styggbo Residency to share, grow, and create within our common language and love of dance. 
One of our foremost goals has always been to build a network of collaboration and community amongst international artists.  We believe that collaboration between artists of different cultures and identities only serves to enrich dance as an art form and a communal language across the globe. Most recently, one of our newest collaborators in Mexico invited Ehrstrand Dance Collective to create work and perform at Festival Internacional de Danza Contemporánea de la Ciudad de México, one of the largest dance festivals in Mexico. This is a huge and unique opportunity for us to create connections with new artists we might not otherwise have the chance to meet.  It is a big step towards furthering our goal of growing the current Styggbo Residency/Dansforum Festival into a broader global network of contemporary dance residencies and festivals.  For this project to succeed as we envision it, we need to raise money to fund transportation for our 9 dancers to travel to Mexico City. We have already been able to secure accommodations and other necessities upon arrival in Mexico, and the final piece of our journey is gathering support for our flight costs. 
Now more than ever, the conversation between international artists is of extreme importance. We ask that you consider making a contribution to our project and to international contemporary dance as a whole. Please do not miss this opportunity to begin connecting the world through dance!

story:
Not Man Apart - Physical Theatre Ensemble presents: 
Jones (Welsh) Talmadge's "Paradise Lost: Reclaiming Destiny"

 

“Paradise Lost: Reclaiming Destiny” transforms Milton’s elegant text into an epic acrobatic dance on stage and in the air. Jones (Welsh) Talmadge’s innovative vision and dynamic partnering style will incorporate Not Man Apart’s unique brand of physical storytelling with the stunning digital animation effects of both J-Walt Adamczyk and video installation artist Hannah Beavers. You will see bodies flying through space, the creation of the universe and the Garden of Eden, Adam and Eve’s Temptation, and the War in Heaven. The powerful visual spectacle integrates with the beautiful choreography to weave a tale filled with emotion and surrounded by evocative music, whether you are familiar with the story from Genesis, Milton’s text, or not at all.

This show offers up a new future, undetermined by the past, free from the need to dominate, and empowers the audience to fully claim a created destiny and connection to the whole.

It’s up to us. Right now. We are not waiting for anything -- we get to create a Heaven on Earth.

We are thrilled to present this new project as a part of NMA’s residency at Greenway Court Theatre.

 

WHAT WE NEED:

We are a not-for-profit (501c3) arts organization; our productions are entirely supported by ticket sales and donations. For "Paradise Lost: Reclaiming Destiny," we are looking to raise $10,000 (one-third of our production budget) through this Indiegogo campaign. From aerial rigging and marketing, to set pieces, costumes, and digital effects equipment, your tax-deductible contributions will go directly to the production of this unique show.

 

WHAT YOU GET:

In addition to your choice of PERKS listed, you get an imaginative new adaptation of John Milton’s classic text, created and directed by Jones (Welsh) Talmadge, co-directed by Laura Covelli, choreographed by Jones, Anne-Marie Talmadge, Pamela Donahoo, Courtney Munch, Charles Roy, and Alina Bolshakova, and featuring an original score composed by Alysia Michelle James, Bernie Sirelson, and Elisa Rosin.

 

THE ONGOING IMPACT OF NMA IN THE COMMUNITY:

We believe the greatest depth of our humanity is discovered in relationship with others. Not man apart, but man together.

NMA strives to create life-affirming, consciousness expanding art that is relatable, relevant and transformative for our audiences and community. During past productions we have worked in partnership with organizations such as New Directions for Veterans, Warrior’s Chorus LA, Art and Action, and more; and are currently spearheading the new Movement Program at Pepperdine University. Exceeding our 10K goal would allow us to continue to extend our work to the community!
 

Perhaps not since the emerging Theatre Movement Bazaar has a physical theatre troupe demonstrated such purposeful integrity. Indeed it would be madness to miss it. – LA Times (Ajax in Iraq)

 

 

How you can help us bring innovative physical theatre to Hollywood:

  • Support Not Man Apart - Physical Theatre Ensemble with a gift of any amount
  • Tell everyone you’re backing our project and they should too! 
  • Share our campaign with your friends and family through social media.
  • Stay connected: follow us on Facebook, Twitter, & Instagram to hear about our epic adventure, as well as upcoming performances and events in Los Angeles and throughout the region. 
     

THE "PARADISE" TEAM
 

Jones (Welsh) Talmadge - Director and Choreographer
 



Laura Covelli - Co-Director
 



J-Walt Adamczyk - Visual Effects
 


CAST
Charles Roy as Adam
Alina Bolshakova as Eve
J-Walt Adamczyk as Father God
Hannah Beavers as Mother God
Zach Davidson as The Son of God
Jones (Welsh) Talmadge as Satan
Laura Covelli as Sin
James Bane as Death
Alexander Garland as Beelzebub
Anne-Marie Talmadge as The Archangel Michael
Elisa Rosin as The Archangel Gabriel
Kendall Johnson as The Archangel Rafael
Moses Norton as The Seraph Abdiel
Janine Montag as Moloch
and Philip Wainwright as Belial


Choreographers - Jones (Welsh) Talmadge, Alina Bolshakova, Courtney Munch, Pamela Donohoo, Anne-Marie Talmadge, and Charles Roy

Wardrobe by Ashphord Jacoway

 

Thank you for investing in innovative physical theatre! 

Your contribution and partnership allows Not Man Apart - Physical Theatre Ensemble to present excellent performances across Los Angeles and throughout the world.

 

http://notmanapart.com/
 

 

Photo credit: Anthony Roldan (NMA on Big Sur Beach), DarrylJim photography (Jones Welsh Talmadge in "The SuperHero and his Charming Wife").

story:
Our Story!

All the money you donate will help to keep the Storefront Theatre up and KICKING through 2017!

With a banner year behind it, the Storefront Theatre 2017’s Winter Season is all about starting a riot. Whether we’re screaming from the rooftops for water sustainability, crusading for forbidden love, or turning a historical masterpiece on its F#$%ing head, this season the Storefront stage is embracing anarchy and naughtiness to see what we can get away with.

The Storefront Arts Initiative provides affordable and inclusive studio and performance space to artists and collectives. The SAI prioritizes new play development and uses a collaborative model with an emphasis on collective responsibility between artists and administrators and provides meaningful learning opportunities for practitioners.

At the Storefront we value community, and this year our Holidaze Campaign features a fun way for you to give back to YOUR community as well! 

2 Ways to play the Break It Forward Challenge:

  • Donate to the storefront through this campaign then nominate a really hard working friend, family member or colleague to TAKE A BREAK. Make a vid of yourself taking a break, nominate them in the vid, then tag them on Facebook and include our #sftbreakitforward hashtag!
  • Get nominated by a friend to TAKE A BREAK! Donate to the campaign then create your own BREAK video and Break it Forward to a really hard working friend, family member or colleague. Remember to tag them in your video and don't forget to include our #sftbreakitforward hashtag!

In the spirit of the season let's acknowledge and recognize those in our lives who give so much! 

What We Need & What You Get

The Storefront Arts Initiative is a not for profit organization that operates the Storefront Theatre and Studio in Toronto, Ontario. we ALSO present and co-produce independent Canadian LIVE performance! We opened in 2012 and over the past four years have worked with over 500 artists and had over 75 independent productions take place in our old pharmacy turned theatre on Bloor Street. Our Board of Directors and Management is working diligently to establish the organizational infrastructure that will position us to spearhead a National Storefront Movement. And we do all of this without ANY large scale financial support. That's right kids. No GRANTS and No Corporate Sponsorships! 

Your contribution to this campaign will see funds going directly to:

  • Facilities: Front Signage, plumbing and electrical fixes and utilities payments
  • Artist and Design Fees: Our upcoming production of DIVINE is produced by our Resident Company the Red One Theatre Collective. We are eager to pay our artists, designers and production team a modest wage for this project. 
  • Administrative Bonuses: Did you know that there are over 25(!!!) staff volunteers who work tirelessly to run the Storefront?? From facilities to box office to marketing and producing we are a BIG team! It would be amazing to be able to give all of our hard working staff a little holiday bonus!

SOME OF OUR RAD PERKS INCLUDE: 

TIX TO OUR NEW YEARS EVE NASTY WOMYN/BADBADBOYS CABARET & DUMPSTERDIVE GALA Real Talk. 2016 was an absolute clusterfuck. BUT WE SHALL NOT SPEAK OF IT. Let's get FABULOUS with no money & usher in 2017 with glamour & style. Spumante Bambino in a champagne flute from Dufferin Mall? Glittering Costume Diamonds paired with a Value Village ball gown/tuxedo. Wear your most fabulous dumpster dive gala chic outfit & let's all pretend we're absolutely fabulous.

TIX TO OUR WINTER SEASON OPENER- DIVINE (JAN.20-FEB 6)#DIVINE It’s 2017, and it’s time to riot. The Storefront Theatre cracks a new year open with a political banger.  Natalie Frijia’s new Canadian play, DIVINE, takes place in an Ontario without water.  A pair of desperate bandits search for their last hope —a water diviner by the name of Penn.  But the bandits aren't the only ones hunting Penn down.  What if there's nothing left for Penn to divine? Co-Produced by the Storefront Arts Initiative’s resident company, the Red One Theatre Collective, DIVINE meshes art with activism, while featuring an all star, all female cast and design team, directed by Storefront Executive Director, Claire Burns. Set in Ontario’s dystopian future, DIVINE is a prophetic cautionary tale told through magical realism and true GRIT.

The Impact

The Storefront Arts Initiative has contributed to a valuable micro-infrastructure of Toronto's entertainment industry. Storefront Theatres act as cultural hubs in urban neighbourhoods and their reclamation of disused or old storefront spaces reinvigorates the tone of a city. In the past four years Storefront has become a local institution (if you can believe it or not!). We are currently in the process of applying for charitable status- once achieved the Storefront will be eligible for more funding opportunities from larger corporate and community donors. Your donation will make a tangible difference in the lives of the artists that work with the organization during this middle period. Thank you so much for your SUPPORT! 

Last year we successfully raised $10,000 through our #project soundproof campaign. Those funds have been re-allocated into an investment fund that is being saved for moving costs- because people- we HAVE to move. We have a bigger vision for the Storefront than our current tenancy allows. We are currently working with OMG Real Estate to find a long term home! Moving Day Set for July 01, 2018!

Risks & Challenges

We realize that this campaign relies on YOUR help! Please be creative, share your BREAK videos and acknowledge those in your community who work so hard but tend to go unrecognized! Let's get this shit on viral! ammmiiiirriiight??

Other ways you can help!

  • If you're short on funds- no problemo! We ALWAYS need volunteers. Email Storefrontvolunteers@gmail.com and we will get you set up- box office, load in crew, website management and more!! All for the arts lover in you!
  • We want to you to be part of our 2017/2018 season! Submit your project to submissionsft@gmail.com by December 18 and YOU TOO could be doing a kick ass indie show at the Storefront Theatre!! more details at www.thestorefronttheatre.com
  • COME TO OUR NYE PARTY! TIX ONLY $10!! 

xoxo

The Storefront

story:
Rebirth of the Circus

Help make circus art an official performing art and keep the circus alive!

For 250 years, the art of circus performing has been taken far and wide to transcend expectations across generations of audiences. While the animal acts and exhibitions have largely fallen out of favor, the unbelievable talents of trapeze artists, aerial performers, fire eaters, and more have become a fixture in America’s cultural history. The few years previous, however, have seen the demise of circus names like the Ringling Brothers, Big Apple Circle, and countless others. The large touring shows can no longer be sustained the way they used to despite the love that audiences have for the circus performers. Even with the impact that circus made in American history, the National Endowment of the Arts (NEA) has never recognized circus as an art form. Given these drawbacks, there’s the great chance that circus art may soon fall off the map of American performing arts within the next few decades. The Smithsonian, however, has noted the circus’s importance and reached out to the right people to make sure that the art doesn’t die.

My name is Tim (I’m on the left). I am the founder and creative director at the Imperial OPA Circus in Atlanta, GA, and the circus has changed my life and the lives of others for the better. With Imperial OPA, I’ve had the privilege of joining other circus artists and bringing their talents to events like festivals, school events, corporate parties, and even the occasional wedding! Imperial OPA also works to keep the circus arts alive by offering classes to children and adults that want to take the trapeze, swing from aerial silks, or master the art of juggling.

The Smithsonian has recognized our efforts and reached out to us to feature Imperial OPA Circus at the Smithsonian Folklife Festival (SFF), an event where we can celebrate the diversity and long history of Circus Art on a national stage. At this festival, we can share the story and talents of The Imperial OPA from June 29-July 9th in Washington, D.C. As the festival is open to the public and free for all, we can use this offered spot to engage in an intimate conversation about contemporary circus arts and provide opportunities for the public to meet and learn from circus arts professionals.

This feature isn’t just a few days of performance. At the SFF, The National Endowment of the Arts will be holding a workshop days for circus owners and artists to meet NEA officials and discuss what is needed to keep circus arts alive and active for the future generations in America. This one workshop day has great potential to keep the success of the circus alive in America. Even more, potential sponsors and granters at this workshop could be moved to help build the foundations that future circus performers will need to produce shows and build the next generations of performers.

YOU Can Help Make This Happen!

With the help of sponsors and supporters, we can bring 10 performers from the Imperial OPA Circus to Washington, D.C. for this 11 day event (*with 2 set up + 1 day tear down). In these 14  days, we will be part of the Smithsonian’s free show on the National Mall in Washington D.C.. We’d be interacting with the guests that will follow the generations before us that loved the circus, and we’d hopefully inspire them to help keep the art alive as well!

What We Need & What You Get

We’re going need your help to get 10 performers to D.C for this 14 day event. We calculated costs and expenses and we’re going to need at least $25,000 to pull this off.

$5,000 is what it will cost us to produce costumes and book plane tickets and supply the props needed. The rest of the $20,000 is needed to be part of this event, as it would be going straight to the Smithsonian institutionon our behalf so they can take care of our meals, lodging, and transportation.

Here’s the breakdown:

  • 1 Artist for 1 day ( meals + hotel room + transportation while in DC) : $143
  • 1 Artist for 14 days : $2,002
  • 10 Artists for 11 days : $20,002
  • 10 Artists :  Flights to DC, Print materials, Costume parts, Performance Supplies needed : $5,000 (about $500 per artist)

Anything extra left over or above would go towards additional costumes and reimbursing the artist for the 14 days they will be taking off from work.

** Please Note **

By participating in this festival, our artists would be donating their time to enrich the cultural diversity in America and help lay the foundation for a thriving circus culture. Aside from whatever we raise above our ask, we won’t be making money from this festival. There is no pay for the time or performances at the SFF.

Let's Talk Perks!

$10 - High Fives!

Every little bit counts! You rock! Thank you for helping support the circus.

$50 - 50/50!

If you are willing to do 50, we are willing to do 50 as well! At this level we will give you a discount code that will take 50% off YOUR ticket price to our next show!

(*FYI : Next show is TBA at the moment...)

$100 - A Special Thank You!

When we get back to Atlanta from the festival, we will send you a few selected photos of the festival along with the review of what we did and how you helped!

$150 - Artist 1 Day!

At this level, you can help cover the on the ground costs for one artist for one day in DC. The artist you sponsored for this day, will take a photo holding a sign with your name on it and we will post it to our social media as you made this day happen for them! You’ll also receive more photos from the event and a review of what your contribution did for us.

$500 - Fly 1 Artist to DC with ancillary costs!

At this level, you can help cover the cost of flying one artist and their costume/print material luggage l supplies to DC! You’ll get the above perks and we will make a private photo gallery of our trip that you will have access too while we are in DC! Circus performers always have something up their sleeve, so there’s no knowing what exciting photos you’ll see!

$2,002 - Artist for 11 days

At this level, you can help cover the on the costs for food and lodging for one artist for the 11 days in DC. You’ll get the above perks and while we’re in DC, we will go live on Facebook for one day and take the time to endorse your web page or product with a link.

$2,502 - 1 Artist with Flight

You’ll be sponsoring one artist for the full experience. This will cover their flight and all the on ground costs for their 11 days at the National Mall. You’ll get the above perks and the name of the artist you helped cover along with a thank you letter from them!

$5,004 - 2 Artists with flight

We like to pair up artists into groups of two for this event to increase their safety and security while on-site in DC. At this level you will be supporting two of the artists to go to DC for the full event! As a perk, you get all of the above AND a bag of tricks--the duo team will get you a circus box of goodies from the 2017 SFF and mail them to you!

$10,008 - 4 Artists with Flights

At this level, you’ll sending two teams of two (four people) to Washington DC for the 11 days! WOW! You’ll get the above perks and two of our performing artist will come to your next event and perform, or give you a private lesson in circus!

$20,016 - 8 Artists with Flight

At this rock star level, you’ll be sending four teams of two artists to Washington DC for the 11 days! You’ll get all of our perks and the full team that goes will spell your out name with their bodies while at the National Mall and for a photo opportunity.*

*10 bodies can only make so many letters, so larger names may have to be photo shopped from two photos.

$25,020 - 10 Artist with Flight

At this level, you’ll be the official sponsor of The Imperial OPA Circus for the Smithsonian Folk Festival. You’ll be instrumental to the future success of circus at the festival and the National Endowment of the Arts. Sponsors will get all of the perks above and more. If you are local to our headquarters, we would bring the 10 person team and perform at an event or party of yours. More options are available for sponsors, as we’d be very open to find ways that we can express our gratitude to our sponsors.

The Impact

Since 2009, The Imperial OPA Circus has maintained a rich history of producing exciting and fun events in Atlanta, Georgia. We have worked with over 200 variety performing artists to help them earn a living in entertaining hundreds of thousands of people, taught kids and adults and we have had a sizable impact on the entertainment level and growth in Atlanta Georgia.

With your help,  we can keep the circus art alive in America. Interfacing with the 1 million+ festival visitors could inspire the many spinoff projects that come from the Folklife festival, but appealing to the National Endowments of the Arts on how they can help circus arts thrive and flourish in the southeast and across the nation could give circus an official place in the performing arts.

Beyond these conversations, we will be actively seeking funding to produce additional circus productions and shows, build a better circus school and program, and open a circus cabaret performance space here in Atlanta Georgia where children and adults can watch regular performances.  Everything we do would directly impact the current population of circus and variety artists in Atlanta and the future generations that come after us find the resources that they need to produce shows of their own. Together, we keep circus alive!

Risks & Challenges

We see very little risks in this project and are fully intent on doing it, whether we send one person or the whole group of ten.

The Smithsonian has confirmed us to be part of the project already. We are confirming the performing artists who will go and best represent us and polishing the performance pieces we wish to premiere.  If we do not reach our full funding goal, we will use the funds we have to fly as many artist as we can (e.i. If we get $5004, we will bring two people to the event, if we get $10,008 will bring four people, etc.). We are intent on going, it's just with how strong of a voice we will have once we get there.

Other Ways You Can Help

We realize that some can’t help with a financial contribution and this is okay. While the monetary donation is the best course of action, you can help share this campaign with other circus lovers to help raise awareness of the Smithsonian Folklife Festival. Post it to your Facebook, share it on twitter, or even writing a blog article with links to our official website to talk about the festival. More voices will help spread the word of our mission. (Psst, Indiegogo has some pretty good share tools you can use!)

If you would like to discuss other ways in which you can help (with an interview, press release, or tax-exempt donation through our fiscal sponsor Fracture Atlas, or who knows what else), we can also make that happen!

Thank you. Truly.  

Without people like you helping to support circus, this artform could possibly dwindle and die.  When we say “thank you,” it is from our hearts and from the heart of the Circus!

With gratitude and and a loud OPA!
-Tim

--

Timothy Mack

Founder and Creative Director

Web | http://theimperialopa.com
story_txt:
Rebirth of the CircusHelp make circus art an official performing art and keep the circus alive!For 250 years, the art of circus performing has been taken far and wide to transcend expectations across generations of audiences. While the animal acts and exhibitions have largely fallen out of favor, the unbelievable talents of trapeze artists, aerial performers, fire eaters, and more have become a fixture in America’s cultural history. The few years previous, however, have seen the demise of circus names like the Ringling Brothers, Big Apple Circle, and countless others. The large touring shows can no longer be sustained the way they used to despite the love that audiences have for the circus performers. Even with the impact that circus made in American history, the National Endowment of the Arts (NEA) has never recognized circus as an art form. Given these drawbacks, there’s the great chance that circus art may soon fall off the map of American performing arts within the next few decades. The Smithsonian, however, has noted the circus’s importance and reached out to the right people to make sure that the art doesn’t die.My name is Tim (I’m on the left). I am the founder and creative director at the Imperial OPA Circus in Atlanta, GA, and the circus has changed my life and the lives of others for the better. With Imperial OPA, I’ve had the privilege of joining other circus artists and bringing their talents to events like festivals, school events, corporate parties, and even the occasional wedding! Imperial OPA also works to keep the circus arts alive by offering classes to children and adults that want to take the trapeze, swing from aerial silks, or master the art of juggling.The Smithsonian has recognized our efforts and reached out to us to feature Imperial OPA Circus at the Smithsonian Folklife Festival (SFF), an event where we can celebrate the diversity and long history of Circus Art on a national stage. At this festival, we can share the story and talents of The Imperial OPA from June 29-July 9th in Washington, D.C. As the festival is open to the public and free for all, we can use this offered spot to engage in an intimate conversation about contemporary circus arts and provide opportunities for the public to meet and learn from circus arts professionals.This feature isn’t just a few days of performance. At the SFF, The National Endowment of the Arts will be holding a workshop days for circus owners and artists to meet NEA officials and discuss what is needed to keep circus arts alive and active for the future generations in America. This one workshop day has great potential to keep the success of the circus alive in America. Even more, potential sponsors and granters at this workshop could be moved to help build the foundations that future circus performers will need to produce shows and build the next generations of performers.YOU Can Help Make This Happen!With the help of sponsors and supporters, we can bring 10 performers from the Imperial OPA Circus to Washington, D.C. for this 11 day event (*with 2 set up + 1 day tear down). In these 14  days, we will be part of the Smithsonian’s free show on the National Mall in Washington D.C.. We’d be interacting with the guests that will follow the generations before us that loved the circus, and we’d hopefully inspire them to help keep the art alive as well!What We Need & What You GetWe’re going need your help to get 10 performers to D.C for this 14 day event. We calculated costs and expenses and we’re going to need at least $25,000 to pull this off.$5,000 is what it will cost us to produce costumes and book plane tickets and supply the props needed. The rest of the $20,000 is needed to be part of this event, as it would be going straight to the Smithsonian institutionon our behalf so they can take care of our meals, lodging, and transportation.Here’s the breakdown:
1 Artist for 1 day ( meals + hotel room + transportation while in DC) : $143
1 Artist for 14 days : $2,002
10 Artists for 11 days : $20,002
10 Artists :  Flights to DC, Print materials, Costume parts, Performance Supplies needed : $5,000 (about $500 per artist)
Anything extra left over or above would go towards additional costumes and reimbursing the artist for the 14 days they will be taking off from work.** Please Note **By participating in this festival, our artists would be donating their time to enrich the cultural diversity in America and help lay the foundation for a thriving circus culture. Aside from whatever we raise above our ask, we won’t be making money from this festival. There is no pay for the time or performances at the SFF.Let's Talk Perks!$10 - High Fives!Every little bit counts! You rock! Thank you for helping support the circus.$50 - 50/50!If you are willing to do 50, we are willing to do 50 as well! At this level we will give you a discount code that will take 50% off YOUR ticket price to our next show!(*FYI : Next show is TBA at the moment...)$100 - A Special Thank You!When we get back to Atlanta from the festival, we will send you a few selected photos of the festival along with the review of what we did and how you helped!$150 - Artist 1 Day!At this level, you can help cover the on the ground costs for one artist for one day in DC. The artist you sponsored for this day, will take a photo holding a sign with your name on it and we will post it to our social media as you made this day happen for them! You’ll also receive more photos from the event and a review of what your contribution did for us.$500 - Fly 1 Artist to DC with ancillary costs!At this level, you can help cover the cost of flying one artist and their costume/print material luggage l supplies to DC! You’ll get the above perks and we will make a private photo gallery of our trip that you will have access too while we are in DC! Circus performers always have something up their sleeve, so there’s no knowing what exciting photos you’ll see!$2,002 - Artist for 11 daysAt this level, you can help cover the on the costs for food and lodging for one artist for the 11 days in DC. You’ll get the above perks and while we’re in DC, we will go live on Facebook for one day and take the time to endorse your web page or product with a link.$2,502 - 1 Artist with FlightYou’ll be sponsoring one artist for the full experience. This will cover their flight and all the on ground costs for their 11 days at the National Mall. You’ll get the above perks and the name of the artist you helped cover along with a thank you letter from them!$5,004 - 2 Artists with flightWe like to pair up artists into groups of two for this event to increase their safety and security while on-site in DC. At this level you will be supporting two of the artists to go to DC for the full event! As a perk, you get all of the above AND a bag of tricks--the duo team will get you a circus box of goodies from the 2017 SFF and mail them to you!$10,008 - 4 Artists with FlightsAt this level, you’ll sending two teams of two (four people) to Washington DC for the 11 days! WOW! You’ll get the above perks and two of our performing artist will come to your next event and perform, or give you a private lesson in circus!$20,016 - 8 Artists with FlightAt this rock star level, you’ll be sending four teams of two artists to Washington DC for the 11 days! You’ll get all of our perks and the full team that goes will spell your out name with their bodies while at the National Mall and for a photo opportunity.**10 bodies can only make so many letters, so larger names may have to be photo shopped from two photos.$25,020 - 10 Artist with FlightAt this level, you’ll be the official sponsor of The Imperial OPA Circus for the Smithsonian Folk Festival. You’ll be instrumental to the future success of circus at the festival and the National Endowment of the Arts. Sponsors will get all of the perks above and more. If you are local to our headquarters, we would bring the 10 person team and perform at an event or party of yours. More options are available for sponsors, as we’d be very open to find ways that we can express our gratitude to our sponsors.The ImpactSince 2009, The Imperial OPA Circus has maintained a rich history of producing exciting and fun events in Atlanta, Georgia. We have worked with over 200 variety performing artists to help them earn a living in entertaining hundreds of thousands of people, taught kids and adults and we have had a sizable impact on the entertainment level and growth in Atlanta Georgia.With your help,  we can keep the circus art alive in America. Interfacing with the 1 million+ festival visitors could inspire the many spinoff projects that come from the Folklife festival, but appealing to the National Endowments of the Arts on how they can help circus arts thrive and flourish in the southeast and across the nation could give circus an official place in the performing arts.Beyond these conversations, we will be actively seeking funding to produce additional circus productions and shows, build a better circus school and program, and open a circus cabaret performance space here in Atlanta Georgia where children and adults can watch regular performances.  Everything we do would directly impact the current population of circus and variety artists in Atlanta and the future generations that come after us find the resources that they need to produce shows of their own. Together, we keep circus alive!Risks & ChallengesWe see very little risks in this project and are fully intent on doing it, whether we send one person or the whole group of ten.The Smithsonian has confirmed us to be part of the project already. We are confirming the performing artists who will go and best represent us and polishing the performance pieces we wish to premiere.  If we do not reach our full funding goal, we will use the funds we have to fly as many artist as we can (e.i. If we get $5004, we will bring two people to the event, if we get $10,008 will bring four people, etc.). We are intent on going, it's just with how strong of a voice we will have once we get there.Other Ways You Can HelpWe realize that some can’t help with a financial contribution and this is okay. While the monetary donation is the best course of action, you can help share this campaign with other circus lovers to help raise awareness of the Smithsonian Folklife Festival. Post it to your Facebook, share it on twitter, or even writing a blog article with links to our official website to talk about the festival. More voices will help spread the word of our mission. (Psst, Indiegogo has some pretty good share tools you can use!)If you would like to discuss other ways in which you can help (with an interview, press release, or tax-exempt donation through our fiscal sponsor Fracture Atlas, or who knows what else), we can also make that happen!Thank you. Truly.  Without people like you helping to support circus, this artform could possibly dwindle and die.  When we say “thank you,” it is from our hearts and from the heart of the Circus!With gratitude and and a loud OPA!-Tim--Timothy MackFounder and Creative DirectorWeb | http://theimperialopa.com

story:
Double Vision (or DV, as we affectionately call it) is an all-new, completely original sci-fi comedy musical coming to the 2020 Chicago Musical Theatre Festival (February 3-23, 2020), hosted by Underscore Theatre Company.

Read on to learn more about the show, our team, the mission for this project, and the exclusive perks you’ll be getting when you support our project and join us on this wild, amazing journey!


 


Double Vision an authentic, multilayered character-driven musical primarily told through sci-fi and comedy. Double Vision is creatively led by artists of color and queer/LGBTQIA+ artists, and we also have four amazing actors of color in our lead roles.

The show follows Luke, an astrophysics PhD student, and Sam, an emerging filmmaker, as they try to make their marks on the world. Luke’s and Sam’s worlds mysteriously collide when Luke figures out how to open a wormhole and finds Sam on the other side.

Double Vision is inspired by both classic and contemporary shows like Wicked, RENT, Next to Normal, Kinky Boots, Aida, Dear Evan Hansen, Waitress, and Six. The show is also influenced by retro/80s and contemporary sci-fi like Star Trek, Stargate, Back to the Future, Contact, and Interstellar.

The great thing is, we already have a proven track record of success and artistry—this full-length, 2+ hour show was previously produced at Stanford University in March 2019 with a four-piece band. When we created Double Vision, we set out to show that an amazing musical that doesn’t need to have a glamorous set or expensively-produced content. We’re living proof of that—and now we’re headed to Chicago to up our game!
 


 

You can check out show photos from the March 2019 run (like these photos above!) and learn more about the story on our website at doublevisionthemusical.com. Now, we’re producing the show again, but this time we’re bringing you a freshly, rigorously, and heavily workshopped script and edited score with all-new orchestrations so that Double Vision can be the comedy sci-fi rock musical we (and you!) have dreamed of.

With a sci-fi spin on types of narratives that may have been told plenty of times, the show works to subvert musical theatre norms and bring new content and styles of storytelling to the stage. In the end, we hope that it’s zany, outrageous, and cheesy, but we also hope that it’s heartfelt, emotional, and highly relatable (but perhaps not the part about the wormhole).


 


Meet the Double Vision lead creative and production team! Our incredibly talented team collectively has loads of theatrical and musical experience building towards this show, and we’re ready to make this show amazing for you.
 


 

OLIVIA POPP (Writer and Producer) is a writer and artist based in the Bay Area and a student at Stanford University. She has studied with Straight White Men playwright Young Jean Lee and Pulitzer finalist Amy Freed, and her work was performed at the Kennedy Center in 2015. Olivia served as the 18/19 Artistic Director of the Stanford Asian American Theater Project. One day, she wants to create the perfect cult TV musical.

ZACH BARR (Director) is a freelance director and critic working in the Chicagoland area. He serves as the Literary Associate at Sideshow Theatre Company. He recently directed Littlebrain Theatre’s Bicycle Thieves, part of RhinoFest 2019. Other projects include work with Otherworld Theatre Company, The Agency Theatre Collective, Kokandy Productions, and Studio East (Kirkland, WA). Zach is a graduate of Northwestern University.

JUSTIN CAVAZOS (Music and Vocal Director) is a Chicago-based singer, actor, and guitarist. He served as Music Director and Arranger for Stanford Mixed Company. He has performed in Chicago with Pride Films and Plays, Music Theater Works, Transgressive Theatre-Opera, and Porchlight Music Theater. Justin continues to write and arrange music for a cappella voices, rock band, synthesized instruments, and more.

ERIN COLLINS (Stage Manager) is a proud graduate of The Theatre School at DePaul University, where she received her BFA in Stage Management. Erin spent her first six months post-grad as part of the production management team for the shows on Celebrity Cruises's newest ship, the Celebrity Edge. Most recently, she stage managed Vision Productions's benefit performance of The Trial of Faith and NoMads Art Collective's production of Mr. Kotomoto Is Definitely Not White. Some of Erin's favorite stage management credits include Growing Up Blue; Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play; Michael Jordan in Lilliput; and We Are Proud to Present (The Theatre School).


 


Having the time, space, and resources to make art is a privilege, and we know that. Thus, we have several overarching goals for this production to play our part towards making institutional change in theatre and musical theatre in the Chicago area and beyond.

The show strives to uplift queer/LGBTQIA+ and POC artists in all facets of the project, from the creative team to the cast and from the characters to the storylines. Theatre (and especially musical theatre) is often dominated by white and heteronormative narratives, representation, and creative direction.

Thus, one of our main goals and commitments is to actively disrupt this while also supporting and validating the pursuits, experiences, perspectives, and stories of queer/LGBTQIA+ and POC artists. Now that we’ve got the platform, we’re working towards change by prioritizing this.
 


 

Double Vision hinges upon the portrayal of many different types of love and relationships, including platonic love, romantic love, familial love, love for one’s work, love for one’s life, and love for oneself. The show is threaded with themes of commitment, motivation, love, discovery, and achievement through science fiction and comedic lenses.

Through this show, we’re interested in breaking boundaries and subverting musical theatre tropes through the characters’ uniquely intertwining narratives, the diverse cast and creative team guiding this project, and providing an absurdist and comedic twist on musical theatre.

We hope Double Vision is a new exemplar of what musical theatre could and can be going forward. We’re really proud of the show we're putting on, and we hope you will be too!


 



Producing a show in Chicago isn't cheap—or easy. Thus, every cent goes towards a crucial part of the show—and, of course, making Double Vision even more awesome! We can't do it without you.

Want some examples? With $10—you just printed us some posters. With $50—you rented us rehearsal space for a couple of days. With $100—you put together a fully-orchestrated song. With $250—you just built us a set piece.

Here's a full breakdown of where your contribution will be going.

OUR TEAM: 30%

We’re all about the people!  With industry rates for storefront theatre (small, often festival-geared productions like this one) in Chicago, this covers seven incredibly talented cast members and our wonderfully skilled creative/production team:

  • Director
  • Music/Vocal Director
  • Stage Manager
  • Scenic Designer/Technical Director
  • Costume Designer
  • Marketing Coordinator
     

FESTIVAL FEES: 20%

We couldn’t do it without the festival!  This helps pay for festival costs like the performance space, a festival publicist, and some incredible festival lighting and sound designers. As one of the participating shows in the 2020 Chicago Musical Theatre Festival, we contribute a small part of the operating costs that make this magical festival possible. 
 

MUSIC AND ORCHESTRATIONS: 15%

Hey, it’s a musical!  Therefore, we’re placing a high priority on—you guessed it—our music. Our multi-talented music/vocal director Justin Cavazos is orchestrating and producing instrumental tracks to both simplify the necessary moving parts and flesh out our music at the same time. Our March 2019 workshop had a four-piece band, and we were able to try out and develop our style through this process. Even though it might seem unconventional for a live show, we’re confident in our music and ready to take that next step to a new, bright, and energetic pop/rock-inspired sound. Get ready—we’ll pop/rock your socks off!
 

MARKETING AND DEVELOPMENT: 15%

We’re looking for more than just butts in seats!  Every design and marketing element represents a crucial part of our show, and we want to make sure we do it justice. This covers graphics by our amazing illustrator/graphic designer Olivia Sy, original artwork for postcards and exclusive DV prints (get yours through our PERKS!), and printing costs for all of the above. Underscore helps to publicize the whole festival, but we want to make sure our show stands out and that those excited about our show know about it! With five shows and the opportunity for extended dates, we’re investing this money towards expanding our audience.
 

PRODUCTION DESIGN: 10%

Let's bring it to life!  CMTF isn’t geared towards Broadway-scale design or flashy spectacle. However, this covers just enough to add a splash of color and important aesthetic style to the show, including set, costumes, and props. Double Vision is inspired by retro/80s sci-fi, and we’re a show that involves a wormhole (folks, a wormhole—where else can you find that?). Therefore, our production design costs contribute to tools that we’ll use to make this the sci-fi comedy of our (and your!) dreams.
 

REHEARSAL SPACE: 10%

Practice (rehearsal?) makes perfect!  We’re investing in the success of our show by devoting these funds to a rigorous rehearsal schedule for direction and vocal direction. These costs will be going into renting rehearsal spaces, which cost $10-15 per hour. Now, we know that’s a lot of hours, but we’re ready and excited to put in the work!

 

 


Hitting our initial campaign goal is awesome and gets us to a baseline for the festival, but going beyond is even more amazing! We've set up some stretch goals that support not only the production right now, but also the future and longevity of the show. Plus, as our incredible backers, you get access to even MORE stuff!


Into the MultDVerse: 12.5K STRETCH GOAL!

Bam! You help us record a Double Vision cast album AND hire a videographer to film one of our CMTF performances! This takes Double Vision up a whole notch and provides high-quality materials to show that we can and should be produced elsewhere. Plus, you'll be able to listen to AND watch DV, on-the-go, anytime and anywhere!

With this stretch goal, ALL backers will receive...

  • A digital copy of the Double Vision script, complete with annotated tidbits about jokes, inspiration, references, and more!
  • EARLY ACCESS to the cast album before it is released publicly on streaming platforms!
  • EXCLUSIVE ACCESS to the show recording online!

 

To InfiniDV and Beyond: 15K STRETCH GOAL!

You help us  ~ u p g r a d e ~  our production design and bring our multiverse to a galactic new level. This helps us take our set, costumes, and props from great to AMAZING! Plus, you also help us bring merch and DV SWAG to all of our CMTF shows! Rad!

With this stretch goal, ALL backers will receive...

  • A digital copy of Olivia's SHOW DIARY, which will include polaroids from the rehearsal process, general show musings, irrelevant doodles, to-do lists, and extra special top-secret DV notes!
  • The chance to vote on a song that the cast and creative team will COVER! The video will be available publicly online. :)
     

With this stretch goal, $50+ backers will ALSO receive...

  • A DV SHIRT! Whoa! Now, even if you don't live in Chicago, you'll get an exclusive piece of apparel that you can use to brag to all your friends!

 

 


We're finally at the exciting part—perks! You can read more detailed info about those on the right-hand side for each backer level.

P.S. You may need to click on each perk for detailed info!
Sometimes they don’t show up automatically. We promise we have cool perks! :)

If your perk comes with personalization or something more specific (i.e. original song, sponsor, etc.), we’ll contact you directly for more info. But here are notes about some of our extra awesome perks:

  • SWAG PACK: BTS footage, production photos, creator commentary, old song drafts, and more!
  • DV POSTER/STICKERS: All new stuff from this production! Once we get them printed, we’ll send them straight to you.
  • EXCLUSIVE POSTCARD and PRINT SET: They’ll include original DV artwork made especially for the show!
  • FIRST PRODUCTION POSTER (LIMITED TO 10): We’re signing posters from our very first production in March 2019! They include a spectacular design by the very talented illustrator/graphic designer Kristel Bugayong.
  • ORIGINAL SONG (LIMITED TO 10): You give us a word/phrase/sentence/image/theme, and we’ll craft a completely original song just for you, record it, and send you the digital file. It’ll be awesome!
  • PLAYLIST: We have a bunch of playlists that inspire us (and have inspired this show!) and we’re curating the perfect one to make our extra special MultDVerse playlist so you, too, can listen along with us and rock with that DV vibe.
  • MEETUP: Have coffee or a meal with the creative team! If you don’t live in Chicago, we’re happy to hold a video call with you. And we’ll also send you some of our favorite snacks as if we were actually meeting up in person. :)
  • COMP TICKETS: Whoa! Free tickets to a performance of your choice!
  • SCRIPT/COMPANY PHOTO: We’ll sign them for you and mail them to ya!
  • SPONSOR: You’ll be listed as a sponsor on our website and in our program! Wowie!


If you have any questions about our perks, hit us up at info@doublevisionthemusical.com.


 


We know there are so many other causes out there to monetarily contribute to (like supporting your local QTPOCs, which we also highly recommend!). If you’re unable to contribute financially right now, you can still help in so many other amazing and easy ways:

  • SHARE THIS INDIEGOGO with friends/family and on social media!
    • Pro tip: you can use those handy-dandy social media icons underneath the campaign progress bar!
    • We’d also love it if you added a personal note telling people why you’re excited about DV :)
  • LIKE US and SHARE our content on Facebook!
  • FOLLOW us on Instagram!
  • FOLLOW and RETWEET us on Twitter!
  • CHECK US OUT online (doublevisionthemusical.com)!
  • SPREAD THE WORD by telling all your friends about the show!


Unlike interdimensional beings, we’re not omnipotent! Think you’ve got another way you can help? Hit us up at info@doublevisionthemusical.com.


 


Outside of this fundraiser, we’d love for you to experience the show that YOU helped create by attending! The festival gives us 5 shows to start with, but the number of EXTRA shows we get depends on ticket sales (the sooner we sell out, the more performances we get!). Thus, our goal is to completely sell out by January 1st or earlier so we can get those extra shows! :)

Tickets are NOW AVAILABLE at dime.io/events/cmtf-double-vision!
We only have 100 tickets available per show! Get yours before they're gone!

Double Vision will be performed on the following dates:

  • Tuesday, February 4 at 8 PM
  • Sunday, February 9 at 6 PM
  • Saturday, February 15 at 7:30 PM
  • Wednesday, February 19 at 8 PM
  • Saturday, February 22 at 3 PM


All performances are at The Edge Theater’s Broadway Stage at 5451 N. Broadway St, Chicago, IL 60640.

----

We thank you so, so much in advance for your contribution. Every cent helps!

So...whaddaya say?

*cue Foreigner’s “Double Vision”*
