He has performed in Chicago with Pride Films and Plays, Music Theater Works, Transgressive Theatre-Opera, and Porchlight Music Theater. Justin continues to write and arrange music for a cappella voices, rock band, synthesized instruments, and more.ERIN COLLINS (Stage Manager) is a proud graduate of The Theatre School at DePaul University, where she received her BFA in Stage Management. Erin spent her first six months post-grad as part of the production management team for the shows on Celebrity Cruises's newest ship, the Celebrity Edge. Most recently, she stage managed Vision Productions's benefit performance of The Trial of Faith and NoMads Art Collective's production of Mr. Kotomoto Is Definitely Not White. Some of Erin's favorite stage management credits include Growing Up Blue; Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play; Michael Jordan in Lilliput; and We Are Proud to Present (The Theatre School). Having the time, space, and resources to make art is a privilege, and we know that. Thus, we have several overarching goals for this production to play our part towards making institutional change in theatre and musical theatre in the Chicago area and beyond.The show strives to uplift queer/LGBTQIA+ and POC artists in all facets of the project, from the creative team to the cast and from the characters to the storylines. Theatre (and especially musical theatre) is often dominated by white and heteronormative narratives, representation, and creative direction.Thus, one of our main goals and commitments is to actively disrupt this while also supporting and validating the pursuits, experiences, perspectives, and stories of queer/LGBTQIA+ and POC artists. Now that we’ve got the platform, we’re working towards change by prioritizing this.  Double Vision hinges upon the portrayal of many different types of love and relationships, including platonic love, romantic love, familial love, love for one’s work, love for one’s life, and love for oneself. The show is threaded with themes of commitment, motivation, love, discovery, and achievement through science fiction and comedic lenses.Through this show, we’re interested in breaking boundaries and subverting musical theatre tropes through the characters’ uniquely intertwining narratives, the diverse cast and creative team guiding this project, and providing an absurdist and comedic twist on musical theatre.We hope Double Vision is a new exemplar of what musical theatre could and can be going forward. We’re really proud of the show we're putting on, and we hope you will be too! Producing a show in Chicago isn't cheap—or easy. Thus, every cent goes towards a crucial part of the show—and, of course, making Double Vision even more awesome! We can't do it without you.Want some examples? With $10—you just printed us some posters. With $50—you rented us rehearsal space for a couple of days. With $100—you put together a fully-orchestrated song. With $250—you just built us a set piece.Here's a full breakdown of where your contribution will be going.OUR TEAM: 30%We’re all about the people!  With industry rates for storefront theatre (small, often festival-geared productions like this one) in Chicago, this covers seven incredibly talented cast members and our wonderfully skilled creative/production team:
Director
Music/Vocal Director
Stage Manager
Scenic Designer/Technical Director
Costume Designer
Marketing Coordinator 
FESTIVAL FEES: 20%We couldn’t do it without the festival!  This helps pay for festival costs like the performance space, a festival publicist, and some incredible festival lighting and sound designers. As one of the participating shows in the 2020 Chicago Musical Theatre Festival, we contribute a small part of the operating costs that make this magical festival possible.  MUSIC AND ORCHESTRATIONS: 15%Hey, it’s a musical!  Therefore, we’re placing a high priority on—you guessed it—our music. Our multi-talented music/vocal director Justin Cavazos is orchestrating and producing instrumental tracks to both simplify the necessary moving parts and flesh out our music at the same time. Our March 2019 workshop had a four-piece band, and we were able to try out and develop our style through this process. Even though it might seem unconventional for a live show, we’re confident in our music and ready to take that next step to a new, bright, and energetic pop/rock-inspired sound. Get ready—we’ll pop/rock your socks off! MARKETING AND DEVELOPMENT: 15%We’re looking for more than just butts in seats!  Every design and marketing element represents a crucial part of our show, and we want to make sure we do it justice. This covers graphics by our amazing illustrator/graphic designer Olivia Sy, original artwork for postcards and exclusive DV prints (get yours through our PERKS!), and printing costs for all of the above. Underscore helps to publicize the whole festival, but we want to make sure our show stands out and that those excited about our show know about it! With five shows and the opportunity for extended dates, we’re investing this money towards expanding our audience. PRODUCTION DESIGN: 10%Let's bring it to life!  CMTF isn’t geared towards Broadway-scale design or flashy spectacle. However, this covers just enough to add a splash of color and important aesthetic style to the show, including set, costumes, and props. Double Vision is inspired by retro/80s sci-fi, and we’re a show that involves a wormhole (folks, a wormhole—where else can you find that?). Therefore, our production design costs contribute to tools that we’ll use to make this the sci-fi comedy of our (and your!) dreams. REHEARSAL SPACE: 10%Practice (rehearsal?) makes perfect!  We’re investing in the success of our show by devoting these funds to a rigorous rehearsal schedule for direction and vocal direction. These costs will be going into renting rehearsal spaces, which cost $10-15 per hour. Now, we know that’s a lot of hours, but we’re ready and excited to put in the work!  Hitting our initial campaign goal is awesome and gets us to a baseline for the festival, but going beyond is even more amazing! We've set up some stretch goals that support not only the production right now, but also the future and longevity of the show. Plus, as our incredible backers, you get access to even MORE stuff!
Into the MultDVerse: 12.5K STRETCH GOAL!
Bam! You help us record a Double Vision cast album AND hire a videographer to film one of our CMTF performances! This takes Double Vision up a whole notch and provides high-quality materials to show that we can and should be produced elsewhere. Plus, you'll be able to listen to AND watch DV, on-the-go, anytime and anywhere!With this stretch goal, ALL backers will receive...
A digital copy of the Double Vision script, complete with annotated tidbits about jokes, inspiration, references, and more!
EARLY ACCESS to the cast album before it is released publicly on streaming platforms!
EXCLUSIVE ACCESS to the show recording online!
 To InfiniDV and Beyond: 15K STRETCH GOAL!You help us  ~ u p g r a d e ~  our production design and bring our multiverse to a galactic new level. This helps us take our set, costumes, and props from great to AMAZING! Plus, you also help us bring merch and DV SWAG to all of our CMTF shows! Rad!With this stretch goal, ALL backers will receive...
A digital copy of Olivia's SHOW DIARY, which will include polaroids from the rehearsal process, general show musings, irrelevant doodles, to-do lists, and extra special top-secret DV notes!
The chance to vote on a song that the cast and creative team will COVER! The video will be available publicly online. :) 
With this stretch goal, $50+ backers will ALSO receive...A DV SHIRT! Whoa! Now, even if you don't live in Chicago, you'll get an exclusive piece of apparel that you can use to brag to all your friends!  We're finally at the exciting part—perks! You can read more detailed info about those on the right-hand side for each backer level.P.S. You may need to click on each perk for detailed info!Sometimes they don’t show up automatically. We promise we have cool perks! :)If your perk comes with personalization or something more specific (i.e. original song, sponsor, etc.), we’ll contact you directly for more info. But here are notes about some of our extra awesome perks:

SWAG PACK: BTS footage, production photos, creator commentary, old song drafts, and more!

DV POSTER/STICKERS: All new stuff from this production! Once we get them printed, we’ll send them straight to you.

EXCLUSIVE POSTCARD and PRINT SET: They’ll include original DV artwork made especially for the show!

FIRST PRODUCTION POSTER (LIMITED TO 10): We’re signing posters from our very first production in March 2019! They include a spectacular design by the very talented illustrator/graphic designer Kristel Bugayong.

ORIGINAL SONG (LIMITED TO 10): You give us a word/phrase/sentence/image/theme, and we’ll craft a completely original song just for you, record it, and send you the digital file. It’ll be awesome!

PLAYLIST: We have a bunch of playlists that inspire us (and have inspired this show!) and we’re curating the perfect one to make our extra special MultDVerse playlist so you, too, can listen along with us and rock with that DV vibe.

MEETUP: Have coffee or a meal with the creative team! If you don’t live in Chicago, we’re happy to hold a video call with you. And we’ll also send you some of our favorite snacks as if we were actually meeting up in person. :)

COMP TICKETS: Whoa! Free tickets to a performance of your choice!

SCRIPT/COMPANY PHOTO: We’ll sign them for you and mail them to ya!

SPONSOR: You’ll be listed as a sponsor on our website and in our program! Wowie!
If you have any questions about our perks, hit us up at info@doublevisionthemusical.com. We know there are so many other causes out there to monetarily contribute to (like supporting your local QTPOCs, which we also highly recommend!). If you’re unable to contribute financially right now, you can still help in so many other amazing and easy ways:

SHARE THIS INDIEGOGO with friends/family and on social media!
Pro tip: you can use those handy-dandy social media icons underneath the campaign progress bar!
We’d also love it if you added a personal note telling people why you’re excited about DV :)



LIKE US and SHARE our content on Facebook!

FOLLOW us on Instagram!

FOLLOW and RETWEET us on Twitter!

CHECK US OUT online (doublevisionthemusical.com)!

SPREAD THE WORD by telling all your friends about the show!
Unlike interdimensional beings, we’re not omnipotent! Think you’ve got another way you can help? Hit us up at info@doublevisionthemusical.com. Outside of this fundraiser, we’d love for you to experience the show that YOU helped create by attending! The festival gives us 5 shows to start with, but the number of EXTRA shows we get depends on ticket sales (the sooner we sell out, the more performances we get!). Thus, our goal is to completely sell out by January 1st or earlier so we can get those extra shows! :)Tickets are NOW AVAILABLE at dime.io/events/cmtf-double-vision!We only have 100 tickets available per show! Get yours before they're gone!Double Vision will be performed on the following dates:
Tuesday, February 4 at 8 PM
Sunday, February 9 at 6 PM
Saturday, February 15 at 7:30 PM
Wednesday, February 19 at 8 PM
Saturday, February 22 at 3 PM
All performances are at The Edge Theater’s Broadway Stage at 5451 N. Broadway St, Chicago, IL 60640.----We thank you so, so much in advance for your contribution. Every cent helps!So...whaddaya say?*cue Foreigner’s “Double Vision”*

story:
Invierte en teatro peruano

Somos La Teatrera, una nueva productora de comedias peruanas que financia el 20% de sus montajes teatrales y giras gracias al financiamiento colectivo. Como "la plata no llega sola" (ni del Estado ni de la empresa privada), contamos con el patrocinio de múltiples inversionistas amantes del teatro peruano.

Ahora nos encontramos en la búsqueda de nuevos patrocinadores para llevar a escena esta innovadora comedia teatral que protagoniza Babe Tercero, un cerdo de alcurnia y pedigree, que tiene una mejor vida que la de muchos mortales.

El dinero recaudado (dos mil dólares) cubrirá la quinta parte (20%) de nuestro presupuesto total (10 mil dólares) y será destinado a los gastos de diseño de arte, realización de escenografía, iluminación y vestuario, además de cubrir el alquiler de la sala de ensayos.

¿Cómo puedes apoyar?

Contamos con diversas recompensas para todos aquellos que nos apoyen: un meet & greet que incluye un almuerzo exclusivo con los actores en el marco de la Copa América y polos/poleras con el diseño de nuestro cerdo mascota. Además, clases de cocina, cena privada con los actores, entradas de regalo, afiche firmado por elenco y merchandising de la obra. Puedes donar desde un dólar ($ 1) hasta quinientos dólares ($ 500), con una tarjeta de crédito o débito de cualquier banco en cualquier parte del mundo.  

Tu colaboración a este proyecto será sustentado ante SUNAT (entidad que fiscaliza los tributos en Perú). "Los cerdos no miran al cielo” es producida por La Teatrera S.A.C. con RUC 20603421672, en la que cada ingreso y egreso estará registrado. 

Nuestra exitosa experiencia

Ya antes lo hemos logrado con la comedia Tu madre, La Concho, que gracias al apoyo de más de 40 patrocinadores continúa por tercer año consecutivo en la cartelera teatral de Lima, rumbo a su función 100, con cuatro temporadas en cinco teatros de lima y disfrutada por más de 12 mil personas quienes celebraron a mamá con teatro.   

¡Sé un vocero de nuestra campaña!

Búscanos en las redes sociales de "La Teatrera" (Facebook e Instagram) y corre la voz de nuestra campaña “La plata no llega sola: Invierte en teatro peruano" Necesitamos que más amantes del arte y la cultura se sumen a esta causa.     

Los expertos la recomiendan

"La comedia es música y Los cerdos no miran al cielo es un texto muy bien logrado por el autor, una obra de teatro que pasea al espectador (con un valioso ritmo y timing), por un mundo de enredos de principio a fin." July Naters - Directora de teatro y televisión

"Muchos dramaturgos se forjan una carrera a punta de inteligencia y trabajo. Otros –son poquitos— tienen talento.  Carlos Portugal, por ejemplo.  Su primerísima obra me hizo saber que Carlos quería correr riesgos artísticos inmensos para salir triunfante. Sus demás obras corroboran esta impresión. Estamos ante un excelente dramaturgo peruano. Felicitémonos." Alonso Alegría - Director del Vivero de Dramaturgia

"Es una comedia con potencial de convertirse en un éxito del teatro independiente limeño. ¿Querías una historia de narcos peruana? Aquí está." Alejandro Clavier - Director del Festival de Teatro Sala de Parto

 

Sobre la obra

Dos periodistas emprendedores, el capo más poderoso del Perú y el cerdo más caro del mundo conforman la obra “Los Cerdos no miran al cielo”, donde dos comunicadores deciden salir de la pobreza con una revista dedicada a la narcocultura, un negocio millonario que los meterá en la boca del lobo cuando uno de ellos se enamora de la esposa de El Cauchero: el capo más temido de la selva peruana, que solo tiene cabeza para Babe Tercero, el cerdo mascota más caro del mundo.

Ficha artística
Dramaturgia: Carlos Portugal
Dirección: Kathy Serrano
Producción general: La Teatrera/Ángelo Condemarín
Elenco: Natalia Salas, Braulio Chappell, Micky Moreno, Alain Salinas y Lolo Balbín.
Estreno: 14 de setiembre
Lugar: Teatro del Centro de la Amistad Peruano - China

Sobre La Teatrera
Somos una productora de comedias peruanas comprometida con innovar la industria cultural y llevar a escena historias de alta calidad que generen una experiencia positiva en el público.

story:
Awkward Conversations with Animals I've F*cked

"Unashamedly provocative and unquestionably memorable" - The Stage

"Really enjoyed. Linus Karp was great" - Edgar Wright 

One-night stands are awkward. One-night stands with animals are more awkward. And when you're as desperate to please as Bobby, things get awkward as fuck. He's just a guy with too much love to give, and a burning desire to give it to consensual adult mammals. Reuniting the creative team from the previous runs - Linus Karp returns to the role directed by Katharine Armitage.

A one-man tragi-comedy, Rob Hayes’ play is a disturbing psychological examination of loneliness. The production tackles mental health, focusing on how toxic masculinity can undermine loving and healthy social connections, while also illustrating the absurdity of society’s treatment of animals. 

"Funny and unsettling" - Mark Gatiss 

"Strangely moving" - Edgar Wright 

"A Fringe hit" - Time Out 

"A sensitive and nuanced performance" - The Stage

"Hilarious" - Gay Times

⭐ ⭐ ⭐ ⭐ ⭐ -  London Theatre 1

⭐ ⭐ ⭐ ⭐ ⭐  -  Everything Theatre

And 14 other ⭐ ⭐ ⭐ ⭐ reviews 

 

Who Are We?

My name is Linus Karp and I am Artistic Director of Awkward Productions, a company committed to exploring contemporary writing and bringing controversial and taboo subjects to the forefront of our dramatic culture. 'Awkward Conversations with Animals I've F*cked' is the perfect example of just that. It puts an unseen voice centre-stage and challenges our audiences to question their perceptions throughout our hour long dark-comedy.

I first encountered this play on a bookshelf in London and I fell in love straight away. I bought it, read it, and re-read all in one evening. It was unlike anything I had ever encountered before and I knew I had to bring this text to life. I first performed the one-hour monologue in The Lion and Unicorn Theatre in London, a small venue above a pub, where it received an overwhelmingly positive reception. Reviews were filled with praise, and the wonderful Mark Gatiss came to the show and described  it as "funny and unsettling". 

In August 2018 we were invited by Underbelly to perform at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival where we enjoyed sold-out shows to raving audiences. Following our success in Edinburgh we had a London transfer to the renowned King's Head Theatre in Islington for a three week run in Spring 2019. Edgar Wright saw the show and had this to say...

Requests soon started coming in from venues across the country and we knew we had take our production and this thought-provoking story on tour.

Coming from Sweden and working as an actor in a second language as well as being a queer artist, the roles available to me are often limited or stereotyped. However, I have been able to thrive in this production. Amidst Brexit chaos and a continued struggle over LGBTQIA+ rights, this production puts a queer European centre-stage for our audiences. This tour is an opportunity for us to bring this incredible piece of work outside of a London-centric theatre scene and share it across the breadth of the UK, but we can only do it with your support!

 

Why This Production?

So far, I have self-funded the first three runs of this show however, while we have enjoyed success, financially it has been very difficult. This tour will be the biggest outing of the show so far and I need your help to make it a reality. My fantastic production team and I are eager to see this show on tour. I have always made sure that everybody working for me has been paid a fair wages for their work and want guarantee this for a tour. 

What we need is financial support in order to secure a decent wage for the creatives involved, transportation for the cast and crew as well as our set and technical equipment, petrol, accommodation and marketing.

Realistically we need £3,200 in order to cover all of our expenses and guarantee that the show will be the best that it can be. I have been working for the past few months in order to pay for the venues, the rights to perform the play, and secure our director and producer for this run - all of which have already been paid for. This Indiegogo is going to help propel the show to even greater heights as I cannot fund the entire project alone.

We're excited to offer a wide range of perks for all of our contributors, ranging from personalised postcards from the theatres we visit to Executive Producer credits on the final production. Make sure to check out everything we have on offer to see what suits you best!

We're hoping to achieve our goals during the lead up to this production but we're prepared to work on a smaller budget if need be. We want to give this show the best space, materials and technical support to demonstrate everything it has to say in the most powerful and gripping way for our audiences.

 

The Impact

"Hayes rampant exploration of loneliness, mental health and bestiality will have you moved whilst wetting yourself with laughter" - Voice Magazine 

We're bringing a successful and acclaimed production that discusses both toxic masculinity and the effects of loneliness on a young man's mental health. This is a production that interrogates the relationship between fathers and sons, tackling how emotional abuse can impact and negatively affect the development of one's sense of self.

"my companion to the show, and I had a lengthy discussion afterwards about Awkward Conversations... if we hadn’t had to part for our separate trains, I think we could still be discussing Bobby and his actions now." - London Theatre 1

In bringing this production across the UK, we're hoping to provoke discussions amongst our audience while at the same time using humour as a bridge to make the uncomfortable topics within the play easily accessible. There is no other play like this to be found on the UK theatre scene at the moment. 

This production has already thrived in London and Edinburgh with five star reviews and sold-out performances, we only expect it to soar to new heights on tour! 

 

Risks & Challenges

Going on tour, we will be taking the show to new cities where we don't have an immediate audience. However, we have a strong social media campaign and we are working with each theatre's marketing department in order to get the word out about the show before we arrive. We want to make sure that we are engaging with audiences from all walks of life as we know that this production has universal messages that everyone can connect to. 

As we already have a finished production that is cast, designed, and ready to go, as well as venues already booked across the UK, we are in a very strong position to see this show succeed.

 

I Can't Donate But I Want To Contribute

We completely understand if you can't make a financial donation but there are still a ton of ways you can help support this project!

1) You can share this campaign on your social media platforms. 

2) You can follow us on social media so you can stay up to date on Awkward Conversations as we travel the country. We're @AwkwardProds on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.

3) If we're not coming to a theatre near you and you want to see us there, tweet your local theatres that you want to see us there!

4) Last but not least, come and see our performances across Autumn 2019! We want to share this piece with you and we cannot wait for you to see it.

Requests soon started coming in from venues across the country and we knew we had take our production and this thought-provoking story on tour.
Coming from Sweden and working as an actor in a second language as well as being a queer artist, the roles available to me are often limited or stereotyped. However, I have been able to thrive in this production. Amidst Brexit chaos and a continued struggle over LGBTQIA+ rights, this production puts a queer European centre-stage for our audiences. This tour is an opportunity for us to bring this incredible piece of work outside of a London-centric theatre scene and share it across the breadth of the UK, but we can only do it with your support!
 

Why This Production?
So far, I have self-funded the first three runs of this show however, while we have enjoyed success, financially it has been very difficult. This tour will be the biggest outing of the show so far and I need your help to make it a reality. My fantastic production team and I are eager to see this show on tour. I have always made sure that everybody working for me has been paid a fair wages for their work and want guarantee this for a tour. 
What we need is financial support in order to secure a decent wage for the creatives involved, transportation for the cast and crew as well as our set and technical equipment, petrol, accommodation and marketing.

Realistically we need £3,200 in order to cover all of our expenses and guarantee that the show will be the best that it can be. I have been working for the past few months in order to pay for the venues, the rights to perform the play, and secure our director and producer for this run - all of which have already been paid for. This Indiegogo is going to help propel the show to even greater heights as I cannot fund the entire project alone.
We're excited to offer a wide range of perks for all of our contributors, ranging from personalised postcards from the theatres we visit to Executive Producer credits on the final production. Make sure to check out everything we have on offer to see what suits you best!
We're hoping to achieve our goals during the lead up to this production but we're prepared to work on a smaller budget if need be. We want to give this show the best space, materials and technical support to demonstrate everything it has to say in the most powerful and gripping way for our audiences.
 

The Impact
"Hayes rampant exploration of loneliness, mental health and bestiality will have you moved whilst wetting yourself with laughter" - Voice Magazine 
We're bringing a successful and acclaimed production that discusses both toxic masculinity and the effects of loneliness on a young man's mental health. This is a production that interrogates the relationship between fathers and sons, tackling how emotional abuse can impact and negatively affect the development of one's sense of self.
"my companion to the show, and I had a lengthy discussion afterwards about Awkward Conversations... if we hadn’t had to part for our separate trains, I think we could still be discussing Bobby and his actions now." - London Theatre 1
In bringing this production across the UK, we're hoping to provoke discussions amongst our audience while at the same time using humour as a bridge to make the uncomfortable topics within the play easily accessible. There is no other play like this to be found on the UK theatre scene at the moment. 
This production has already thrived in London and Edinburgh with five star reviews and sold-out performances, we only expect it to soar to new heights on tour! 
 

Risks & Challenges
Going on tour, we will be taking the show to new cities where we don't have an immediate audience. However, we have a strong social media campaign and we are working with each theatre's marketing department in order to get the word out about the show before we arrive. We want to make sure that we are engaging with audiences from all walks of life as we know that this production has universal messages that everyone can connect to. 
As we already have a finished production that is cast, designed, and ready to go, as well as venues already booked across the UK, we are in a very strong position to see this show succeed.
 

I Can't Donate But I Want To Contribute
We completely understand if you can't make a financial donation but there are still a ton of ways you can help support this project!
1) You can share this campaign on your social media platforms. 
2) You can follow us on social media so you can stay up to date on Awkward Conversations as we travel the country. We're @AwkwardProds on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.
3) If we're not coming to a theatre near you and you want to see us there, tweet your local theatres that you want to see us there!
4) Last but not least, come and see our performances across Autumn 2019! We want to share this piece with you and we cannot wait for you to see it.

story:
Short Summary

When Nathanael Lee (producer, director & actor) approached me (Zabet NeuCollins) to help him co-produce The Mystery of Irma Vep - A Penny Dreadful by Charles Ludlam, I was a little hesitant. It wasn't because the play didn't capture my attention -- quite the contrary! Reading the script had me giggling uncontrollably. No, I was more worried that the play would be too much of a production for us to put on. Both Nathanael and I have a very high standard in the work that we create. How could we expect to put on a professional show, up to our own standards, with our limited budget and resources? However, Nathanael was persistent and he soon convinced me that it was worth a shot.

It is without doubt that Nathanael's enthusiasm has got us where we are today. However, to my amazement, local actors and artists stepped out of the woodwork to support us in this venture. Ed Dillon, the set designer, is ingenious! To our first production meeting (literally just a "meet-and-greet"), he brought miniature cardboard cutouts of the set! Thomas VanGorder, the other actor, brings levity to every rehearsal. And there are more:  Kate, the stage manager, Stephanie, the costume designer, Chuck the sound designer, Didi on lights, Mark the music-score man and Garrett, the poster designer. What's that saying? "If you want to go fast, go alone; but if you want to go far, go together."

We are so excited to be able to produce this show with the help of the Criterion Theatre in Bar Harbor, Maine. However, we are in need of $1500 to help us cover expenses such as rights, costumes, and stage props. With your help, we'll be able to make this show a top quality production that we all enjoy being a part of.

What We Need

The bulk of the money we fund-raise will go to the custom set Ed Dillon is creating, along with prop-pieces and furniture items we purchase to decorate the stage. The remainder will go towards custom-made costumes. This play has eight characters but only two actors, resulting in many  quick costume changes. Simple costumes that at the same time depict characters of different genders and statures are hard to find: that is why all our costumes will be custom made by Stephanie Urquhart.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if a financial donation is out of the question, we can sure use your help! First and foremost, please spread the word about our project. We would love to see you, your family, your friends, and your acquaintances in the audience!

Second, we are on the look out for stage-hands and any back-stage helpers that can assist us during the actual performance(s) to change the set, help with costume changes, and more. Please contact us if this is something you'd be interested in!

--

 

And that's about it! Thank you for supporting us!

story:
Summary

Kenneth Walker Dance Project is in the planning stages of its first ever story ballet, Carmen.  Carmen will debut in the Summer of 2020. 

  • KWDP is a contemporary ballet company based in LA.
  • We're raising funds to make this momentous event happen. 
  • We begin rehearsals in March 2020 and need to have primary funding in place by then.
    • Why do we need funding in place by then?  Our design team leads enough time to create costumes and design lighting for the show.  Getting them involved at the beginning is hugely important to the success of this show.
  • Creating this dance marks a new level of growth and achievement for our company.
  • We are your local company. 
    • Homegrown and representing the diversity of LA.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

  • We are looking to raise $3,000 with this campaign. 
  • 3K is the amount we have budgeted for new costumes for this dance.
  • Some of the perks associated with the campaign include:
    • KWDP shirts

      • T-shirts

      • Tickets

      • Open rehearsal

      • Pre-performance backstage tour

The Impact

  • Premiering this work announces to the dance community that we have arrived.
  • Doing bigger works like Carmen helps our dancers grow as performers. 
  • Your donations help KWDP continue its mission and we rely on our individual donors more than corporate or government funding. 

Risks & Challenges

Bigger dances means more rehearsals, more costumes, more dancers.  This all means more money.  But....

  • We are confident that our version of this tragic tale with be an instant classic and
  • We will be able to sell more tickets than before helping to achieve our goals of increasing our earned revenues. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute?

  • We ask that you help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • We always need volunteers to help make our vision come true.  Email us and ask how you can volunteer to help on show day to make it run smoothly.
  • We're also looking for board members.  Joining the board gives you an opportunity to help steer the company into the future.

Thank you for your continued support

story:
Requiem for Aleppo; A new theatre production born from a simple desire to help

Towards the end of 2016, many of us were staring in distress at our TV screens, feeling overwhelmed and angered by the loss of life in Syria. We watching those scenes of devastation, seeing a rich history and civilisation turn to rubble.  We felt deeply affect and compelled to 'do something'.

As artists, we turned to our crafts. David, our creator and composer, wrote a haunting piece of music combining Requiem Mass lyrics set to choral music, linked by Arabic poetry from the 11th, 12th and 13th centuries and spoken testament from the people of Aleppo.

And I, Jason, the choreographer, took this music and filled it with dance that reflected how I felt when I witnessed this suffering and despair. We put out a call to the international dance community and over 500 dancers responded. Carefully, we whittled this selection down to the final 12 dancers, assembled a fantastic Creative Team and Requiem for Aleppo, the production, was born.

 

Our Aim - to create a Dance & Music Tour which would:

  1. Express our solidarity for the Syrian people
  2. Give voice to the people of Aleppo
  3. Raise awareness about the ongoing situation in Syria
  4. Raise funds to help the Syrian people rebuild their lives and their futures

We are now partnered with two charities profoundly helping Syrian civilians and refugees; Syria Relief and Techfugees. These charities will receive all ticket proceeds from our premiere at Sadler's Wells Theatre on 23 April, 2017 and the subsequent tour; hence we are looking to the public to help fund the costs of the production.

 

What We Need to Succeed

We have been working relentlessly to secure financial investment for the production, and we are sincerely grateful to the following establisments for the encouragement and support that have shown us whilst we quickly transformed Requiem for Aleppo from an idea to a full-scale production;  Sadler's Wells, The Linbury Trust, Rambert School of Ballet and Contemporary Dance, Candoco Dance Company and the Saïd Foundation - we thank you.

Now we must raise the remaining £20,000 needed to cover the following production costs:

  • light and sound engineering
  • costume and set design
  • rehearsal space hire
  • insurance
  • ticket office administration
  • music production
  • stage management
  • security

 

Your Ongoing Impact

As listed above, your contribution will go towards our production expenses, however it will in turn do so much more. Each donation we receive will help us prepare for our UK tour. The more performances we put on, the more money we will raise for the people of Syria.

We have successfully secured a place at the Edinburgh Festival in August 2017 and are currently in talks with several other major festivals and theatres around Britain. 

 

Our Thanks to You

As our way of saying Thanks for each contribution, we have devised a list of perks that both publicly recognise your philanthropy and leave with you with timeless means of enjoying the beautiful music and choreography from Requiem for Aleppo.

These perks range from the Digital Album of our original score, to a Personalised Thank You message on a Digital Recordings of the Premiere, to a Dance Workshop with myself (Jason Mabana) and an opportunity to Meet the Cast, Creative Team, members of our charities partners Syria Relief and Techfugees, and David and I at the premiere after-party.

 

Want to help more? Be our Ambassador

There are several ways you can help Requiem for Aleppo on it's journey to creating ongoing financial support and awareness for the people of Syria.

  • Come and see the show! Tickets on sale now through Sadler's Wells Theatre
  • Like us on Facebook and Twitter and share our page with your friends and family
  • Spread news of this Crowdfunding campaign far and wide!

 

Please Support Requiem for Aleppo Today.

Thank you.

story:
CLUB SOL PARTY- THE BIRTH

Adam, Mark, Nic and Nicky met in the winter of 2012 while working on NewsRevue (Canal Cafe Theatre). Their chemistry was instant so when their run of the show was over they continued to meet, eventually writing an early format of what is now CLUB SOL PARTY. 

Club Sol Party went on to debut at The Canal Cafe Theatre to a sold out audience. It then moved closer into town to The Leicester Square Theatre where it also enjoyed a sold out run. The party then headed to Latitude festival playing on their comedy/cabaret stage. The Club Sol reps were in demand and began organising and delivering bespoke comedy events, parties and corporate gigs including organising Summer parties for regular clients Virgin Holidays.

The show is also well known for  giving notable cabaret and comedy performers the opportunity to come down and show what they've got at Club Sol's monthly comedy residency at the prestigious Century Club and various nights at the awesome Bethnal Green Working Men's Club.  

So... After years of waiting the time is ripe, the show is ready and the Club Sol Reps are primed...they are taking the party to the EDINBURGH FRINGE FESTIVAL! 

What all this means...

We have always been more into giving than receiving ;-) and trust us if we didn't need help we wouldn't be asking....

Although we have been paid a little in the past, believe it or not its hugely hard to break even in this field. We always insist on paying our acts and anyone that helps on our events (even if it's not much) but this doesn't leave us with a huge amount to embark on future projects. We have decided to go up with the 'Free Fringe' and although this keeps venue costs down there is still a huge amount of outgoings... Some of these are listed below: 

Travel Costs

Acts Expenses

Technical Costs

Rent! 

Props and Costumes

OBVIOUSLY we are not in this for the money... It's the LOVE of performing a show we know brings joy to so many people combined with giving other acts the opportunity to do their thing that fills us with MEGA CLUB SOL LOVE! However there are bases we need to cover and things we can't avoid paying for.

Other Ways to help... 

Got no money? We geddit... Neither have we...

1.... Please spread the word, tell your friends, your family, yo HAIRDRESSER etc

2..... Follow us on Social Media

INSTA: ClubSolReps 

Twitter: @ClubSolReps 

Facebook: @ClubSolParty 

OR COME SEE US..... 

We will be hosting a fundraising event at Bethnal Green Working Mens Club on the 19th May: 

https://www.tickettailor.com/checkout/view-even...

We will be hitting EdFest 2017: 

https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/club-sol-...

 

THANKS FOR STOPPING BY... We hope you HOLIDAY with us soon 

 

Your Mauve Coats x

story:
Yes, and..The Beginning

Back in 2009, at the dawn of the Improv Era in Bulgaria, 5 enthusiasts who just graduated the National Academy of Theatre and Film Arts, started improvising in a park. A few months later they hosted their first performance in the hallway of a rundown community center built in the 1930s. Out of the 40 invitees, 20 people showed up. You know it was before Facebook events were a thing in Bulgaria too.
They did short form improv - fast and fun.
In 2013, after a successful run in the 150 seat venue of the same community center, one of these enthusiasts - Zlatin - created the first longform improv company - ShiZi Pro.
Now we are a growing community of improvisers, striving to create a variety of improv shows. Fast, fun, deep, meaningful, happy, with music, without music, in rhyme, but always in the rhythm of cooperation, trust, support and teamwork (group mind).  

In the last 8 years, more that 300 people of all ages and backgrounds were introduced to the art of improv via our training center.

Yes, and...The Dream

The community center "Slavyanska Beseda" did an essential role in nurturing the growth of improv in Bulgaria. Initially, when improv was unknown to Bulgarians, the center provided rehearsal space and the 150 seat venue rent-free. It has been a home for improv shows ever since. 

Unfortunately, it hasn't been renovated for more than 12 years. The entrance and the staircase are in bad condition. So is the electrical system and the lights. Most needed is the replacement of the seats in the main venue and the repainting of the lobby, which will become a dedicated stage for improv performances. 

We dream of opening the First Improv Comedy Club in Sofia at the very heart of the community center. It will host newly formed groups, both long and short form shows, seminars to spread the word of improv and much more. A place to relax and read a book about improv during the day or be inspired by an imaginative show at night. Where you can meet like minded collaborative "yes, and"-ing individuals. A place worthy of hosting an International Improv Festival in Sofia, Bulgaria. 

Yes, and...What We Need

At the end of July, we are getting ready to start the renovation of "Slavyanska Beseda".  It will be a group effort by both the community center and the improv community.
Part of the funding will go directly into creating the first stage in Sofia, Bulgaria, dedicated to the art of improv.  

We were allowed to transform part of the center into a flourishing and cosy, improv-infused and inspiring Improv Comedy Club. The go-to place for improvisers in Sofia, Bulgaria.

We need to fix the lightning, the sound and the electrical systems, to repaint and refurnish it and to build a performance corner. 

We will be needing 8000$. We have already started a campaign in Bulgaria to gather additional funding, but we need all the support we can get. 

Yes, and...Why we do it?

Improv has made and continues to make tremendous impact in our lives. By creating a home for improv comedy in Sofia, our dream is to introduce more people to this wonderful art form and plant the seeds of positivity and nonjudgmental, collaborative and creative thinking. 

Yes, and...What else can you do? 

Even if you can't contribute, you can always support us. Just share our cause to your local improv community. Get the word out, help us open the FIRST IMPROV COMEDY CLUB in Sofia. 

And that's all there is to it. Yes and...

A place to relax and read a book about improv during the day or be inspired by an imaginative show at night. Where you can meet like minded collaborative "yes, and"-ing individuals. A place worthy of hosting an International Improv Festival in Sofia, Bulgaria. 

Yes, and...What We Need
At the end of July, we are getting ready to start the renovation of "Slavyanska Beseda".  It will be a group effort by both the community center and the improv community.Part of the funding will go directly into creating the first stage in Sofia, Bulgaria, dedicated to the art of improv.  
We were allowed to transform part of the center into a flourishing and cosy, improv-infused and inspiring Improv Comedy Club. The go-to place for improvisers in Sofia, Bulgaria.
We need to fix the lightning, the sound and the electrical systems, to repaint and refurnish it and to build a performance corner. 
We will be needing 8000$. We have already started a campaign in Bulgaria to gather additional funding, but we need all the support we can get. 

Yes, and...Why we do it?
Improv has made and continues to make tremendous impact in our lives. By creating a home for improv comedy in Sofia, our dream is to introduce more people to this wonderful art form and plant the seeds of positivity and nonjudgmental, collaborative and creative thinking. 

Yes, and...What else can you do? 
Even if you can't contribute, you can always support us. Just share our cause to your local improv community. Get the word out, help us open the FIRST IMPROV COMEDY CLUB in Sofia. 
And that's all there is to it. Yes and...

story:
A new play by Andy Paterson, writer of the critically acclaimed play 3000 Trees: The Death of Mr William MacRae - the story of the assassination of SNP politician Willie MacRae in 1985.

Paterson takes another swipe at the heart of a corrupt Establishment in this fast paced two-hander with unexpected twists. On the evening Home Secretary Archie Cornwall celebrates the passing of new, tougher sentencing guidelines for convicted paedophiles, he is visited by his former lover, tabloid newspaper editor Fiona Myles. Meanwhile, in South London. a road rage incident has escalated into a shooting, leaving five people dead. 

Instead of enjoying an evening of celebration, Archie finds himself in the eye of the storm as Fiona reveals what she knows about his afternoon gatherings at his Mayfair flat, his connection with the South London shootings and a former children's home. But will Archie be hanged on his own gallows, or is he too powerful to be toppled?

Reflecting the climate created by current historic abuse cases, Paterson's new play takes a sometimes darkly comedic look at the culture of entitlement within the Westminster establishment as it struggles to deal with potentially damaging revelations.

Andy's first play, 3000 Trees: The Death of Mr William MacRae, has been touring since its first sold-out Edinburgh Fringe run in 2014 and has gathered a cult following that will keep it touring for many years to come.

3000 Trees: The Death of Mr William MacRae has received 4 and 5 star reviews and was given 'Outstanding Show' by Fringereview.com.

The funding being sought will allow Sex Offence to progress into its full run at this year's Edinburgh Fringe. We still have a funding shortfall of some £5000 for this play, We really hope that some of you can help. Sponsorship deals are still available also at this stage.

We are confident that Sex Offence will be popular with critics and audience alike. The show, along with 3000 Trees: The Death of Mr William MacRae is being promoted by The Stand (Salt 'N' Sauce Promotions).

Over the last three years we have taken plays around the country to non-theatre venues and theatres alike - without public funding funding we have reached audiences in some of the most remote parts of the country. In Spring of 2018, we will tour Sex Offence in the same way. Funding the fringe show will also assist in kick starting that tour. Please help us continue this work.

Andy has a track record in delivering small scale touring theatre with 3000 Trees, Iain Heggie's The Tobacco Merchant's Lawyer and his new show about the Croatian War of Independence Arizona Market: A Soldier's Story.

Andy Paterson trained as an actor at Royal Conservatoire of Scotland after a varied career in journalism, design and music.

story:
The story so far

Hello, I am Michael B. Judkins, and I would like to introduce you to my poetry collection, Interlude to Sentimental Me! It is the second in the Sentimental Me series and was released by aois21 publishing in May 2016. As I traveled promoting my book and reading my poetry, I decided that I wanted to do something more. After working with a playwright, we have turned the section Mercury Rising into a stage production, bringing my work to a new medium and a new audience. Help me as we bring my work to the stage!

Judkins announced December 1st on his Facebook page that Union Baptist Church- Brother Knoxley and the Youth committee will be the first venue to host the stage play production. With that information known, Judkins will be holding a table read for script review and such prior to announcing open auditions in January 2018. 

What We Need & What You Get

Creative writing process-                                    

  • Create script with playwright-
  • Edits/ revisions/ creative read
  • Rewrites ( if needed) review period ( Hire someone to review for validity)

Production-

  • Review venues- stage/ rehearsal spaces
  • lighting / staging/ design(  props/ no props/)
  • Hire creative director/ director/
  • Production company- video production- ( IFC productions)
  • Insurance

Actors- Crew-

  • Consider roles( certain people in mind) Pitch
  • Local theatre actors/ community based
  • Auditions - casting call - Est- 5- 7, male/females
  • Insurance

Funding-

  • Secure funding aspects ( crowdfunding support, sponsorships, endorsements, family, friends)
  • Fundraising efforts

Marketing/ promotions-

  • Press release
  • radio / local TV/ Social media campaigns
  • Word of mouth
  • Video marketing( such as: advertising, print
  • Marketing efforts ranging depending on media outlets used and overall marketing time frames- Est total budget ( projecting) $ 1,500.-$2,000 )

Distribution-

  • Video distribution options
  • Streaming options/ Pay per view

Music-

  • Music director/ songs for record and stage
  • Musicians - Vocals, recording artist for record.
  • Studio / recording costs- productions
  • Consider either EP- 4 tracks or LP- 8 tracks-
  • Agreements-
  • Collection of music

The Impact

By bringing Michael's poetry to the stage, it exposes his work to a whole new audience. On top of that, it will provide opportunities for new actors and stage hands. The theater may draw new attention that may lead to further productions. On top of all of this is the experience that will be earned from producing such an endeavor.

Risks & Challenges

Creating a stage production requires a lot more moving parts than a book of poetry. With more people involved, it allows more challenges and room for mistakes. By keeping a tight schedule and vision for the production, we can limit the chance for errors.

We have a back up plan for video release if a stage production becomes impossible. Other concessions can be made to economize the project.

Other Ways You Can Help

Every donation gets us closer to our goal, but so does your ability to like, share, or comment on this campaign. Help spread the word! Our network of friends and supporter can only get us so far. Use your social media to share the campaign, let us know what you think. We can only succeed with you!

story:
Helmed by some of the area's best-known stage directors, and starring some of its most promising up-and-coming actors, this free event will feature original works from The Detroit Playwrights’ Lab  ("The Lab").

The Lab was launched at the Detroit Repertory Theatre on July 25, 2016, as a forum for area playwrights to come together and hear their works read. Meeting twice a month, The Lab strives to provide a positive and productive atmosphere for both experienced and aspiring writers to integrate, learn, and grow. As such, we support and nurture the full creative development of our unique individual voices through peer evaluation, writing exercises, group visits to various theater events and other related undertakings to benefit our individual skill and confidence as viable playwrights. 

Our upcoming summer showcase, the first of more to come, will present 10-minute plays and excerpts written by our members to help expose and cultivate their developing projects, with the goal of helping them to craft production-worthy works.

story:
Short Summary/ Sommaire

Babellodrome:

BABELLODROME is a multimedia and multi-lingual audience participatory show presented by the collective collectif BUS 1.2.3. with the participation of the Element choir and Choeur Maha. The site-specific interactive performance looks at the following question: in today's globalized media chaos, in a world where fiction and reality (real and virtual) collide with "alternative facts" and "fake news", what is our own reality ... how do we define ourselves when confronted with commercial and political propaganda that tells us what to believe? Combining poetry, humour and fantasy, this show tackles the question in a series of scenes combining dia- logue, visuals, live music and audience participation.

Large-scale video projections and live music make it a unique and intriguing show that can inspire the imagi- nation of audiences of all ages. The performance is in the form of a journey, a procession along a path, tra- velling from one scene to another, It follows characters who are sometimes humourous, sometimes mythical, and who while in search of their identity, live through multiple technological and linguistic challenges: pro- blems of communication, erroneous translations, senseless games and fake ads. When they finally reach their destination, they rediscover their true nature, free of all media artifice: a return to their essence.

This piece is inspired by Argentinian author Jorge Luis Borges' short story "Library of Babel". We feel it's im- portant because it continues the dialogue about the immigrant experience shifting between cultures, and ex- plores the complexities of language, communication and identity.
Babellodrome est un spectacle francophone participatif, multimédia et multilingue présenté par le collectif BUS 1.2.3. en collaboration avec le chœur Element. La performance interactive in situ se penche sur la question suivante: dans le chaos médiatique et globalisé actuel, dans un monde où s'entrechoquent fiction et réalité (réelle et virtuelle) jusqu'aux "faits alternatifs" et aux "nouvelles fictives", quelles sont nos réalités... comment se définir en opposition aux propagandes commerciales et politiques? Alliant poésie, humour et fantaisie, ce spectacle aborde la question sous forme de tableaux dialogués, visuels et musicaux, avec participation du public.

Les projections vidéo à grande échelle et la musique en direct en font un spectacle unique et intriguant qui inspire l’imaginaire d’un public de tout âge. Cette performance foisonne de personnages tantôt parodiques, tantôt mythiques, qui cheminent au travers des nouvelles technologies à la recherche de leur identité.

En cours de route, les protagonistes vivent de multiples péripéties: problèmes de communication, traductions erronées, jeux insensés et publicités fictives. Au moment où leur quête culmine, ils retrouvent leur nature véritable, dénudée de tout artifice médiatique: une renaissance de l’essentiel.

Our Goals/ Nos Objectifs:

There are three main goals to the project:
The first goal is interaction with the public. We believe that members of the audience complement and com- plete the performance by participating in it and moving through the piece going from one scene to the other. The audience will be involved making sounds from typewriters according to timings determined by the per- formers, playing an abstract version of scrabble, and participating in a fake conference. They'll be asked to answer questions, tell stories, translate sentences.... By including them in the action of the piece, we hope to invite them to begin their own questioning on the themes of the piece.

The second goal is to have the location transform the piece. The benefit of performing in a site specific loca- tion is that it gives us the opportunity to draw from the area's local history and architecture and use the local environment to inform the work.

The third goal is to collaborate with Christine Duncan and the Element Choir, and Kathy Kennedy and the Choeur Maha. We feel we share the same creative processes that would greatly benefit this production, both in amplifying and complementing the themes of the project as well as bringing an inter-generational and multi-disciplinary element to the piece. 

Le premier objectif est l'interaction avec le public. Nous croyons que le public complémente et complète la performance en y participant tout en se déplaçant d'une scène à l'autre. Les spectacles pop-up intégreront lee membres du public en les mpliquant dans la production de sons à partir de machines à écrire, en jouant une version abstraite de Scrabble et en participant à une fausse conférence. On leur demandera de répondre aux questions, de raconter des histoires, de traduire des phrases ... En les incluant dans l'action de la pièce, nous espérons les inciter à leur propre questionnement par rapport aux thèmes de la pièce.

Le deuxième objectif est de permettre au site de transformer la pièce. L'avantage de se produire dans un emplacement spécifique est qu'il nous donne l'opportunité de s'inspirer de l'histoire et de l'architecture locales afin d'informer l’installation et le déroulement de la performance.

Le troisième objectif est de collaborer avec Christine Duncan et le choeur Element. Nous estimons que nous partageons les mêmes processus créatifs qui profiteraient grandement à cette production, à la fois en amplifiant et en complétant les thèmes du projet et en apportant un élément intergénérationnel et multidisciplinaire à la pièce.

 Collectif BUS 1.2.3:

Collectif BUS 1.2.3.,based in Toronto, is a multi-lingual and multimedia not-for-profit professional collective formed in 1991. The group presented BUS 1.2.3, its first creation, at the Festival of Independent Dance Artists (fFIDA) in Toronto the following year. The play questioned the influence of new technologies on society at a time when the Internet was still in its infancy. 

Twenty years later, many of the original members of the collective came together again to remount the piece and update it according to current issues. Thanks to several grants from the Ontario Arts Council (2012-2015) and a project grant from the Canada Council, the collective was able to conduct several intensive research residencies, based on improvisation and collaborative creation techniques. It went on to develop a finished theatrical piece presented in a theatrical setting in 2015. The new work, building on themes of language, communication and identity, became a multi-generational, multi-lingual and multimedia production titled Babelle et Barbarie. It was presented at the Winchester St. Theatre for four nights in September 2015. The collective then decided to re-imagine the work for the public space and focus on public participation. This new piece is title "Babelledrome."

The original piece was built on improvisation, a creative process the collective decided to keep. Motivated by the desire to critique media's place in contemporary society, the collective retains elements of its previous creations (videos, recordings, musical compositions and songs ...) and reintegrates them in new projects under development. The scenic writing of the collective is based on a rich language constructed from several vocabularies, including video, music, text and performance, exploring the themes of the piece in a multi-sensory technological environment. This approach requires collaboration between singers, actors, musicians and videographer; an approach the group has been practicing since its inception. The performance doesn't therefore rest solely on text and is thus more akin to performance art than conventional theatre.

Le collectif BUS 1.2.3 est un collectif multidisciplinaire et multilingue formé en 1991. Il a présenté sa première création BUS 1.2.3 au fringe Festival of Independant Dance Artists (fFIDA) à Toronto l'année suivante. La pièce questionnait la place des nouvelles technologies dans la société contemporaine au moment de la naissance d’Internet.

Vingt ans plus tard, des membres originaux du collectif se sont réunis afin de reprendre la pièce et d’en actualiser les enjeux. Cette nouvelle collaboration a conduit à la création du spectacle multilingue Babelle et Barbarie (B+B) présenté en septembre 2015 au Winchester St. Theatre à Toronto. Les thèmes utilisés cette fois-ci portaient sur le langage, l’identité et la communication. Après ces représentations, le collectif a décidé de poursuivre sa réflexion en ré-imaginant l’oeuvre dans l’espace public et en se concentrant sur la participation du public.

La pièce originelle avait été bâtie sur un travail d’improvisation, processus créatif que le collectif a décidé de conserver. Réuni par la volonté de proposer une réflexion sur la place des médias, le collectif conserve des éléments de ses précédentes créations (vidéos, enregistrement, compositions musicales et chantées…) et les réintègrent dans les nouveaux projets en cours de développement. La démarche du collectif est ainsi inscrite dans le temps et s’adapte aux nouveaux enjeux technologiques et aux nouveaux comportements des publics.

L’écriture scénique du collectif s'appuie sur un langage fécond s'abreuvant à plusieurs vocabulaires, dont celui de la vidéo, de la musique, du texte et de la performance, explorant les thèmes de la pièce dans un environnement technologique multi sensoriel.

Cette approche exige une confrontation entre chanteuses, comédiens, musiciens et vidéaste ; un travail collaboratif tel que le groupe le pratique depuis ses débuts. Le spectacle s'apparente ainsi plus à de la performance scénique qu'à un théâtre conventionnel où tout reposerait sur le textuel.

Christine Duncan and the Element Choir:

The Element Choir is an improvising choir from Toronto led by vocalist Christine Duncan. This is a group that works with both structured and non-structured elements, based primarily on a system of conduction cues. As an ensemble they explore textural and timbral sound qualities, soundscapes, rhythmic patterns, sound poetry, group and individual composition ideas, musical genre interplay and extended voice techniques. This cinematic approach to group vocalizing presents both tonal and non-tonal material in a constantly evolving and ‘in the moment’ sonic environment.

A musical chameleon with a near five octave range, Christine Duncan uses her voice as an instrument, exploring its full tonal, timbral and textural range. She is involved with everything from jazz, R&B, gospel, improvised music, sound poetry, to new music and musique actuelle.
She performs with many musical groups and projects, most notably Hugh Fraser’s VEJI (Vancouver Ensemble of Jazz Improvisation) and Barnyard Drama with drummer/electronic artist Jean Martin. Christine also teaches voice in the jazz programs at Humber College and the University of Toronto.

The Element Choir has performed and recorded with Tanya Tagaq, as well as participated in the Apocalysis (Luminato Festival) Barnyard Drama, with Tim Berne and Snake Oil,  Shelter Opera (Tapestry New Opera), Hard Rubber Orchestra tribute to Kenny Wheeler, Veryan Weston,  Inverted Mountains, with Coleman Lemieux & Compagnie, Idiolalla West Coast Tour with DB Boyko,  L’Off Festival (Montreal) and William Parker (Guelph Jazz Festival)

Le chœur Element est une chorale d'improvisation basée à Toronto et dirigée par la chanteuse Christine Duncan. Il s'agit d'un groupe qui fonctionne avec des éléments structurés et non structurés, fondés principalement sur un système de signaux de conduction. Ensemble, les choristes explorent des paysages sonores par la texture et le timbre, les motifs rythmiques, la poésie sonore, les idées de composition en groupe et individuelles, l'interaction des genres musicaux et les techniques de voix. Cette approche cinématographique de la vocalisation de groupe présente des matériaux à la fois tonale et non tonale dans un environnement sonore en direct et en évolution constante.

Un caméléon musical avec une gamme d'environ cinq octaves, Christine Duncan utilise sa voix comme instrument, en explorant sa gamme tonale, timbrale et texturale complète. Elle est impliquée dans tous les genres musicaux, du jazz au R & B, du gospel à la musique improvisée, et de la poésie sonore à la musique contemporaine et la musique actuelle.

Elle participe à de nombreux groupes et projets musicaux, notamment le VEJI de Hugh Fraser (Ensemble d’Improvisation Jazz de Vancouver) et Barnyard Drama avec le batteur / artiste électronique Jean Martin. Christine enseigne également la voix dans les programmes de jazz au Humber College et à l'Université de Toronto.

Le chœur Element a joué et enregistré avec Tanya Tagaq, ainsi que participé à Apocalypsis (Luminato Festival), Théâtre Barnyard, avec Tim Berne et Snake Oil, Shelter Opera (Tapestry New Opera), hommage à Kenny Wheeler avec Hard Rubber Orchestra, Veryan Weston, Inverted Mountains avec Coleman Lemieux & Compagnie, Idiolalla (tournée sur la côte Ouest avec DB Boyko), L'Off Festival (Montréal) et William Parker (Festival de Jazz de Guelph).

What your money will help achieve / Ce que votre argent nous aidera à réaliser :

Your donation will help us to achieve our goals of putting on this production next June and/or July, and the money raised will be used for rehearsals and testing how to best integrate audience participation and interactivity into the show. We have also been awarded a grant from the Ontario Arts Council for the actual performance, and are applying for further grants. Yet we are short of our planned budget of $48 000 to make this show a realization and your help will go towards achieving this. If, unfortunately, the full budget cannot be achieved, we will adjust the performance to fit  into the budget constraints. However, we still need your help for the research and development stage of the project.

Votre don nous aidera à atteindre nos objectifs de mise en production en juin et / ou juillet prochains, et l'argent recueilli sera utilisé pour les répétitions et tester la meilleure façon d'intégrer la participation et l'interactivité du public au spectacle. Nous avons également reçu une subvention du Conseil des arts de l'Ontario pour les représentations et nous demandons d'autres subventions. Pourtant, nous sommes à court de notre budget prévu de 48 000 $ pour que ce spectacle soit réalisé et votre aide sera versée à cette fin. Si, malheureusement, le budget total ne peut être atteint, nous allons modifier la performance pour tenir compte des contraintes budgétaires. Cependant, nous avons encore besoin de votre aide pour la phase de recherche et de développement du projet.

Other ways that you can help / Autres moyens que vous pouvez aider:

We will be looking for volunteers to help run the show next year in June/July. If you wish to help please contact info@collectifbus123.com
