story:
For 35 years--through workshops, retreats, classes and productions--we at ANDTheatre Company (aka Artistic New Directions) have developed new theatre pieces. We have a special interest in the intersection of improvisational and scripted theatre. Without-a-Net is one intersection.

For a Without-a-Net production, we give an original five-character play to five directors who, in turn, each cast five different actors. The play is rehearsed separately by each director and cast. Then, over two weeks, we present 25 performances of this one play with a different cast for every performance. At each performance, one actor is called from each of the five companies. The five actors encounter each other for the first time when they meet on stage. While they all have prepared their own characters (they have memorized their lines and understand the relationships to the other characters as written), they encounter the other characters as played anew every time the lights come up. They fly without a net in a performance requiring complete trust. The lines may be set but in all other respects the show is improvised, with discoveries surprising those on either side of the lights.

This production concept was introduced to us by Gary Garrison and Roland Tec when they offered their play The Rubber Room to be produced in this manner. A thought-provoking piece about New York City’s practice of moth-balling public school teachers with disciplinary issues for years at full pay, the show appealed to the theatrical community because of its daring and the educational community because of its provocative subject matter. Two years later, we offered Kristine Niven’s Human Resources, a bittersweet look at white collar workers in a shrinking employment market, and two years after that Café Pen, set in a small town with an economy based on the local federal penitentiary, the script explored a community of characters who live outside the prison walls but whose lives are linked to those serving on the inside.

Human Resources and Café Pen were both developed through another of ANDTheatre’s programs, the annual Summer Salt Playprov Retreat, where the playwright researched the characters and their encounters through a series of guided improvisations. The scripts continued to be developed through AND-sponsored readings and workshops. Their presentation as a Without-a-Net project is a fulfillment of the company’s mission to generate, revise, and polish a piece till it’s ready for a public audience.

Our 2017 Without-a-Net script has been developed as described above, through the programs of ANDTheatre Company.  Buried in Time, written by Kristine Niven,  tells the story of  what happens when Charlotte Donohue, a woman who has made her mark in New York City,  returns home to Guthrie, PA, population 6000, for the funeral of her father. She meets her high school/college boyfriend, his niece, and a childhood mentor. Along with Charlotte's brother, they prepare for the funeral. As they prepare for the funeral, we discover everyone has something to bury, put to rest, or uncover. 

Without-a-Net is a huge project for our little company. With 25 actors, five directors, five stage managers, plus the talents of set, lighting and costuming designers, our budget needs help. The complete budget is below. We are hoping to raise $7,500 towards it. Box office receipts are projected to bring in $5000-6000 (tickets are priced between $10 and $18, and as an Equity production, we are required to comp Equity actors and industry people, e.g. casting directors, agents, producers, directors). The balance will come from a recent benefit and our general funds. The company is determined to present this project. Your support will help move intention to realization.

Budget - Without-a-Net: Buried in Time

Facility Rental

Rehearsal $4800

Theatre $4400

Auditions $ 250

Production Mtngs $ 100

Design Fees

Sets $ 100

Lighting $ 100

Costume $ 100

Sound $ 100

Graphics $ 100

Production Fees

Prod Stage Mgr $ 100

Asst PSM $ 100

3 Stage Managers $ 100

25 Actors $2500

5 Directors $ 500

Playwright $ 100

Box Office Mgr $ 100

Production Expenses

Sets $2000

Lighting $ 400

Costumes $ 200

Props $ 400

Insurance $ 185

Credit Card Fees $ 100

Postcards/Posters $ 350

Programs $ 500

Marketing/PR $3000

Copying $ 200

Closing Night $ 700

Trucking $ 300

4 Load In/Out Crew $ 400

TOTAL BUDGET $22,585

Box office receipts are projected to bring in $5000-6000 (tickets are priced between $10 and $18, and as an Equity production, we are required to comp Equity actors and industry people, e.g. casting directors, agents, producers, directors). The balance will come from a recent benefit and our general funds. The company is determined to present this project. Your support will help move intention to realization.
Budget - Without-a-Net: Buried in Time

Theatre $4400
Auditions $ 250
Production Mtngs $ 100
Design Fees

TOTAL BUDGET $22,585

story:
The Fertile River has been selected by The Atlanta Black Theatre Festival for two main stage performances at the beautiful Porter Sanford Performing Arts Center this October 2016! 

  Vincent Terrell Durham and Alton J. Patton III.

It’s the summer of 1958.  Mrs. Sarah Woods has been visiting colored families in the small rural North Carolina community.  Armed with her eugenics board questionnaire, she has been doling out sterilization orders to families of the afflicted.  Already ashamed of having imperfect children and impaired family members, the targeted households keep their new misery a tightly held secret.  Mama Cora is the latest to receive an appointment notice from Mrs. Woods.  The sixty-four-year-old woman has no idea what a white social worker from the government would need to see her about.  But being a colored woman of the south, she knows the visit is a call for caution.

The Fertile River made its West Coast premiere on November 15, 2015.  The piece was presented as an exclusive one-time stage reading at The Actor's Company in Hollywood, CA. 

Click here to listen to an interview on Encounters with Eric & Eliza Roberts - Go to 13:45

Directed by Nancy Cheryll Davis, the reading received a standing ovation.  Miss Davis is a director, actress, producer, and co-founder of Towne Street Theatre.  TST is fresh off a successful three-week run of In Response.  Miss Davis and Vincent Terrell Durham teamed up again with her direction of Tomatoes/Tomahtoes and A Concern of National Interest.      
                                                                          

Learn more about TST, Click here: Towne Street Theatre

As a brilliant actress, Nancy Cheryll Davis has been invited to present her riveting one-woman show, Passing Solo, to German audiences in the fall of 2016. 

To learn more about Passing Solo, Click here: Passing Solo


The Fertile River is now excited to make its East Coast premiere at the 5th Annual Atlanta Black Theatre Festival.  We are passionate about sharing this vital piece of new American Theatre, and ask our INDIEGOGO contributors to help us in achieving this goal.

Jump into the Fertile River

The Atlanta Black Theatre Festival is a 10-day self-produced event.  The Fertile River will be featured on the main stage in two live performances, October 14th at 6pm and October 15th at 3pm.

Your generous INDIEGOGO contribution will benefit us in the following ways:

A six week L.A. rehearsal.    

Air travel from L.A. to ATL for a production team of 11, including 5 cast members. 

Hotel accommodations, meals, and ground transportation for a 6 to 10 night stay. 

Festival fees, 2-day main stage rental.

Set design, graphic image creation, costuming, playbill printing, poster production, and advertising.

Compensation for actors, director, stage manager, and lighting tech.

                                                                            

The Impact

Our debut at the Atlanta Black Theatre Festival will help us continue telling the story of the forgotten victims of the American Eugenics Movement.  We pay tribute to the thousands impacted, by sharing the story of The Fertile River.

The Eugenics Board of North Carolina thrived from the 1930’s to the 1970’s.  The members of the board sought out the weakest in society for gene elimination.  The feebleminded, lame, blind, epileptic, deaf, promiscuous, impoverished, and people of color became the prime targets for sterilization procedures.  Eugenics - Unfit to Breed


Original Artistic Image

We are excited to announce that renown Artist Andre Rochester, of Hartford, CT, will debut an original work of art inspired by The Fertile River at the Atlanta Black Theatre Festival!

Click here to learn more about Andre Rochester, and view his work.

Spoken Word Artist

We are honored to have award winning poet Food4Thot lending us his incredible talents! The prolific spoken word artist will set it off for both the October 14th and October 15th performances of The Fertile River! Don't miss this brother's poetic genius!
Click here to learn more about Food4Thot

Click here to watch "When I Speak" By Food4Thot


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone will be able to contribute a monetary gift.  Please consider sharing our campaign with your family and friends.  You can also send us an encouraging tweet or like our Facebook Page.     

Twitter - @TheFertileRiver       Facebook - The Fertile River                                                                                             

Thank You & Welcome toThe Fertile River Family!

Alton and Vincent

Twitter - @TheFertileRiver       Facebook - The Fertile River                                                                                               Thank You & Welcome toThe Fertile River Family!


Alton and Vincent

story:
Montreal's Finest Magical, Burlesque, Musical, and Theater performers are getting together to bring this year's WEIRDEST show to Fringe Festival.

This is a show that will change you: entice you: bring you to the point of madness, all from the safety of your chair, as the great revelation of the Clavis Argentum transforms the way you see theater, and the world, FOREVER!

This show will infect your dreams with its profound apocalyptic expositions and nightmarish visions. It will teach you how to navigate those dreams, so that you too can become an Enlightened Master!

Now is your chance to get in on the ground floor. To make all this happen, we need your help! A few dollars from you will open the gates and bring forth the stratagems of our Inner Circle so that these profound truths can finally be revealed to the world! 

When the snowball begins to roll down hill, and this show becomes the biggest and most talked about phenomenon on the Montreal Theater Scene, you will want to have the privilege of telling people you were there first. That YOU gave your hard earned money to make it happen!
That YOU ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE HORRORS THAT WERE UNLEASHED UPON THEIR FRAGILE PSYCHES!

And we will reward you for your generosity with merchandise and paraphernalia to prove to them that you are ONE OF THE CHOSEN!
We have been waiting for centuries to present the fruits of our hard mystical labour to the world. And now the Stars Are RIGHT!

We have chosen the St. Ambroise Montreal Fringe festival June 9-18th 2016 as the perfect time to reveal centuries of hidden wisdom to the public.  

We believe the true MYSTERIES of the UNSEEN WORLD can not be stated in simple language, and so we have hidden them in the abstractions of our art. Join us if you want to see the GREAT SECRETS of the ancient world revealed.

The Elder Ones have taught us the secrets of their occult technology. They have shown us how close our species are to the precipice. The revelations that will be shown to you in our presentation are the only way that life on this planet can be preserved from what is coming, and YOU can be part of the movement that brings these secrets to the public before it is TOO LATE!
Be warned! Once you see our show you will never be the same. 

Our initial run will be at Theatre St. Catherine, 264 Rue Sainte-Catherine E, Montréal, QC H2X 1L4 from June 9-16th as part of the St. Ambroise Montreal Fringe festival. 


The Clavis Argentum will have a second run with almost twice the running time at the Crowley Center, 5325 Crowley Ave, H4A 2C6 Montreal QC. (in NDG) in later fall.  More truth soon.

But these secrets do not come without cost. Our production will require help from YOU if it is to move forward its plan to Immenantize the Eschaton.


Our budget is as follows:

Montreal Fringe Fees: 620.00

Theatre St.Catherines venue fees: 500.00

Posters, promo video, effects ,Robes, knives etc: 300.00

Live band: 520.00

Make-up, Magic Props : 580.00

These funds are going to be used totally for the show, every dollar we get goes to funding the experience. Our show will feature a live jazz band performing original score composed by the up and coming MAESTRO Ilya Pechersky.

Quite simply put, the more we get through this campaign the greater and more awe inspiring we can make our rite.

We have a dedicated flock that is working night and day to bring this truth to light.

Our Inner Circle production team :

Producer/Director Jason McCullough, better known as Jimmy Phule Burlesque host and award winning Fringe producer.

Marisa Parisella, our creative photographic genius  www.mparisella.wix.com/glamourmtl and stage-management for the Clavis Argentum.

And Matt Risk : Magician and writer and Keeper of the secret of the Clavis Argentum

Together they have hundreds of shows experience and work in concert to bring Matt's vision to the people. The Clavis Argentum also has the virtue of some of the most beautiful and gifted burlesque movers and shakers in Canada.


JolieStripes 

Velma Candyass

Baron Von Styck

Natasha Nebula

And more…

Fringe Show times:

Thursday June 9th  7:15pm

Saturday June 11th  3:45pm

Sunday  June 12th  2:00pm

Tuesday  June 14th  9:00pm

Thursday June 16th  5:30pm

Friday  June 17th  9:00pm

Saturday June 18th  1:45pm

Sunday June 19th  4:00pm

story:
Short Summary

My name is Gloria Bacon. I am a dancer, choreographer and the organizer of the International Modern Dance Festival in Nicaragua.  I have been promoting modern dance in my country for over 30 years. 

As a dancer in Nicaragua I see and live the limitations of being an artist in Central America.  Little funding to produce new work, to travel and to attend workshops.  To grow as an artist and encourage new generators of dancers to push the boundaries, I found the need to bring the international modern dance movement home. 

I created the festival with the purpose to offer my students and the dance community in Nicaragua an opportunity to see and exchange ideas with dancers from all over the world.

For 22 years this festival has offered nicaraguan and international dancers a space to exchange ideas and make long lasting relationships. This year we will celebrate the 23rd edition of the International Dance Festival and we are expecting groups from Germany, Sweden, Spain, Mexico, Canada, Paraguay and Central America.

What We Need & What You Get

With the money we raise through this fundraising campaign we will cover the cost of lodging, in country transportation, food and productions for the dancers that are arriving for the festival. this year we are expecting over 25 dancers from all over the world who will be performing in different cities and venues around Nicaragua. 

We are offering great perks in exchange for your donation like: tickets to shows, access to the workshops and seminars, t-shirts of the festival and our most heartfelt gratitude. For the people that are able to donate more we offer full access to all the shows and workshops, a t-shirt, an invitation to the welcome dinner and a chance to have Art-tempo perform at your next event or party.

Every dollar helps. The money raised will go towards the cost of running this festival. 

So please help us continue this work that has enriched the lives of so many people in our community as well as abroad.   

The Impact

The dance movement in Nicaragua is still developing and many dancers professional and aspiring have limited access to new trends in the dance world.  It is important to open spaces of exchange and offer people here the opportunity to explore, learn and experience different types of modern dance.  

The relationships that dancers have made during the festival have led to international tours and exchanges, scholarships for youth and has opened a dialogue of the importance of contemporary culture in Central America.  

Risks & Challenges

For 22 years I have gone door to door, made phone calls, sent emails to local business and government agencies.  Through the different donations here and there we have been able to house, feed and cover the cost of production for the International Modern Dance Festival.  Each year is a challenge and each year it has been unbelievable rewarding. 

This year are usual donors were not able to help us. Which is why I'm reaching out to you and your network to give us a hand this year. The show must go on!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help today please share this campaign with your network and help us get the word out! 

Spread the word! Share the love!

story:
Stackin' Styles Vol. 1 will be taking place on Saturday the 23rd, 2017 at Harvard University and will have workshops the day of and on the following day Sunday the 24th,
'click here' for the Facebook event page*

Short Summary

Stiggity | Style, Creativity 
Stackz | To build, expand, one piece at a time  

"I've spent the past 10 years of my life completely devoted to the dance art culture. Exploring, learning, teaching, traveling, competing, performing, collaborating, and collecting data to be able to bring to life a growing brain child that I am honored to finally launch, StiggityStackz Worldwide Inc".  - Ashton Lites 

This start up company offers affordable urban art related services, intellectual property, clothing, and merchandise, all layered in the principle of using urban art to build or "Stack" on important aspects of an individuals life, so in return, they can be of better service to their own community. Stackin' Styles Vol. 1 will not only be a powerful launch for the company but for the entire Boston urban dance community
 

What We Need & What You Get

We want Stackin’ Styles Vol. 1 to provide you with a high quality experience, and our expenses reflect that. Here is a small breakdown:

  • 4 elite battle guests competing AND teaching at Stackin’ Styles. Dopey Fresh (CA), PopNTod, (CA), Whiteboi (CO), and Stephy Stylez (NJ).
  • We are bringing in one of the best DJ's in the urban dance culture, Captain Puerto Rico, from Baltimore, Maryland. 
  • Boston's hometown hero, Chad Shabazz, will be our MC/Host.
  • Tyrell Black will be flying in from Toronto ON to join Stackz on the judge panel (Soul Brothers) 
  •  Production/ media team featuring some of Boston's local creatives 
  • We will hand out awards at the event to honor some of Boston's most dedicated contributors.
  •  Cash & prizes totaling up to $500 
  • A dance floor and game show themed set up.
  • Studio rental for workshops.
  • Advertising and marketing expenses. 

We need $2500 to cover these expenses.  $1000 will go directly to StiggityStackz Worldwide Inc to assist with the start up costs. 

 

The Impact

Our goal is to bring all hands on deck to get the ship sailing in the Boston urban dance community. Your contribution will help us reach our community development goals!  Stackin' Stylez vol. 1 is layered with opportunities to improve our city’s dance culture: 

  • The presence of our battle guests and other world class dancers will provide Boston with the highest level of competition our city has seen in years.
  • Our judges and battle guests will provide high level dance education at our exclusive event workshops. (See Facebook event page for event format)   
  • This experience will provide networking and collaboration opportunities aimed at uniting Boston’s influential artists with dancers, studios, and organizations from other regions.

Stackin’ Styles’ unique format has enjoyed major success at similar competitions in other cities and countries:  

  • Urban Artistry of Washington DC were the first to offer this educational format at their event, The Book of Styles. They since been able to grow their own community and spread their influence worldwide. 
  • Jack of All Trades, in Montreal, attracts high level dancers from all over the world at each of their installments. Inspired by The Book of Styles, their educational format is a high point at their event as well. 
  • Our Judge Tyrell Black's company, The BLACKOUT, had an amazing turnout at his event using the “2 to Lose” format, which we are excited to incorporate at Stackin' Stylez Vol. 1.

Risks & Challenges

Any new event faces the challenge of being well-attended and properly funded.  We have implemented strategies to decrease the risk of low numbers at this event: 

  • We have created company discounts in addition to already discounted event and workshop packages.  We hope this incentive urges dancers of all backgrounds to attend!
  • We have secured a quality event line up whose reputation should attract other inspired dancers from multiple regions.
  • We have incorporated outside feedback to create an event built in the interest of all our communities.

Regardless of attendance, we guarantee people will leave Stackin’ Styles Vol. 1 satisfied and wanting to come back for more. Your contributions will help a company devoted to improving the community. 

As artists that have experienced many challenges, we are ready to make due :)  Even if we don't reach our financial goal, we will move forward with the support we’ve already received, though we may not be able to fairly compensate the guests we’ve recruited to make this a special event.  We are already blessed to have friends who have supported us with graphics, a venue, an amazing sound system, lighting, and volunteered to staff our event – but we need more help.

We hope YOU can help make Stackin’ Styles Vol. 1 the highest quality event possible!

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand if you can't contribute financially but want you to know you can still have a helping hand in this project. 

  • Help us spread the word about our Indiegogo campaign, Stackin’ Styles Vol. 1, and StiggityStackz Worldwide Inc. Improving our reach is a huge bonus for us and opens up possibilities to increase participants and contributors. Use the Indiegogo share tools, “Like” our Facebook page, “Follow” our Instagram, and “Subscribe” to our youtube channel.
  • If you have a service or product that could potentially help our campaign or event, please let us know!
  • Lastly, your feedback is extremely important to us. Contact us via email if you have any feedback. Support@StiggityStackzWorldwide.org 

Thank you so much! 
Stackin' Stylez Vol. 1 Team

Studio rental for workshops.
Advertising and marketing expenses. 

We need $2500 to cover these expenses.  $1000 will go directly to StiggityStackz Worldwide Inc to assist with the start up costs. 
 

The Impact
Our goal is to bring all hands on deck to get the ship sailing in the Boston urban dance community. Your contribution will help us reach our community development goals!  Stackin' Stylez vol. 1 is layered with opportunities to improve our city’s dance culture: 

The presence of our battle guests and other world class dancers will provide Boston with the highest level of competition our city has seen in years.
Our judges and battle guests will provide high level dance education at our exclusive event workshops. (See Facebook event page for event format)   
This experience will provide networking and collaboration opportunities aimed at uniting Boston’s influential artists with dancers, studios, and organizations from other regions.

Stackin’ Styles’ unique format has enjoyed major success at similar competitions in other cities and countries:  

Urban Artistry of Washington DC were the first to offer this educational format at their event, The Book of Styles. They since been able to grow their own community and spread their influence worldwide. 

Jack of All Trades, in Montreal, attracts high level dancers from all over the world at each of their installments. Inspired by The Book of Styles, their educational format is a high point at their event as well. 
Our Judge Tyrell Black's company, The BLACKOUT, had an amazing turnout at his event using the “2 to Lose” format, which we are excited to incorporate at Stackin' Stylez Vol. 1.



Risks & Challenges
Any new event faces the challenge of being well-attended and properly funded.  We have implemented strategies to decrease the risk of low numbers at this event: 

We have created company discounts in addition to already discounted event and workshop packages.  We hope this incentive urges dancers of all backgrounds to attend!
We have secured a quality event line up whose reputation should attract other inspired dancers from multiple regions.
We have incorporated outside feedback to create an event built in the interest of all our communities.

Regardless of attendance, we guarantee people will leave Stackin’ Styles Vol. 1 satisfied and wanting to come back for more. Your contributions will help a company devoted to improving the community. 
As artists that have experienced many challenges, we are ready to make due :)  Even if we don't reach our financial goal, we will move forward with the support we’ve already received, though we may not be able to fairly compensate the guests we’ve recruited to make this a special event.  We are already blessed to have friends who have supported us with graphics, a venue, an amazing sound system, lighting, and volunteered to staff our event – but we need more help.
We hope YOU can help make Stackin’ Styles Vol. 1 the highest quality event possible!

Other Ways You Can Help
We completely understand if you can't contribute financially but want you to know you can still have a helping hand in this project. 

Help us spread the word about our Indiegogo campaign, Stackin’ Styles Vol. 1, and StiggityStackz Worldwide Inc. Improving our reach is a huge bonus for us and opens up possibilities to increase participants and contributors. Use the Indiegogo share tools, “Like” our Facebook page, “Follow” our Instagram, and “Subscribe” to our youtube channel.
If you have a service or product that could potentially help our campaign or event, please let us know!
Lastly, your feedback is extremely important to us. Contact us via email if you have any feedback. Support@StiggityStackzWorldwide.org 

Thank you so much! Stackin' Stylez Vol. 1 Team

story:
*ALL DONATIONS ARE 501c(3) TAX DEDUCTIBLE*

 

Summary

We need your help to fund this year's Fringe Encore Series.  Started 12 years ago to give top Fringe shows a platform to grow and develop their shows, the Fringe Encore Series has transformed into an internationally recognized festival that curates and develops the top Fringe shows from around the world.  Each Fall, the SoHo Playhouse hosts the Fringe Encore Series.  

This year, we want to bring 16 of the world's top Fringe shows to New York City to perform at the SoHo Playhouse. These shows will push the boundaries of conventional theatre forcing the artist and audience to push the envelope.  

Without contribution, the Fringe Encore Series goes away.  Without the Fringe Encore Series, so much of the risk taking needed to push the performing arts forward goes away.  

Why We Need $100,000

We need $100,000 to begin production on this year's Fringe Encore Series.  We can raise a lot of the money from ticket sales, but that is not enough to get started.  There is no New York Fringe Festival this year, meaning that this year's show are going to be coming from across the world.  We need to raise $100,000 to get the 16 shows from across the world back to New York City.  

  • $50,000 will be used to bring the 16 shows back to New York City. 
  • $50,000 will be used as production budget for the shows

What is the Fringe Encore Series 

SoHo Playhouse in New York City is proud to officially host the 2017 Fringe International Encore Series. This year marks the 12th annual Fringe Encore Series. This will be the first year the series expands to include shows from Adelaide, Brighton, Edinburgh, Hollywood and Winnipeg Fringe Festivals. What is the Fringe Encore Series? After years of seeing buzz generated behind several Fringe shows, having them sell out all their festival performances and turn away people at the door and then finding them not being able to find the backing or a space to extend their production; something had to be done, and that is how the Fringe Encore Series was started. Headquartered at the historic SoHo Playhouse, the Fringe Encore Series created a festival to extend these worthy productions The Series gives these shows an additional run at SoHo Playhouse, with the goal of turning these short runs into future productions and successes here in New York City.

Running September and October 2017 this year’s series will present a selection of audience favorites and critical successes selected by a host of theatrical producers, directors and promoters selected from the top Off Broadway Theatres in New York. 

The Encore Series helps make this a reality by working with the shows and theaters providing visiting companies, the venue, press representation, technical support, advertising and marketing along with offering developmental advice for each production. Past audiences, along with critics and industry, have found the series to be one of the finest ways to discover emerging companies and writers.

The Series has teams of scouts going to each festival. Once a committee member expresses an interest in a specific show, a representative will make contact with the show to start inquiring as to interest and hopefully facilitating their inclusion in the Encore Series. For more information please Contact mail@sohoplayhouse.com

The Impact

Many of the past productions in the series, such as Drama Desk Nominees Krapp 39 from FringeNYC 2008, Jamaica Farewell FringeNYC 2009 and Rap Guide To Religion from Edinburgh Fringe 2015 have gone on to extensive Off-Broadway runs and international success.  Fringe Festival, and consequently Fringe Encore Series is a launching pad for so many different artists.

Michael Laurence performed Krapp 39 a little over 10 years ago at the Fringe Festival and then the Fringe Encore Series which went on to international success.  

One of the turning points in Michael Shannon's storied career was performing at the SoHo Playhouse, Killer Joe.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can, please share this campaign with your networks, both online and offline.  Every little bit of support means the world.

story:
EPIC FOG THEATRE COMPANY NEEDS YOUR HELP

Two years ago, as a response to our successful production of “Hamlet,” we produced an even more successful production of “Arsenic and Old Lace.” Last year we took time off from producing, but now we are back, with a brand new production of Oscar Wilde’s “The Importance of Being Earnest: A Trivial Comedy about Serious People.”  Our production will go up in February here in New York City: but theatre is not cheap! To keep ticket prices affordable, our budgets have to be so low that it’s hard to pay for, well, anything. In addition to period costumes, the play has three different locations, meaning three sets.

Your donation will help pay for the construction of sets and costumes, the theatre rental, and stipends for our actors and crew. We are planning to pay our actors a larger stipend this time round as well. Our goal $7,500 with a stretch goal of $9,000. The more we make, the more elaborate we can make our sets and the better dressed our actors will be.

The creative team from “Hamlet” and “Arsenic and Old Lace” has been reassembled. Michael Cramer and Hanna Edwards return as producers, and Craig Hutchison will once again direct. Since Arsenic, Michael and Hanna have been working in independent film. Hanna has also been heavily involved in projects at The Actor’s Green Room, and she just shot a commercial (in Spanish). Craig has directed plays with Black Orchid Theatre Company and Nu*Ance Theatre, including directing Michael as Elwood P. Dowd in “Harvey.” This fall,  Craig directed the complete “Oresteia” trilogy by Aeschylus in which Michael portrayed Agamemnon.   

We chose “The Importance of Being Earnest” primarily because we wanted to do another comedy, and because we had the perfect Algernon in fellow actor Cedar Brock. It’s a smaller cast than our last two productions, which will make things a bit easier. However, it has greater demands in terms of sets or even costumes than our earlier plays--it’s easy for us to costume people in Renaissance or 1940s America, but Victorian England is a whole other matter.  

“The Importance of Being Earnest” is a farce of manners--if there can be such a thing--about two men, Jack Worthing and his friend Algernon Moncrief. In order to avoid their everyday responsibilities, they have each created an imaginary person. Algernon has invented an imaginary invalid named Bunburry, whom he has to visit in the country whenever he wants to escape town, while Jack has concocted a fake brother named Earnest, whose indolent ways draw Jack to London whenever he wants a night on the town. 

The play was first performed at St. James’ theatre in London on Valentine’s Day, 1895, starring the actor manager George Alexander as Jack. Most critics were unimpressed. George Bernard Shaw called the play “heartless,” While William Archer wrote that it was nothing more than the expression of an irrepressibly witty personality. H. G. Wells, however, considered it one of the funniest plays of the season, and also saw a message in it, joking in his review “...how Serious People will take this Trivial Comedy intended for their learning remains to be seen. No doubt seriously.”

The play closed early due to the scandal surrounding Wilde's affair with Lord Alfred Douglas, which led to his imprisonment for homosexuality. As Wilde’s reputation was rehabilitated after his release from prison, so were his plays, and Earnest was revived several times, first by Alexander then others. Eventually it became one of the most popular plays in the British repertory. It’s been adapted for radio and television, made into six musicals, two operas, and two popular film versions, exactly 50 years apart. In 1995, the British critic and journalist Mark Lawson declared it the second most known and quoted play in English, after Hamlet.

PLEASE support independent theatre by donating to our campaign today!

story:
This is the first edition of Practicing Performance: a 2-week dance festival at The Ohio State University that aims at bringing European based and American artists together to share, exchange, perform and play in a safe and creative environment.

PP wants to create an environment where conversation is at the fulcrum of each and every practice. The exchange of knowledge through classes, workshops, practices, and performances begins with discourse about the what, why, and how of what we do in our field.

This 2-week course is aimed for 18 and up, professional dancers, makers, choreographers, artists, and performers to develop their stage and creative skills. We offer training with international active choreographers and teachers.

 
  • Days will include various classes and workshops.
  • Nights will include Performances + Wednesday Skillperts nights + Nobody’s Business + Mental Gardening.
  • Visit the website to find more information! www.practicingperformance.com 

We Albert Quesada (ZOO/Thomas Hauert) and Katie Vickers (Martin Nachbar, Deborah Hay, Cullberg Ballet) are two dancers/choreographers/teachers living and working in between the U.S. and Brussels, Belgium. Traveling back and forth, we wanted to see more of a dialogue between these two dance communities, thus the birth of Practicing Performance. We hope this platform can be a start into bringing people together to ask questions within two very different contexts, share experiences, and enrich the field at large.

 

So, we invited a group of very talented artists:

Andrew Robinson Champlin (Miguel Gutierrez, Xavier le Roy, Pam Tanowitz)

Eleanor Bauer (Rosas, Trisha Brown, Matthew Barney, Boris Charmatz)

Tale Dolven (Rosas)

Gabel Eiben (Nature Theatre of Oklahoma, SITI Company)

 

WHAT WE NEED: We can't do this without your help! 

We have an ambitious sum of money to reach but are confident that these two communities can come together to make this happen! We are looking for $8.000 to be able to cover:

  • travel costs
  • accommodation
  • teachers fees
  • promotion + marketing
  • studio rentals
  • tech [sound|lighting| for the performances

Please know that whether you donate* $5 or $3,000 every penny counts and it really does make a difference!

We are so passionate that no matter how the funds go, we will push forward with this first year's festival edition. We are engaged with our artists and believe the community will benefit tremendously from it.

THE IMPACT 

We believe art is necessary for a society where new points of view, reflection, and communication are essential for a better living. With this festival, we want to practice sharing and exchanging, a place where people can meet on equal grounds to share tools, knowledge, and to foster a sense of togetherness. We hope that by gathering artists from different backgrounds and contexts sparks an environment where we can support different ways of working and thinking.

 

A festival is a space.

This space is supportive and caring.

This space is working towards the development of art practices.

This space is an exchange of ideas.

This space is critically thinking about dance and its place today.

This space is for training skills (for performance, for creation).

 

 

RISKS & CHALLENGES

This is our first year starting PP and with that, there are always challenges and huge risks to face.

We foresee three major challenges:

  • Organizing the 2-week festival to our vision
  • Getting the needed funding
  • Attracting artists and participants to the festival.

We hope to overcome these challenges with our experience:

  • As directors: (we have directed a summer program, Performing Arts Intensive, for over 5 years at Mercersburg Academy. As directors, we’ve organized the festival from start to finish from newsletters and marketing to the final performances at the end of two weeks.)
  • As creators: we have created over 12 dance performances over the last 10 years, including looking for funding, employing other artists, and managing the company's touring.
  • As teachers: we have taught in many countries, in academies, private studios, and universities.

With this experience and the help of the other artists, we are confident that Practicing Performance in any shape or form will be a success.

 

Can't donate but still want to help?

Some people can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Reach out to us as we get closer to find out if there are organizational ways in which you can be involved with the festival.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!


 

Video credits:

Video footage: used with permission by Andrew Champlin, Eleanor Bauer, Tale Dolven, Gabel Eiben, Albert Quesada, Katie Vickers  Video editing: Albert Quesada
